original_text:
Overall the gaming experience was good and I've had a quite some fun. There's a bit awkward difficulty spike towards the end, mostly involving slightly to big hitboxes and lack of appropriate space to maneuver, but it's within an acceptable margin.

The story is simple, but interesting enough. 
It probably stems from the fact that they've kept in mind that our protagonist is indeed just a little girl. 
She's scared, but not in the manner an adult would be. She wonders about the spirits, at times getting spooked and surprised, but she doesn't really feel the horror. She lacks the adult viewpoint and just doesn't want to be alone and lonely. 

While I've had no issues myself it's certainly sad to see the amount of people which issues running the game. 
But please don't get discouraged. The actual game itself is certainly worth of the "Mostly Positive" rating.
Consider taking a look at this guide:

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1184305463

Also, fullscreen with a desktop resolution above 1920x1080 is horrid, please turn it off and use "Scaling - Stretch" which is the devs unique way of saying "borderless window/fullscreen mode".  I'm not sure what would happen on older 4:3 or Ultra-wide monitors though.

A bit too many things have been left unexplained for my taste. Mind you, I'm not talking about the story. I'm fine with that. I'm talking about sub-events and mechanics. I would've liked a couple more of helpful remarks from the girl herself and more useful hints in the easier to find note/message type collectibles.

The most notable problem is that the statue quick save just functions as a re-spawn point and doesn't truly save progress unlike the save at home. 

The other major thing that bothered me is the way the map only ever gets truly completed by performing a certain, late-game action, which makes thing awkward.  Before that there's various spots on the map that unavoidably will make you worry about whether or not you've missed something, even though you've been through in your exploration efforts.

Talking about exploration. Most collectibles are reasonable easy to find as long as you thoroughly search the town and interact with the various spirits. However, after you've spent a couple of hours you might notice that there're are, probably three, items which really shouldn't make you feel too bad about taking a look at:

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=761744358

They're items based on sub-events with low chances. Getting them involves repeated actions aka farming. And it doesn't help that the game does NEVER straightforwardly tell you that you need to go home to properly reset things and get your next chance.

And if you're an achievement hunter let's not forget to talk about the ridiculous 50 hour achievement. I gave up looking for the above mentioned items around the 12 hours mark. Walking around in free roam quickly gets tedious, because there's no real variation. I would bet someone with better gaming sense could find everything in this amount of time and more ambitious people would struggle for another 12 hours and get it done by then. But there's just no way to realistically spent 50 hours in this world. So get ready to use a save game or idle in-game. If you're planning to idle be sure to stay out of the menus and save occasionally, because it's your save game that needs to log 50 hours and not steam.

Now one last little thing I would like to warn about, [b] a tiny spoiler [/b], is something that could possibly happen to you:

[spoiler] If you're in the factory there'll be an auto quick save after you've crossed the large pipe. At this point make sure you get the relatively close by "Rusty small key". Getting this key can be somewhat tough challenge and you might have to try multiple times. If you go explore in the wrong direction, find the statue and quick save you'll have doomed yourself to a long walk, tedious walk for each try.  [/spoiler]

At this point make sure you get the relatively close by "Rusty small key".
Getting this key can be somewhat tough challenge and you might have to try multiple times.
If you go explore in the wrong direction, find the statue and quick save you'll have doomed yourself to a long walk, tedious walk for each try. [/spoiler]

original_text: I have not finished the game yet, but this was just what I was itching for! Gylt is a beautiful game with an interesting narrative and design, which heavily reminds me of Coraline with fairy tales elements. I was looking for a game that would make me struggle to put the controller down and that was just it! However, it is worth noting that the game is not challenging mecanic wise, operating like a sort of the last of us for children: you will defintely not need most of the ressources but it's nice to sometimes just enjoy the game and not pull elden ring moves. Super excited to see where this ends!

original_text: Imagine if you could share a Silent Hill game with your 10 year old. It's a stealth action horror game: you aren't helpless, but you will probably lose any stand up fight against any groups of more than one or two enemies. The aesthetic, theming and difficulty curve are all appropriate for younger gamers, but will still be a lightweight diversion for older audiences. graphics and sound are all polished, no bugs or jank in the gameplay.

analysis_results.chunk: Imagine if you could share a Silent Hill game with your 10 year old.
It's a stealth action horror game: you aren't helpless, but you will probably lose any stand up fight against any groups of more than one or two enemies.

The aesthetic, theming and difficulty curve are all appropriate for younger gamers, but will still be a lightweight diversion for older audiences. graphics and sound are all polished, no bugs or jank in the gameplay.

original_text:
This is a perfect example of how a single mechanic can undermine an otherwise unforgettable experience. In this case, it's the boss fights—or rather, boss "events".

For most of the game, you're immersed in beautifully eerie nighttime settings, avoiding spooky ghosts. You wander through dark streets, listening for the sound of your heartbeat as it warns of nearby danger. Along the way, you collect trinkets, admire the "child's drawing" art style which I loved, pet the cats, grow close to your friend and, of course, to the adorable pomeranian.
Then, out of nowhere, you're thrust into what feels like a Dark Souls boss fight—but without rolling, without stamina, without a weapon, and without fun. You’ll die over and over, trying to figure out the boss’s patterns, only to dodge with your sluggish speed.

This game wasn’t built for these kinds of encounters. It could have been an incredible horror experience, but they squandered that potential by forcing in frustrating "boss action" sequences that, quite frankly, no one asked for—or enjoyed.

--- EDIT after I beat it:
I got a little bit emotional after the last chapter and ending, so in the end I'm left with a positive experience rather than the negative one.
But those bosses are unforgivable. Don't do that BS.

original_text:
A stronger recommendation for me than the first game was, and that mostly comes down to the story.

There are, of course, a lot of similarities between the two titles. You play as a young girl in a town haunted by spirits of the dead and demons and explore around dodging these supernatural threats in search of a missing loved one. The aesthetic is simply gorgeous and the monster design is A+ work. You still die in one hit from things, although the game mercifully puts you in far fewer chase sequences than the first game. It's fair to say that this is a refinement of the previous title rather than a full blown overhaul.

But the story is much more involving. You play as Haru, a young girl looking for her best friend Yui, who has gone missing under mysterious circumstances. There is an episodic approach to the game, like the first, with plenty of side stories before the main plot takes over in the final third. Not only is it even moodier than the first, but the story is actually very engaging, with real emotional stakes thanks to the authentic bond between the two characters. There's also an adorable Pomeranian named Chaco, who it must be said is one of gaming's best bois. 

There are still a few frustrating sections of tedious trial and error, but they are thankfully fewer than in the first game, which become computer throwingly frustrating at times. This one, I think, is going to stick with me for a while. Very recommended.

There's also an adorable Pomeranian named Chaco, who it must be said is one of gaming's best bois.
There are still a few frustrating sections of tedious trial and error, but they are thankfully fewer than in the first game, which become computer throwingly frustrating at times.
This one, I think, is going to stick with me for a while.
Very recommended.

original_text:
I loooove this game. I really liked the first one but I am so glad they tried to improve upon it instead of keeping the same old formula. That's not to say there isn't elements from the first game in the second one (there's a lot), but they were able to expand/improve upon it in creative ways. 
The style of the game is beautiful and there is so much to do. As I'm sure someone already mentioned, it is a bit darker than the previous game so there's a bit of warning there. I will admit the game is pricey for the amount of time it took me to finish the main game (and I took my sweet time) but I got my copy while it was on sale, so I'm pretty happy with it. I strongly recommend it to those who enjoyed the first game, those who like decent atmospheric horror games, or if you're just looking for a good scare and the game is on sale.

The more annoying part is that in many of the places you will die (will, not if) you are forced to go through the cut scene again.

original_text:
As a fan of the first game as well as the horror genre as a whole, I feel like if you enjoy horror games that are heavily influenced by sound design, hand drawn backgrounds and characters, forign culture, tension and compelling settings scenarios and characters, I cannot reccomend this game enough, even at its current 30 dollar price point.

PROS: 
- Extremely strong sound design; perhaps one of the most well done use of sound effects, silence and background noise. The sound design works so well within the games system, as well as adding to the enviornment, it's nothing short of exemplary.
- Well designed character, sprits and environments. Every single character as well as spirits are creatively designed and expertly illustrated, as well as expertly illustrated backgrounds and enviornments, expanding the simple 2d plane of the previous game to create a more dimensional gameplay. 
- Compelling gameplay; The heartbeat system returns from the previous game, as well as the function of revealing spirts via light sources. Each design of the spirts are wonderfull, and will inspire you to look more into their backstory and creation, as well as devising methods to deal with each specfic spirt you encounter.
- Interesting Story. The story, while simple in its premise, is very well paced, and interlaced with elements of exploration and discovery, and leads to a satisfying conclusion.
- Optional world building and item collecting. The option of exploring the game world has been expanded from the previous game: three entire pages of inventory have been dedicated to collectable items that have been scattered around town, each seemingly benign in appearence, but given an subtle eerie description. More optional events have been added, and exploring rewards the player with collectables and room decorations.
- Expanded game area. The base area is roughly twice the size of the first game, providing unique districts and areas, as well as being able to return to the town from the first game in the post-game.

CONS:
-Some systems can be difficult to grasp for first time players. This game subtly decides that you have played the first game, and you dont have a long period to practice controlls
- Some periods can be frustrating if you're having difficulty understand certain enemy or boss mechanics. 
-Certain locations are removed from the last save point, or do not give you the ability to return to the world map from the save points, so backtracking through an area might be a bit boring.

If you're interested in Horror and Japanese culture, this game is for you. I highlly recommend this game for anyone who likes well designed simple games, with a penchant for horror. 9/10

original_text:
Yomawari Midnight Shadows is a good game, but it's definitely a step down from the first game.

The story is still nothing to really write home about, but the main duo of Yui and Haru pull at heart strings more, and definitely have more development in general. It has a lot of gorgeous little scenes that show the team was more confident in designing environments, but the atmosphere is a bit dampened by it feeling a bit more gameplay heavy.

It still boils down to the same gameplay loop of starting a night, doing some specific objective, boss fight, rinse and repeat for a few hours. Your flashlight shows spirits, but some are visible no matter what. What changes a bit with this game is that it has a lot more spirits than the first game, and their lethality is turned up by eleven. Your average gamer will die a lot, and the game seems to compensate for this by giving you a lot more coins to save at the Jizo statues and tons of new items to deal with the various new spirits. Jizo Statues now also actually save instead of being general quicksave spots. Also a new form of "puzzle" is in the game, with you needing to carry or push objects in the environment. It's not really a puzzle though, you just kinda do the actions.

Post game content is relatively the same, but instead of heavily relying on rare events, it now relies heavily on the aforementioned pushing and carrying mechanics. If it doesn't do this, it'll be some multi-chain process to get items. It can be quite obnoxious to get a lot of the collectables. If you're not interested in doing a 100% run, I recommend avoiding the entire post-game. 

It wasn't as much of a problem with the previous game, but navigation can be super obnoxious specifically because of some new indoor areas. You cannot fast travel out of these indoor areas, and they are lethal labyrinths. 

Despite my dislike of some of the new changes, I enjoy this game a lot, so why do I not recommend it?

Because it also has a critical issue where the game just stops working. Nowhere near as bad as the previous game of course because it actually boots, but on both my computer and Steam Deck, it would just randomly close for no reason I could identify. While it did stop doing this eventually, it did it over seven times. Yes you can save a lot, but a game should not have an extra stress of making you need to save constantly so you can avoid losing progress. 

When the game was working on my Steam Deck 512 GB LCD, it ran smoothly just like the previous game with at least three hours thirty minutes of battery life and with no sound or graphical issues. I did not change my version of Proton. 

Same with the previous game, get it on sale if you're PC only and don't be afraid to refund it if it frustrates you or doesn't work. If you can, buy it on another platform as I do think it's worth it.

If you're not interested in doing a 100% run, I recommend avoiding the entire post-game.
It wasn't as much of a problem with the previous game, but navigation can be super obnoxious specifically because of some new indoor areas.
You cannot fast travel out of these indoor areas, and they are lethal labyrinths.
Despite my dislike of some of the new changes, I enjoy this game a lot, so why do I not recommend it?
Because it also has a critical issue where the game just stops working.
Nowhere near as bad as the previous game of course because it actually boots, but on both my computer and Steam Deck, it would just randomly close for no reason I could identify.
While it did stop doing this eventually, it did it over seven times.
Yes you can save a lot, but a game should not have an extra stress of making you need to save constantly so you can avoid losing progress.
When the game was working on my Steam Deck 512 GB LCD, it ran smoothly just like the previous game with at least three hours thirty minutes of battery life and with no sound or graphical issues.
I did not change my version of Proton.
Same with the previous game, get it on sale if you're PC only and don't be afraid to refund it if it frustrates you or doesn't work.
If you can, buy it on another platform as I do think it's worth it.

original_text: The aesthetics are great, but the game itself is tedious. In my opinion, the insta-death mechanic ruined the exploration, which also ruined the game. Considering that there are many divided paths with many traps and lackluster rewards, It would have been better if the game had quick saves, which would have allowed for more easier exploration. In retrospect, I wouldn’t have minded the lackluster rewards or traps in the game if the game didn’t have an insta-death mechanic. The number of times I died trying to find collectible items is ridiculous, and being sent back to the last save every time is tedious. I died so much that I ended up experiencing learned helplessness in one of the boss fights—the sewer boss—because I didn’t want to do anything that could potentially kill me. Overall, the game could have limited the tedium by including quick saves.

Overall, the game could have limited the tedium by including quick saves.

original_text:
Transitions between scripted control and player control aren't always very clear which makes boss fights in particular a bit frustrating at times. 

Unlike Yomawari Night Alone this time I played with a proper controller and I find it's not necessarily a better experience. Controls are better but comfort is worse. Talk to my sore thumb for more details.

The save point system looks to have improved since the first game. This time you resume from last save whether it's jizo statue or home. In the first game you always resume from home so you may lose progress if you've been exploring around a while and haven't gone home to save. I remember I couldn't go back into the house after exiting so that means saving happens after clearing a chapter.

The game is enjoyable although the ending is bittersweet (more bitter than sweet).

original_text:
Later in the game, the saving points get spotty. No matter how close you are to the next saving point, if you fail, you replay the whole thing from the last saving point, often that means a 5 ~ 10 mins repeat for the whole damn part you just played, including boss encounters. Pretty soon the only emotion left for me was frustration and nothing else. Truly a stupid way to prolong players' playing time.

On the other hand though, overall the plot is well planned and story well written. I really felt the sadness of the characters at the end.

original_text:
Yomawari : Night alone was a small die-and-retry horror game that was less about being cute girls encountering spooky things than it was about an innocent grade school girl coming to understand mortality and the cruelty of the world. Effective in its simplicity.

Midnight Shadows is very much what might expect of a sequel - bigger, more elaborate. The town is noticeably larger, you have interior environments, and more variety in both gameplay mechanics and malevolent spirits. Night Alone had, barring a few exceptions, only one strategy against ghosts - manage your stamina to avoid them, often in the nick of time because stamina and speed was carefully calculated to be just barely enough. Midnight Shadows has a greater variety of strategies, or perhaps more accurately rules against the spirits. Don't run, avoid their gaze, turn off the lights, et caetera. You die less because you ran out of steam than because a spirit took you by surprise.

The story, too, is much more present. While Night Alone was somewhat sandbox-y, Midnight shadows has much more direction to it. More dialogue, more jump scares (which tend to be creative so I can't be too mad at them), more cutscenes. You can explore the town and encounter optional events in both, but the main story is heavier in the sequel.

In summary, I think I liked the story of Night Alone better, but Midnight Shadows is every bit a sequel that expands on the premise.

Midnight Shadows is very much what might expect of a sequel - bigger, more elaborate.
The town is noticeably larger, you have interior environments, and more variety in both gameplay mechanics and malevolent spirits.

Midnight Shadows has a greater variety of strategies, or perhaps more accurately rules against the spirits.
Don't run, avoid their gaze, turn off the lights, et caetera.
You die less because you ran out of steam than because a spirit took you by surprise.
The story, too, is much more present.
While Night Alone was somewhat sandbox-y, Midnight shadows has much more direction to it.
More dialogue, more jump scares (which tend to be creative so I can't be too mad at them), more cutscenes.
You can explore the town and encounter optional events in both, but the main story is heavier in the sequel.
In summary, I think I liked the story of Night Alone better, but Midnight Shadows is every bit a sequel that expands on the premise.

original_text:
It's alright when it comes to its style, it handles its sounds mostly well and there's an attempt at an equipment system. However, there are many cheap jumpscares, enemies teleporting on you and very tedious trial & error boss sequences.

The first couple chapters are pretty good, but the game loses its momentum before the halfway point and progressing becomes a slog. Overall, it's just kinda boring.

100% achievement completion boils down to a collectathon after you beat the story, which has you re-explore every corner of the map (or, more likely, following a guide).

original_text:
When this game was announced I was very excited since I played the first title and really enjoyed it. I personally don't like horror games and sometimes I'm way too scared to play one but the cute designs of the characters and the world building helped me get through this game.


Story (Potential Spoilers)
The story this time is tells itself more compared to the first. Within the first game, you sort of piece things together and sort of figured out an interpretation but in Midnight Shadows there is more dialogue which helped you figure out what's going on which the first didn't do. I found that the items you picked up in Midnight Shadows did more warning of things than of telling a little bit of a story of the town. LIke in the first game you learned the fate of the ghost girl but the ghost girl in this game I felt didn't have much clues that lead to her demise unless I missed something. Though the main story is much more fleshed out.

Visual/Audio
The game is again very pretty. Nicely detailed backgrounds that are dingy dark and foreboding at times. The character designs are simplistic and cute while the spirit designs are unsettling. Everytime I encountered a spirit I had chills running through my body. The game only has one song in it but much like the first game it is a great piece. Other than that, the game has ambient noise along with the haunting sounds of spirits at times. Again the sound design is very fitting and effective.

Gameplay
Midnight Shadows plays very much like Night Alone. You can run, you can tip toe, you can control where you point the flashlight, you can hide, and use items. The game adds equipable charms which will give you some sort of a benefit. Another mechanic that was added is the ability to push objects and carry objects both of which disables you ability to use your flash light. So you basically wander around town dodging spirits. One thing I feel like the game lacked was more utilization of the pushing and holding of objects. They could have used that mechanic more. The game was more straight forward. I remember in Night Alone that there are some items you basically had to find in order to get through situations which the game didn't guide you to find. The end game had a very interesting gimmick though. So very much like the first game. It felt good to play and it was pretty easy but that may be because I played the first and in some cases knew what to expect.

Summary
It was a fun experience the story was interesting enough for me to push forward. The gameplay was not too hard but not too easy though I feel like it was easier for me compared to the first. It still has things like the game saving you progress even when you don't save at a save point meaning you retain treasures you picked up when you die. The game is still very pretty and the audio fits to make spine chilling encounters. There are some jump scares too.

I'd recommend the game but I will say that it is a little pricey. Though I think those looking to 100% the game will get some more bang for the buck but unless you are a big fan of the first game I would say wait out for a sale.

original_text:
A fantastic game from my favorite developers. I don't think I can say enough about this game and how much I love it. That feeling of childhood fear and fascination of the dark is captured so well, and the new locations, collectibles, and monsters engaged me better than many AAA horror games with heftier price tags. While I think the first game's story and storytelling are a bit better this game is still amazing for what it brings to the table, and the gameplay improvements and fixes make movement and exploration feel even better. Please play this game!

P.S.: I finally learned how to use the rocks!

That feeling of childhood fear and fascination of the dark is captured so well, and the new locations, collectibles, and monsters engaged me better than many AAA horror games with heftier price tags.

While I think the first game's story and storytelling are a bit better this game is still amazing for what it brings to the table, and the gameplay improvements and fixes make movement and exploration feel even better.
Please play this game!

original_text:
If you never played the first Yomawari or you didn't like its unfairness, the second one is the best place to start. 

It is more polished, with a less tedious gameplay and more dynamic situations. The game is more accessible, without losing anything from the previous one. For example you can save at any checkpoint, not just at the end of each act. There are more locations to explore, a creepy plot and setting and a wide range of disturbing enemy. The game is quiet long compared with the original (~8 hours; 15 to do everything), with a lot secondary things to do. The game is not easy, with lot of difficult situations, but it is more polite in its design.

The problem is if you played the first Yomawari, because in that case you will have lot of deja-vú. Many enemies and also situations are completely recycled from the previous game. However this is just a part, because the majority of the game is original and innovative. Especially the final boss deserve an applause, both in term of design and gameplay.

The game is a beautiful and dark fairytale, with an amazing atmosphere and a nice sense of exploration. The price is a bit exaggerated, maybe wait a bit and buy when is in discount, you will not regret it. 
(Version played: Beta)

Many enemies and also situations are completely recycled from the previous game.
However this is just a part, because the majority of the game is original and innovative.
Especially the final boss deserve an applause, both in term of design and gameplay.
The game is a beautiful and dark fairytale, with an amazing atmosphere and a nice sense of exploration.
The price is a bit exaggerated, maybe wait a bit and buy when is in discount, you will not regret it. (Version played: Beta)

original_text: Well, after 17 hours, I managed to 100% complete the game, and I must say that it was a fun ride. The art style is really cute for a horror game, the plot is interesting enough to make you wonder what will happen next, and the atmosphere really make you feel like one lone kid slowly ventures into the unknown darkness. Still, the game has some frustrating encounters at times, and I'm still salty about that scissor spirit, but maybe I am just bad. I played this game with a guide, so I saw things coming some kilometres away, but some moments still make me jump off my seat. Anyway, a pretty good game, not really difficult to beat, and not really grindy to 100%. If you see this game on sale and want to try it out. I highly recommend it.

original_text:
Yomawari: Midnight Shadows is no doubt an improvement over the original game and while many of the complaints I had about Night Alone remain in the sequel, it does enough for me to recommend it where I didn't recommend the first.

The game starts out slow with a fairly standard tutorial, it takes awhile to get into the game proper but if you play through to the end it really pays off. At the end of the tutorial your character hangs herself setting the mood for the rest of the game. Right after that and you're back to playing her seemingly fine and going out to watch the fireworks with her friend, What happened with that opening? is it the future? Can I stop this? Already the game does a way better job of getting its hooks into you, the story while it lags a bit in the middle is far superior to Night Alone (where it was mostly just a framing device) and this serves to carry the game home when the horror fades.

And yes the horror won't last the whole game, there are some scares to be had don't get me wrong, but like any horror game time will inoculate you to fear, monsters still for the most point boil down to thing to run from and there are still some encounters that rely on cheap deaths (looking at you mansion level) which would help speed up the fear immunisation if it was earlier in the game. On the other hand much improved is one element from the first game I enjoyed, that being the little side stories you could encounter. While in Night Alone these were random with such low chances of happening that you'd probably never see them in a normal playthrough, in Midnight Shadows these are simply hidden away for you to find with clues mentioning folklore and rumours that you can use to uncover these events without being at the mercy of RNG (there is still a terrible RNG event in the game though).

Overall if you like Night Alone you'll adore Midnight Shadows, and if you didn't touch it or disliked it, then maybe this game might bring you around.

original_text:
Do you want fun, non-railroaded missions? A complex story that is mysterious and attention grabbing? A horror game that can be scary past boring "jumpscares"?

Well you came to the wrong place.

Touch anything and you die! Get locked in unskippable cutscenes where the sole scary factor is that it involves ghosts in various ways. The only reason this game is a horror game is from the gore and ghost themes. It is also incredibly hard to play on M&K and I refuse to buy a controller to play a single game. The character moves at a snail's pace and you get baited with a stamina bar that runs out quicker the more scared you are, becoming basically useless as soon as you're in danger.

Finally quit and will not be finishing after dying several times to a 'boss' that would use an attack WHILE I was locked in a cutscene, killing me. The fucking audacity of this game to label itself a horror game.

analysis_results.chunk: Do you want fun, non-railroaded missions?
A complex story that is mysterious and attention grabbing?
A horror game that can be scary past boring "jumpscares"?
Well you came to the wrong place.
Touch anything and you die!
Get locked in unskippable cutscenes where the sole scary factor is that it involves ghosts in various ways.
The only reason this game is a horror game is from the gore and ghost themes.
It is also incredibly hard to play on M&K and I refuse to buy a controller to play a single game.
The character moves at a snail's pace and you get baited with a stamina bar that runs out quicker the more scared you are, becoming basically useless as soon as you're in danger.
Finally quit and will not be finishing after dying several times to a 'boss' that would use an attack WHILE I was locked in a cutscene, killing me.
The fucking audacity of this game to label itself a horror game.

original_text:
As its prequel, this is a simple horror game with awesoem visuals and a tragic story. 

The souls in this game are more diverse than on the first, and the horror atmosphere is constant.

As its prequel, the game keeps its mechanic of distract/run for your life against the souls. However, this game has several more items that can be used in your aid. 
While death is often punishing, many times, as in its prequel, dying becomes an annoyance instead of dread. 

Regardless of that, this is interesting enough to be worth playing.

As its prequel, the game keeps its mechanic of distract/run for your life against the souls.
However, this game has several more items that can be used in your aid.
While death is often punishing, many times, as in its prequel, dying becomes an annoyance instead of dread.
Regardless of that, this is interesting enough to be worth playing.

original_text:
Sequel to Yomawari: Night Alone, and feels a bit more polished.

It's much more narrative driven now, unlike the first game which was almost absent of dialogue.  Running is more forgiving, and the game is more focused on set pieces and boss fights rather than blindsiding you with enemies in the world.  The world itself is a bit less densely packed, but there are now indoor areas to explore and there's less aimless wandering.

If you only choose one of the two, go with this one.  They only have thematic connections so you aren't missing out on anything by skipping to this one.  Around 5 hours of playtime, more if you go for extras.  Grab it on sale.

Running is more forgiving, and the game is more focused on set pieces and boss fights rather than blindsiding you with enemies in the world.
The world itself is a bit less densely packed, but there are now indoor areas to explore and there's less aimless wandering.
If you only choose one of the two, go with this one.
They only have thematic connections so you aren't missing out on anything by skipping to this one.
Around 5 hours of playtime, more if you go for extras.
Grab it on sale.

original_text:
Don't decide to buy this game just because you enjoyed the first game. This game lacks pretty much all of the game mechanics of the Night Alone; you mostly just run in the opposite direction when you see something. The normal gameplay is a lot less tense than in the original. The art style and storytelling is similar to the first game, which are definitely positives.
But that stuff  isn't why I give it a thumbs down. The driving reason behind that is the terrible boss fights in this game. The normal gameplay isn't that interesting, but the boss fights will make you sorely miss it. It's not that they're challenging. If you know what to do they will usually only take a couple of tries. What makes them so bad is that there's really no fun to them at all past the first attempt (because it doesn't really even feel like gameplay, more like an extended cutscene) and you're intentionally punished by the developers for dying in the battles by having your time wasted. I'm not kidding, they intentionally waste your time between attempts in order to make beating it without dying feel more important. That wouldn't be such a big deal if some of the boss battles weren't so finicky/luck based.
But anyway, the strong points of this game being the story and art means that you can just watch a Let's Play of the game and get all the same real value out of it. If you're interested in gameplay, just stick to the first game.

The normal gameplay is a lot less tense than in the original.
The art style and storytelling is similar to the first game, which are definitely positives.
But that stuff isn't why I give it a thumbs down.
The driving reason behind that is the terrible boss fights in this game.
The normal gameplay isn't that interesting, but the boss fights will make you sorely miss it.
It's not that they're challenging.
If you know what to do they will usually only take a couple of tries.

What makes them so bad is that there's really no fun to them at all past the first attempt (because it doesn't really even feel like gameplay, more like an extended cutscene) and you're intentionally punished by the developers for dying in the battles by having your time wasted.
I'm not kidding, they intentionally waste your time between attempts in order to make beating it without dying feel more important.
That wouldn't be such a big deal if some of the boss battles weren't so finicky/luck based.
But anyway, the strong points of this game being the story and art means that you can just watch a Let's Play of the game and get all the same real value out of it.
If you're interested in gameplay, just stick to the first game.

original_text: I really really wanted to like this game. I love rpg horror games and the story and style remind me so much of games like IB and Mad Father. And the story is really good. However, perhaps its better on controller but I've spent more time having to go through the same area multiple times because the arrow key control scheme makes it hard to keep my flashlight trained on monsters or to sometimes even see the threat. A few bosses have unclear hit-boxes and I spent most of my time playing more frustrated than i was scared or fascinated by the mystery. Again I really like the story and style and the characters but at least on the computer the game-play was frustrating enough that I've pretty much given up on it.

Again I really like the story and style and the characters but at least on the computer the game-play was frustrating enough that I've pretty much given up on it.

original_text:
This is as fun as the first Yomawari. 
The only thing i don't like about this one is the check points being placed a bit far from the boss fight.

(spoiler)
Really love how the Narrator from the Tutorial turned out to be the last boss... Truly Evil and explains a lot about the question we got in the tutorial! 

For those who played and still don't understand the game concept due to certain translation error and lost of information after translation...

This is the typical horror story often found in Japanese Novel/Movie/Manga...

The final boss is an Evil Spirit that sweet talk and lure people to their death, then it trap their souls as part of itself. Yui being turned into "one of the" monster (Kotowari) by the boss, resisted and helped Haru to survive. The scissor has the power to cut Bond Ties (Red String in Japanese Legend), and the Kotowari Yui cut Haru's hand off to cut their bonds to save her and let her move on in the true ending. (It's a scene often found in friendship type of Horror stories in Japan).

original_text:
I think that there are very few franchises that have woven themselves so much into heart like Yomawari. Truly, the games are not as groundbraking, rich or horrifying as others. But because Yomawari always has this soothing atmosphere, bizarre charme and disturbing implications, it is still a masterpiece. 

The lonely towns, filled only with the protagonist´s footsteps, the nightly sounds of nature and the echoes of bygone spirits have this melancholic air around them. It is almost nostalgic in nature, similar to that of Cry of Fear. It´s almost relaxing to walk around in them, despite the imminent danger.

The stories are mostly comprised of quiet, minimalist dialogue that heavily relies on visual and metaphysical aid and leaves some room for interpretation. Yet they never feel preachy of pretensious. They have a purpose.

The monsters of the series are fascinating. Most often, they are mixture of uncanny, compared to the rest of the adorable artstyle, kind of endearing and a well-developed vision of classic Japanese myths and legends. As such, the players, specifically those acquainted with these myths, are intrigued and horrified by the beings all the same.

I don`t know if this essay throughly explains my fascination for the games, but I hope that you enjoyed regarding it, dear reader. Perhaps it even peaked your interest. Either way, I will adore this franchise to the high heavens.

analysis_results.chunk: I think that there are very few franchises that have woven themselves so much into heart like Yomawari.
Truly, the games are not as groundbraking, rich or horrifying as others.
But because Yomawari always has this soothing atmosphere, bizarre charme and disturbing implications, it is still a masterpiece.
The lonely towns, filled only with the protagonist´s footsteps, the nightly sounds of nature and the echoes of bygone spirits have this melancholic air around them.
It is almost nostalgic in nature, similar to that of Cry of Fear.
It´s almost relaxing to walk around in them, despite the imminent danger.
The stories are mostly comprised of quiet, minimalist dialogue that heavily relies on visual and metaphysical aid and leaves some room for interpretation.
Yet they never feel preachy of pretensious.
They have a purpose.
The monsters of the series are fascinating.
Most often, they are mixture of uncanny, compared to the rest of the adorable artstyle, kind of endearing and a well-developed vision of classic Japanese myths and legends.
As such, the players, specifically those acquainted with these myths, are intrigued and horrified by the beings all the same.
I don`t know if this essay throughly explains my fascination for the games, but I hope that you enjoyed regarding it, dear reader.
Perhaps it even peaked your interest.
Either way, I will adore this franchise to the high heavens.

original_text:
I think this is an underrated series and I wholeheartedly recommend this to anyone that likes short survival horror games.

A direct sequel to Night Alone, while there isn't much dialogue, there is a deeper story behind all of the jumpscares, pebble throwing, and chibis running around in the dark that I fell down that rabbit hole of trying to piece everything together. That made me love this series much more (to the point that I want to read the JP novel now).

Gameplay can be repetitive and the save points can be very few (which sucks when you have to run back after a death), but it is just a minor frustration.

11/10 gimme more sequels and more doog :'(

original_text:
I think this was a big step down in a LOT of ways from the first game, but at the same time, i think it's a pretty enjoyable game in it's own right. 

The reason i loved the first game was because it left you alone to explore, and because it made you scared without using jumpscares. I think those are what made the first game good, but this game did away with both of them. You are constantly being guided and escorted through the world, and it's hard to go 5 minutes without some cheap jumpscare being thrown at you. Adding more guidance is forgivable since I do believe that is a big flaw with the original, and you are still free to explore once you're done, but I just don't think this game handles guidance well. I'd rather have the sense of loneliness add to the fear factor over constantly being told where to go when i've already figured it out, and many parts are still just as confusing and unclear as in the original. It's really struggling to find a good middle ground here. And as for the jumpscares, well i think a png creepypasta style face popping up on screen speaks for itself. Feels more like mid 2000s youtube than a horror game i paid for.
I also managed to clip out of bounds a few times breaking everything; I thought the boss fights were even more confusing and even more reliant on trial and error than before; I thought some parts were very lazy copy pastes from the first game; and I think some things are without a doubt not being discovered unless you're following a guide.

All that being said, I still loved this. I thought the world was interesting, the characters were interesting and loveable, the puzzles were enjoyable, the aesthetics are charming, the story was easy to get invested in, the post game was fantastic, and despite my complaints i had a really good time overall. I think it's full of problems, but i still found myself having fun. I think if i wasn't comparing it to the first game, i would have very few complaints. I think it's only fair to judge this game on it's own, at which point i've gotta say, it was pretty damn good! With the exception of the jumpscares that is, lol.

The reason i loved the first game was because it left you alone to explore, and because it made you scared without using jumpscares.
I think those are what made the first game good, but this game did away with both of them.
You are constantly being guided and escorted through the world, and it's hard to go 5 minutes without some cheap jumpscare being thrown at you.
Adding more guidance is forgivable since I do believe that is a big flaw with the original, and you are still free to explore once you're done, but I just don't think this game handles guidance well.

I'd rather have the sense of loneliness add to the fear factor over constantly being told where to go when i've already figured it out, and many parts are still just as confusing and unclear as in the original.
It's really struggling to find a good middle ground here.
And as for the jumpscares, well i think a png creepypasta style face popping up on screen speaks for itself.
Feels more like mid 2000s youtube than a horror game i paid for.

I also managed to clip out of bounds a few times breaking everything; I thought the boss fights were even more confusing and even more reliant on trial and error than before; I thought some parts were very lazy copy pastes from the first game; and I think some things are without a doubt not being discovered unless you're following a guide.
All that being said, I still loved this.

I thought the world was interesting, the characters were interesting and loveable, the puzzles were enjoyable, the aesthetics are charming, the story was easy to get invested in, the post game was fantastic, and despite my complaints i had a really good time overall.

original_text: I really enjoyed the game.  The gameplay itself maybe not so much, but it has a lot of value for the first run when you don't know what's coming.  As such, it's advisable to be very careful when looking at guides and stuff.  I would criticize the gameplay in that sometimes when you have to walk a long distance, especially over and over, it gets tedious because even running, your character is slow.  I would praise the use of strategy with different ghost behaviors to avoid death, and the fact that you're killed in one hit can make the game very tense and make you feel like you're actually a defenseless kid, but at the same time it does cause frustration sometimes.  Fortunately, the game is pretty good about giving you save points right before places you'll likely die.  The best thing about this game would definitely be the atmosphere.  The art is beautiful, and gives a very nostalgic, countryside/old-fashioned Japanese neighborhood feel.  Despite all the ghosts I found myself wanting to visit this place.  Overall, it's only medium difficulty and pretty accessible/intuitive with controls, and though it may not be really horrifying, the jumpscares are unsettling without being cheap.  It's commendable how little the game tries to interfere with your experience, like it isn't trying to shove in your face that you're about to be scared, it just lets you get scared on your own and scares you with environmental storytelling and excellent sound work.  Altogether it's more of a playable horror movie than a game, but I'd still recommend it for a decent, short horror experience, which should be especially effective for those who grew up in fear of Asian ghost mythos like myself.

It also makes pretty unexpected moves and success at shocking you at key points of the story. Side stories told in the game are also not bad at all. Spirits we see trough the whole game are much better looking than the previous game and as good looking as the previous one as well. It was worth the price and I left the game satisfied.

original_text:
[b]Highly Recommended That You Wait For This Game To Go On Sale[/b]

TL;DR - This is a short puzzle game (even with a bit of exploration on my end it only took a little over 6 hours to complete), and the strategy tag is a mislabel. Still a fun play, but not for $20.

========

Coming on the heels of Firely Diaries, and considering it was a handheld game, I didn't expect a long trip. The overall atmosphere is self-explanatory - a quiet town in the dead of night. No music to intensify or interfere with the experience. Just silence and ambient noises.

Since the game is played top down, it's less of a horror game (cute tag is of notable detriment) and far more of a puzzle adventure. The strategy tag really has no place up top, considering it's pretty basic what you can do: hide, run, and die. There [i]is[/i] a tiptoe option for movement, but I never found a use for it. Almost all the enemies are triggered by proximity, and distracting them with objects tended to only work on a few of the basic ones. Knowing when and how to hustle is your best (and later on only) friend.

The difficulty is fairly casual, in that items you pick up are still in your log/inventory even after death. While this means some puzzles can be entirely negated by suicide running them, the intent was to soften the blow when confronted with the larger stretches of the game where save points are infrequent or don't exist. This is worthwhile in several scenarios beginning around the third chapter.

original_text:
I really enjoyed this, BUT

There is an extreme over-emphasis on chases in this game, and it is balanced in favour of killing you. Because your stamina drains faster the nearer you are to a spirit, the closer a spirit gets, the harder it becomes to escape. This means that if you are not both ridiculously strategic and lucky with your movements, you will get killed over, and over, and over, and over.

It is also split-second punishing, and unfairly punishing. For example, in one chase section, I couldn't nail it - until I watched a walkthrough and saw the player run south instead of north. It made no difference in distance on the map, but in the game was the difference between dying repeatedly or completing that section.

Despite this, it really is quite magical. I found the story engrossing, and when I read about the shinto aspects of the different competing spirits / gods, it was really rewarding as in-game, the players actions have a metaphysical relevance. In one section, you have to fulfil a favour to one spirit in exchange for being allowed to live, so they can maintain their own little fiefdom. In the final section, lighting the shrines on the mountain path felt incredibly profound and mystical.

Nonetheless, by the end of the level I was on the point of begging for the chase mechanics to stop. Enough chasing!!!! Use all the tips and tricks you can to get through the frustration, and Yomawari is a treat.

This means that if you are not both ridiculously strategic and lucky with your movements, you will get killed over, and over, and over, and over.

For example, in one chase section, I couldn't nail it - until I watched a walkthrough and saw the player run south instead of north.
It made no difference in distance on the map, but in the game was the difference between dying repeatedly or completing that section.
Despite this, it really is quite magical.

I found the story engrossing, and when I read about the shinto aspects of the different competing spirits / gods, it was really rewarding as in-game, the players actions have a metaphysical relevance.
In one section, you have to fulfil a favour to one spirit in exchange for being allowed to live, so they can maintain their own little fiefdom.
In the final section, lighting the shrines on the mountain path felt incredibly profound and mystical.
Nonetheless, by the end of the level I was on the point of begging for the chase mechanics to stop.
Enough chasing!!!!
Use all the tips and tricks you can to get through the frustration, and Yomawari is a treat.

original_text:
I'll give my short but honest review of this game. Overall its a decent game, the art, the soundtrack, the atmosphere, the scares, the gameplay but the only downside is that its too short and the $20.00 price tag seems to much for a 4-5 hr game. Due to this, I recommend purchasing it if its on Sale. 

But even though its short, I enjoyed every minute and every second of it. I hope they make or publish more games like this.

Just some Tips: 
1. Play this game with a headphone on and with the lights of for full immersion.
2. Don't be afraid to spend coins on save points, coins are very abundant. 
3. And if you really want to enjoy the game, don't read walkthroughs or watch videos until you finish this game.

original_text:
This is the second game I have bought from this developer and after playing this game I expect I'll be buying from their games again and again. This game was what I hoped for and more, I expected a decent atmospheric horror game with cutesy art and I got an excellent horror game with an eerie but charming atmosphere, fantastic art that ixed cutesy with scary perfectly, great music, enjoyable and challenging gameplay, and an intriguing story. There were multiple times that I felt very moved while I was playing the game, these scenes where you get the chance to learn more about your main character and her world are rewarding. Honestly, half the fun was seeing what comments she would make about items as well as seeing the map.
     At first I felt the game was too difficult and died many times, but the game is very fair and balances out the difficulty of some encounters with a decent save mechanic. After playing through the game and looking for most of the collectibles my only complaint is that I still don't know if I'm using the rocks correctly!
      This game is worth your time and money, and so are their other games. I highly reccomend this title!

original_text:
So I wanted to enjoy this game, as it provides a really cute and yet horrific environment. I found as I played though, that there are some major frustrations holding this game back from being great.

The quicksave system isn't really a save system, if you leave the game your progress will be lost. You can only truly save by entering your house, which you cannot do whenever you want. Playing this game with limited time doesn't really enable me to pick this game up and put it back down again.

The controls are a bit clunky, but not intolerable, however combined with this strange question mark/exclamation point notification system, I find myself wondering what I am trying to interact with half of the time.

There are too many enemies, scattered all throughout the level. A heartbeat sound warns you when they are close, but it is going off pretty much through the entirety of your trip. This makes it both kind of annoying, but also really frustrating when you are trying to ignore it and a monster runs out to kill you. 

Also the foreground, very often gets in the way of the view spectrum. This can be quite tedious to deal with, I don't mind the loss of control too much, but it makes dealing with exploration a pain because of its frequence. Pair this with a lack of direction from the game, and you have a mediocre experience. 

I can neither say you should play this game, or should not. I feel like most of the issues plaguing this game could be addressed with some QOL fixes, and then this would be something truly special.

You can only truly save by entering your house, which you cannot do whenever you want.
Playing this game with limited time doesn't really enable me to pick this game up and put it back down again.

The controls are a bit clunky, but not intolerable, however combined with this strange question mark/exclamation point notification system, I find myself wondering what I am trying to interact with half of the time.
There are too many enemies, scattered all throughout the level.
A heartbeat sound warns you when they are close, but it is going off pretty much through the entirety of your trip.
This makes it both kind of annoying, but also really frustrating when you are trying to ignore it and a monster runs out to kill you.
Also the foreground, very often gets in the way of the view spectrum.
This can be quite tedious to deal with, I don't mind the loss of control too much, but it makes dealing with exploration a pain because of its frequence.
Pair this with a lack of direction from the game, and you have a mediocre experience.
I can neither say you should play this game, or should not.
I feel like most of the issues plaguing this game could be addressed with some QOL fixes, and then this would be something truly special.

original_text:
[h1]Horror has never been this Kawaii[/h1]
[i]This is an early review from me. I'll edit this when I have more time to play this and the inevitable game updates. Start playing this at 0200am and I have class at 0800am. GG.[/i]

Possible spoilers. Though I don't think I spoil anything, but you know, just in case...

I wanted to play this game so bad ever since it came out on Vita last year in Japan but there's no way I'm cashing out a few bucks for PSVita just to play this game. To my suprise it gets a Steam release. I got so excited that I pre-ordered it.

Does it meet my expectation? For now it exceeds way more than my expectation.

[h1]Don't judge a book by it's cover[/h1]
Despite the cute art, the gameplay can be hard and brutal. Heck,[spoiler]this game f@$k you up when you just in the tutorial.[/spoiler] In general, you play as a little girl who tries to find her older sister. You have to dodge,hide or find a way to get past the ghosts lurking in your neighbourhood while finding her. What I really love about this game is that most of the time it force you to figure things out  on your own. You'll collect tools along the way and it's up to you to figure out what it does.

[h1]Details at it's best [/h1]
The background art is filled with all those little details you might miss in your first glance. It looks like it was painstakingly hand-drawn each. But what really sold me is the sound. Each different surface you step on has different sound. You also have to pay attention to sound when you play this game. Your heart beats louder indicates a ghost is getting closer. In this game you can set what language you want to play in. English or Japanese. Choosing one of them will change the language not only to dialogue, but the street signs, notice board, and almost all the in-game enviroment all changed into the language you choose.

[h1]Controls [/h1]
Playing with gamepad is highly recommended. I mean no suprise,right? Since it's a console port. You can play with keyboard and mouse but it might be hard to get used to for some players. Credits to the devs still as they had make playing with keyboard and mouse not as awkward as some other port I know. For me it works just fine.

[h1]Technical [/h1]
Though it wasn't a problem for me and I don't know if anyone find this as nuisance but just for a heads up, my RX480 can't reach a solid 60fps. Which for me is weird for a game like this. It ranges from 56-50fps. Do tell me how the game performs on your rig.

original_text:
If you watch any screenshot of Yomawari without knowing nothing about it, probably you could think that is the perfect game for your little sister. And you couldn't be more wrong, because behind the cute characters and the bright pastel colors, the heart of a real horror game beats.

In Yomawari the history is simple and totally an accessory. A girl is searching her dog, later will search her sister. Done. 
The gameplay as well is very simple. You can just run and hide from monsters, with a stamina bar that depletes very fast. Even with these simple mechanics, the game is though and hardcore.

But Yomawari has also one of the most interesting, inspired and wide selection of enemies, and an incredible sense of exploration.

Surely a brilliant and original horror game in a 2017 full of clones and uninspired games.

Complete review: https://surrealandcreepy.wordpress.com/

Complete review: https://surrealandcreepy.wordpress.com/

original_text:
There is a 50/50 chance of the game not working, or not even reaching the menu. Depending on how new your computer is and updated, there's even less of a chance. This game is more of a trap than anything, there are no updates for issues fixes and seems to have been abandoned. I myself have tried to change settings, windows, etc, and have done everything recommended and possible. The beta might work for some, but hasn't for me. According to several others, even when the game works there are still many issues that prevent the player from actually playing. 

I love playing games of this variety, but I just can't with this one with all the issues presented. If the problem ever gets solved I will fix my review. Till then I can't recommend this game to anyone who is interested and highly discourage it, even when on sale. Until then I must hope there are enough reviews about the problem that something is finally done. Even if you doubt you will have this issue, I don't recommend finding out. Especially since I cannot get a refund after wasting my life trying to solve it's issues. This game isn't worth the effort, even if it just costed a quarter.

UPDATE: I somehow managed to get to the loading screen and barely past it. Using windows 95 on administrator, while using steam beta. It helps if you remove the steam overlay as well. I have been constantly messed with the game since purchase, to forcefully make it to work. But, I cannot get it open from steam itself, plus you have to mess with the settings in a very specific way to even have it open past the loading screen on folder. Even if your using the same settings as what might be recommended, is not enough to make it open.

The game still instantly crashes 90 percent of the time before getting to the loading screen. I somehow managed to play around a few seconds before crashing once again. IF I can make it function and play a decent amount I will edit things once again.

original_text:
If I could leave a neutral review, it would definetly be useful for this game's rating. But I've had more frustrating moments than fun, that left a bad taste in my mouth. I like this game and I want to like it even more, but I simply cannot. 

One of the most enjoyable things was definetly artstyle! The details on little trees, sidewalks and diffrent ideas for each spirit caught my eye. Background objects and houses with spirits that interacted with them was such an amazing thing to experience first hand. The shopping district and the forest were my favourites, when it came to visuals! As an explorer myself - finding items in the most obscure, hidden places was also a lot of fun. I like how we're rewarded whenever we collect an item and it shows our collection process, magnificent! Flavour texts from notes is thoughtful addition too! Heartbeat mechanic was also intetresting on paper and it really enchanced the horror experience the first few times you encounter the spirits!
The cutscenes were also very well made, but it I wish they wouldn't play out every time we died.

Unfortunately this is where the positives end. The clipping textures and chopped pieces of the objects on the map while exploring. A minor thing, but definetly an ick for some. Additionally the chase sequences specially further in the game can be pretty challenging for the average person. The enemies have a big upper hand on you. Teleport near protagonist, dash when you're out of breath - sometimes it was so frustrating I wanted to quit the game and leave it here! So many sequences that just build up more and more negative feelings rather than encourge the player to learn something from their death. But what it is to learn, if you're just powerless! As I mentioned earlier the heartbeat mechanic was fun, but in my opinion - executed poorly. It feels like you need to be lucky to pass some sections without the major punishment of reseting from the same statule multiple times.

Overall this game is best to buy on sales and play, if you'd like a bit of thrill. I don't think it's worth a full price considering the negatives listed above, but it's still worth buying!

- NOBODY will ever fix it, so do yourself a favor and don't buy it.

original_text:
Recommended if you can get it !!!ON SALE ONLY!!!
I had a good time with this, but keep in mind I got it for $2.99
Good atmosphere, great enemy design, and some genuinely tense situations...but you can finish it in ~4 hours, there's plenty of jank in the controls & certain things can be really obtuse. It's nowhere near perfect, but fills that "in-between" slot when you're playing some other longer games. A bite-sized horror game for the Fall season. Give it a try on sale!

original_text:
Can't recommend this one to people who have problems with frustration in video games. This game sometimes will feature some really awful design decisions with cheap deaths, unreliable controls and hitboxes. 

Still, visually charming as hell and the town can mimick both the feeling of fear and curiosity while exploring present in the best Silent Hill games.
The monster design is pretty unique and I enjoyed the story quite a lot. 

Yomawari: Night Alone is no masterpiece, but what it does great is indeed great.

original_text:
This is a very fun and cute "horror" game. It's sold as horror, though I found the most horrific thing about it to be the breath mechanic when running away.   

Basically, the closer you are to a monster, the more you panic, thus your little girl lungs cant hold much air thanks to hyperventalating. Overall, it makes sense, BUT making sense does not excuse poor design. This mechanic will be the bane of your existance on every, single, one of the boss "fights". if they had just disabled it on those i'd be fine with it....

Other than a few really cheap kills ( a couple unavoidable) i'd say they have the monster design down well, and is pretty fair.

Little girls and horror are my favourite things when mixed together, and this game has a terrifically cutsey, yet gorey feel that I adore~ If you're looking for a pretty nice story with elements of horror, i'd say give it a go. And there's a lot of optional side tasks for you to find and complete, like chasing down headless chickens or playing tag with a horribly disfigured ghost child. 

And as a last bit of advice, play with a controller, or rebind the keyboard controls. the defaults are unintuitive at best, though i can excuse it due to the game being a port of a psp game.

Overall 8/10

original_text: The introduction had me intrigued but the experience afterwards just made me more and more frustrated as it went on. The stamina system doesn't mesh well with the one-hit kill, trial and error nature of the game. It's not as much of a problem in the beginning, but once you start to come across enemies that are faster than your character it just stops being fun.

The stamina system doesn't mesh well with the one-hit kill, trial and error nature of the game.
It's not as much of a problem in the beginning, but once you start to come across enemies that are faster than your character it just stops being fun.

original_text:
Wander around a giant empty map filled with recycled assets and absurdly diverse enemies with unexplained behaviour patterns, doing relatively generic horror game chores until you run out of things to do; and are expected to just keep wandering until you find the arbitrary thing meant to progress.


The main map that players spend most of their time in is a large, empty series of streets made of perpetually recycled assets. There's nothing interesting to look at, it's all just typical small town architecture with a lot of empty space and pointless diverging paths. The game is just you wandering around said sandbox doing chores.

The game features a ridiculous amount of different enemies. They are sprinkled around the map with absolutely zero logic or consistency, and each of them behaves in completely different ways yet players are expected to figure it out themselves for each individual enemy. Do they have an actual line of sight, are they faster then the player, are they distracted by throwable objects, are they invisible when the player is not looking directly at them, does hiding even make any difference at all, does slow walking even make any difference at all. Figure it out yourself for every single of the dozen plus creatures, die over and over, most of the unique mechanics are pointless as most of the enemies do not seem to be effected by them. Why do the unique mechanics even exist then if most of the enemies are not coded to react of them. Instead you might as well just run away from them as that's the only consistent way to avoid them, the most boring and typical way.

Some enemies are invisible unless you are looking at them and directly shining your light on them, so sometimes you will just die because something invisible jumped you. Other times you will die because the enemy is obscured by something in the foreground and you cannot see it. There is a feature where your heart beats when something is close, but there are so many enemies spastically placed all over the map that your heart is beating half the time. So it's mostly just an auditory annoyance.


The basis of the gameplay itself is just generic horror game chores, go here and pick up this to unlock this to get this to do this. Which would not be so bad if the game wasn't set in a massive bland empty map where the only interesting thing to do is these chores. There's no nuance to the map design, it's just empty streets. Just like there is no nuance to the enemy design, they are just placed all over the map in random spots and have random behaviours which are mainly just countered by running away.

Then there is the dog enemy which sometimes jumps out of the bushes in one of two places, and instantly kills you unless you immediately run into a nearby bush with less then half a second of time to spare. So it just kills you over and over until you learn the meta of getting as close to its trigger as possible, triggering it, then immediately dashing into the nearby bush.

Another unique mechanic is where the game hints to you whenever an interactable object is nearby. Most of the time it triggers on hiding spots, which are obvious and so telling the player about them is pointless. Other times it triggers on important things. But the range at which it activates is so broad, you can never tell what exactly it's hinting to so you just have to run around looking for what triggered it. Could be an obvious hiding spot, could be something you need to progress the game. All it really does is totally confuse the player as the trigger radius is so massive it might as well not exist at all.

The game is not scary, at all. There is zero atmosphere, or ambience. And there is no suspense since the player is constantly surrounded by generic enemies with the annoying heart beat sound going off. While the enemies are not intimidating either since the map is so oversaturated with them. There are hardly even any unique events in the game, most of the time you just wander around running away from enemies that just follow you.


It has nice art, and that is about it. The story is generic and typical, the map is empty and boring, the enemies are asinine and tedious; while all the unique mechanics are either unused or just make the game more annoying. It's not even remotely scary as a horror game, and it's not even remotely fun as an adventure game.

original_text:
It's a cute horror game, that is based on all kind of japanese myths and urban legends. It begins great with the main story being engaging since the very beginning and doesn't disappoint you throughout the whole game, and if you want some more of it there are lots of tiny details, clues and hints surrounding the town if you want to learn more about it. 

It's not a scary game by any means, but has it's own unique/creative moments, considering it features a huge variety of ghosts/creatures, so you often don't know what to expect, which made a big impression on me. Usually in other games, you see same type of monsters all over again, and you get used to their behavior and appearance, but in Yomawari you have spirits that you see only once, or they have a rare spawn chance and encountering them adds a lot to the atmosphere. Each one of them has it's own symbolism and story behind their hauntings. That's where the exploration shines in this game, it's fun and rewarding. Art style is very pleasing to the eye, sometimes it's very detailed, and sometimes a bit lazy, mushy.. I'm not sure what was the budget and the scope of the project, but the main character and all the things that she does is done purposely in a very cute way, while the horror aspect of the game I think it borrows some inspiration from Yume Nikki and popular creepypastas. 

Now the bad things, first of.. the save system is confusing and cryptic. There is an actual guide online that explains to people how to actually save your game, it's something that game doesn't explain properly and you may lose a lot of your progress if you don't get the idea behind how it works. It's vague and badly designed. Quite often you will end up in situations where massive objects will block your view, such as houses or trees and you have no idea where you are going, to make it worse, devs put enemies or hidden objects in such areas, as if they tried to annoy the players by exploring their own badly designed choices. Why not make these things transparent once they block your view? Nope, let's just make it more irritating. The game encourages you to hide into bushes from enemies that you can't outrun, but even if you use them and wait for more than a good minute, they won't go away, they will just wait till you come out and insta kill you, which makes it useless. Also some achievements are nonsensical or require you to trigger random rare events, which will require you to restart and revisit same places dozens of times. When you spot a spirit, or the game tells you that a threat is nearby, you'll hear heart beats, the first time I heard them they quickly felt so annoying.. I thought I will get a headache soon if I continue playing, but eventually I got used to it. But I feel like there could've been an alternative way on executing this mechanic differently..

It's an interesting and a good game overall, but suffers from a bad game design, and some technical problems, considering it's a rough PS Vita port. I feel like it's not really worth it's full price on the handheld, but it's a nice treat during the steam sale.

It begins great with the main story being engaging since the very beginning and doesn't disappoint you throughout the whole game, and if you want some more of it there are lots of tiny details, clues and hints surrounding the town if you want to learn more about it.

It's not a scary game by any means, but has it's own unique/creative moments, considering it features a huge variety of ghosts/creatures, so you often don't know what to expect, which made a big impression on me.

Usually in other games, you see same type of monsters all over again, and you get used to their behavior and appearance, but in Yomawari you have spirits that you see only once, or they have a rare spawn chance and encountering them adds a lot to the atmosphere.
Each one of them has it's own symbolism and story behind their hauntings.
That's where the exploration shines in this game, it's fun and rewarding.
Art style is very pleasing to the eye, sometimes it's very detailed, and sometimes a bit lazy, mushy..

I'm not sure what was the budget and the scope of the project, but the main character and all the things that she does is done purposely in a very cute way, while the horror aspect of the game I think it borrows some inspiration from Yume Nikki and popular creepypastas.
Now the bad things, first of.. the save system is confusing and cryptic.

There is an actual guide online that explains to people how to actually save your game, it's something that game doesn't explain properly and you may lose a lot of your progress if you don't get the idea behind how it works.
It's vague and badly designed.

Quite often you will end up in situations where massive objects will block your view, such as houses or trees and you have no idea where you are going, to make it worse, devs put enemies or hidden objects in such areas, as if they tried to annoy the players by exploring their own badly designed choices.
Why not make these things transparent once they block your view?
Nope, let's just make it more irritating.

The game encourages you to hide into bushes from enemies that you can't outrun, but even if you use them and wait for more than a good minute, they won't go away, they will just wait till you come out and insta kill you, which makes it useless.
Also some achievements are nonsensical or require you to trigger random rare events, which will require you to restart and revisit same places dozens of times.
When you spot a spirit, or the game tells you that a threat is nearby, you'll hear heart beats, the first time I heard them they quickly felt so annoying..
I thought I will get a headache soon if I continue playing, but eventually I got used to it.
But I feel like there could've been an alternative way on executing this mechanic differently..
It's an interesting and a good game overall, but suffers from a bad game design, and some technical problems, considering it's a rough PS Vita port.
I feel like it's not really worth it's full price on the handheld, but it's a nice treat during the steam sale.

original_text: This horror game sounds like it would be short but it's quite frankly pretty long. I'll just do a quick summary of its elements. The game has a great sense of exploration. You can collect a lot of items and some of those appear in your room, so there is an incentive to collect stuff. Each item has a description which might hint at the game's lore like in Dark Souls. You have to dodge different specials all over the map and they play by different rules. This means that you have to figure out how each enemy behaves and adapt to the environment. The general art follows a hand drawn style which looks great. There's nice attention to detail in some visual queues like with street lamps and the sound design is nice. This game actually freaked me out a fair bit so as a horror game it does a good job. I didn't expect to spend as many hours as I did playing the game and the story itself was interesting too. I feel like the game also tries to offer varied levels so you never feel like you're experiencing the same thing. All in all this game was a good experience and I would recommend it to others if you want a fun horror game experience. If you get it on sale, this game is more than worth it in my opinion.
