original_text:
Potential neutral review which turned extremely negative. 

At the first glance the game looked like I'll love it. Pretty graphics, intriguing start of the story and a grim world which you'd like to discover. At the first glance...

Then gameplay happened. And it's awful. We have to go somewhere, and the same moment try to avoid enemies whom we can see only in the flashlight. Some spirits fast and specially for that we have a sprint bar. Which continues in danger situations for a second only. Just one second, Carl. I retried some moments dozens of time. Gameplay here extremely annoying and repulsive. 

I continued to play because of the atmosphere and my curiosity about the story. Here I wasn't rewarded too. They didn't explain anything even after the final. What did happen with the town? Why it happened? A lot of questions without answers.

Anyway, after the end of the story developers let us free walk through the town. And now appeared some collectibles for achievement, which weren't here while I had played before credits. Cute, right? So, I am a trophy hunter and I like achievements. It's 40% of formula "why I buy games". But here they are disgusting. I'd call them like a time-wasting trophies. Seriously, they were made specially for taking your time as much as it could be. For example, while I am writing this lines, I am earning a trophy called "Long night". I have to play the game 50hrs. So Yomavari just working in the background. Yeah, I finished this game in ten hours with other achievements and a guide how to reach 'em. If you think that was the worst kind of trophies, you're wrong. The game has some with a small random chance of getting it. Even if you fulfill all the conditions it does not mean you can take it. Proximately 5-10-% of success. And if not, so go home and try again. To take a "monster cat" took me about 30 attempts (1,5 hour). Checked my PC resources for a case of mining after all.

Big expectations about this game were pointless. Silent Hill, they said. Deep grim atmosphere and story, they said. *Sigh

P.s. All my short reviews you can find [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/kiko_kitsune/recommended/] here [/url]

original_text:
Nippon Ichi's second Vita-released horror game after the disastrous htoL#NiQ: The Firefly Diary, Yomawari was directed by Yu Mizokami, who worked on graphics and level design for The Firefly Diary, but is a very different, and better, thing altogether, and was inspired by her late-night commute to the Nippon Ichi offices. There's not much in the way of mechanics, but it does a lot with what it has, especially the flashlight, which has a limited range of movement and is your only real defense, aside from hiding, against the spirits and spectres in this charmingly-presented Japanese countryside town. With fantastic sound design (your heartbeat is used to alert you to spirits getting closer) and superb presentation throughout, it's a tense experience that does not outstay its welcome (around 4 hours) and made a serious impression on me. 

There are a few areas to criticise- some enemies, especially in the final stretch, can be a bit flaky when it comes to hit detection and can get stuck on walls to make things even harder, there's a few monsters that are much, much faster and appear with little time to react to appropriately, and it is a little jumpscare-heavy, but overall, this is a solid game, one to play in the evenings over the course of a week, with earphones on and the lights out.

A more in-depth review available here
http://gaminghell.co.uk/YomawariWarning.html

original_text: I was having fun with this one and genuinely wanted to leave it a positive, but the near-constant crashing just saps any will to keep playing right out of you. Seems this has been an ongoing issue for a long time as there are several players complaining about it in the reviews and nothing has been done to patch the problem. The only way to preserve your progress is to teleport back to your in-game home, which takes you off the path you're on and means re-tracing the route all over again. If you're on an especially difficult run to a particular location, that's just a killer.

original_text:
I haven't played much of this game [strike]mainly because I'm a wuss.[/strike] But the parts of it I have played I really enjoyed. And I still intend to [strike]muster up the courage[/strike] find the time to play this game all the way through eventually.

Yomawari: Night Alone has you play as a little girl who has set out in the dead of night to find her missing sister who never game back one night. Don't let the cutsey imagery fool you, this game's story hits you really hard right at the beginning. It's a very good combination of cute, and creepy that gives me at least that same kind of creeping fear that I used to get when climbing a dark staircase at night as a child. 

The artwork is also worth mentioning. It's like if Hayao Miyazaki had a nightmare in the middle of writing Spirited Away and decided to make a game in his spare time based off of it. Very cutsey. Very Japanese. And the monsters look very youkai inspired. But some of them you can tell could have just been everyday objects if you weren't a child lost in a town in the middle of the night. It's cool, intriguing, spooky, and cutsey all at the same time.

Give this game a shot if you haven't yet. It's a fun, original adventure that's a breath of fresh air from all the usual popular genres of games these days. If you catch it on sale sometime, it's definitely worth it.

original_text:
[h1] An eerie search begins... [/h1]

Yomawari: Night Alone is a short indie-horror game. You'll play as a little girl, who is exploring her neighbourhood haunted by strange spirits and monsters in search of her sister. 

First off: This game is more of a stealth/survival than a horror game, with most of the death being jumpscares and death being no uncommon thing. This being said - the atmosphere is very well made, the games hand drawn textures and background noises underline the eerieness and the feeling of loneliness extremely well.

The story thus far seems good to me, and I really enjoy exploring the neighbourhood with all of it's unique ghosts and locations! I also really like that there are archievements for this game - rewarding me for exploration and progression!

I heard this game doesn't take very long to be beaten though and as I understood it seems to have only little replay value - so I would wait for a sale to grab it! I wish y'all who are playing good luck on your walk through the darkness!

This being said - the atmosphere is very well made, the games hand drawn textures and background noises underline the eerieness and the feeling of loneliness extremely well.
The story thus far seems good to me, and I really enjoy exploring the neighbourhood with all of it's unique ghosts and locations!
I also really like that there are archievements for this game - rewarding me for exploration and progression!
I heard this game doesn't take very long to be beaten though and as I understood it seems to have only little replay value - so I would wait for a sale to grab it!
I wish y'all who are playing good luck on your walk through the darkness!

original_text:
[h1]★★★✰✰[/h1]

Yomawari: Night Alone is a decent horror game, but not without serious flaws. It's held back by technical issues, somewhat clunky controls, unfair enemies, and lack of character development. 

For many players the game crashes at start up and may need some fiddling to get it working. From there on it's a pretty standard formula of running around, finding items and using them in the right places while avoiding monsters. Plenty of optional collectibles to find as well. There are many enemy types with different behaviors and ways to counter them... 

...or not. 

And here lies the game's biggest flaw: many enemies in the game appear unexpectedly, outrun you easily and kill you almost immediately. Usually there's a way to escape; Sometimes there isn't. Regardless, death comes so quickly that there's no opportunity learn or try anything. Thankfully, you don't lose progress upon dying, and save points are frequent. However, as a result, many dangers are avoided not with your skill, but by dumb luck, brute force, and trial-and-error. If you're willing to bear with that, the game is otherwise enjoyable, if a bit barebones story-wise.

For many players the game crashes at start up and may need some fiddling to get it working.
From there on it's a pretty standard formula of running around, finding items and using them in the right places while avoiding monsters.
Plenty of optional collectibles to find as well.
There are many enemy types with different behaviors and ways to counter them......or not.
And here lies the game's biggest flaw: many enemies in the game appear unexpectedly, outrun you easily and kill you almost immediately.
Usually there's a way to escape; Sometimes there isn't.
Regardless, death comes so quickly that there's no opportunity learn or try anything.
Thankfully, you don't lose progress upon dying, and save points are frequent.
However, as a result, many dangers are avoided not with your skill, but by dumb luck, brute force, and trial-and-error.
If you're willing to bear with that, the game is otherwise enjoyable, if a bit barebones story-wise.

original_text:
Yomawari is an interesting little horror game where you play as the cutest little protagonist ever in her search for her "missing" dog and sister. Nights in Japan get pretty crazy however, and you must avoid being killed by spirits that apparently dont like your presence very much. The game itself might not satisfy you if you're looking for some intense horror, but there are at least a few good spooks in here. Its also important to consider the context, as you are an innocent child who is probably around 8 years old facing the very real consequence of death.

The Good:
+The game does an excellent job at mixing cute and scary with its artstyle. The atmosphere is also pretty on point.
+Overall design for the characters and spirits is really good and unique.
+Gameplay is simple yet effective, consisting of running from and avoiding spirits using various methods.
+There is a surprising amount of depth to the story, and quite a few heartwarming moments.
+Many small and subtle occurences throughout the town add some intrigue and mystery to the game.
+The game runs like a charm and I havent encountered any bugs whatsoever.

The Bad:
-Certain areas of the game can be a bit heavy on unfair deaths until you figure out how to make it through.
-At $20 the game isnt more than about 5 hours long, so the price may seem a bit much for some people.
-The game isnt exactly the scariest despite its good atmosphere. Spooky at best.
-An innocent little girl getting killed over and over is not okay. Dont mess up too much.

Its also worth noting that the game can actually be bit difficult at times, but this isnt much of a problem though since its mostly just simple trial and error. Overall a very good game that I highly recommend if you willing to pay the $20 despite how short it is (or at the very least grab it when its on sale).

analysis_results.chunk: Yomawari is an interesting little horror game where you play as the cutest little protagonist ever in her search for her "missing" dog and sister.
Nights in Japan get pretty crazy however, and you must avoid being killed by spirits that apparently dont like your presence very much.
The game itself might not satisfy you if you're looking for some intense horror, but there are at least a few good spooks in here.
Its also important to consider the context, as you are an innocent child who is probably around 8 years old facing the very real consequence of death.
The Good: +The game does an excellent job at mixing cute and scary with its artstyle.

The atmosphere is also pretty on point. +Overall design for the characters and spirits is really good and unique. +Gameplay is simple yet effective, consisting of running from and avoiding spirits using various methods. +There is a surprising amount of depth to the story, and quite a few heartwarming moments. +Many small and subtle occurences throughout the town add some intrigue and mystery to the game. +The game runs like a charm and I havent encountered any bugs whatsoever.

The Bad: -Certain areas of the game can be a bit heavy on unfair deaths until you figure out how to make it through. -At $20 the game isnt more than about 5 hours long, so the price may seem a bit much for some people. -The game isnt exactly the scariest despite its good atmosphere.
Spooky at best. -An innocent little girl getting killed over and over is not okay.
Dont mess up too much.
Its also worth noting that the game can actually be bit difficult at times, but this isnt much of a problem though since its mostly just simple trial and error.
Overall a very good game that I highly recommend if you willing to pay the $20 despite how short it is (or at the very least grab it when its on sale).

original_text:
If you're interested in Yomawari: Night Alone, it's likely you are looking for a horror game or something distinctly Japanese. With this one videogame you get both elements, and they're delivered in a way that I can guarantee is something you need to experience for yourself to appreciate. You will not be disappointed.  

Yomawari: Night Alone succeeds in its genre where other horror games fail by imposing a sense of subtle stress on the player. I'm not saying this game will make your hair turn grey, but it might just tense you up. Its endearing design draws you into a bubble, then pops it without warning. Then it does it again, and again, every time a new chapter begins or a new enemy is introduced. Playing Yomawari is like drowning in a bubble bath while your rubber ducky watches on... and I mean that in the best way possible. 

A passing glance at Yomawari doesn't do the game justice; Nippon Ichi Software's trademark cuteness is paired with a number of unsettling sensory experiences that deserve the full attention of every horror game fan. It's important to describe the game's elements in this manner because Yomawari isn't only pleasing for it's visual aesthetics. The sound design is among the clearest, cleanest, most detailed experiences in any past or present horror game. There is a surprising level of depth to everything from your own footsteps over metal grates to the wind rustling through nearby trees. Enemies skitter about and groan in ways expected of their horror genre counterparts, but every little note and noise is executed strategically. Yomawari sounds like how a nightmare should sound. Everything is satisfyingly disquieting. 

Perhaps most important to those reading Steam reviews, the game's mechanics are minimal but appropriate considering the world you're dropped into. The main character's defenses from the dangers of Yomawari's ghost filled streets are limited to a somewhat restrictive endurance system. You truly feel like you have the fortitude of a small, scared child. In-game adrenaline is lacking, despite the constant lub-dub of your heartbeat telling you monsters are near. A single bar and a beeping light at the bottom of the screen indicate just how much more energy you have left to escape your threats. A handful of usable items (five in total) help keep the dangers of the world at bay, but in no way eliminate the threats around you. And those threats truly are dangerous. Yomawari contains jumpscares. It contains enemies that can and will kill you many times until you discover the pattern of avoiding them. This is ultimately the games worst weakness, even if the system of try-and-try-again is very forgiving. There is little to no consequence for "dying" in Yomawari; you keep every item you collect, even if it was picked up immediately before being killed. And that's for a very good reason, since the amount of collectibles in this game - which range from curiously childlike to downright macabre - is quite large. Finding them all is an achievement in and of itself, as they are mostly optional to the story. Yet, the collectibles add a depth and feel, making them not feel tacked on or pointless. I genuinely wanted to find each ball of hair and broken dog toy and little crayon note that's scattered through the town. As long as you remember that searching is going to be dangerous, it becomes quite a fun little hunt. The game does remain dangerous and surprising throughout, even if your abilities to search the town are never truly upgraded or expanded. You're not playing Silent Hill where a shotgun is dropped on your lap and it's suddenly revealed you have godlike firing accuracy. You're a little girl whipping rocks, matches and dog treats in an often futile attempt to distract the immortal creatures of the night. And if your tiny arsenal of options run out, then with a heart-splattering darkness you say goodnight to your night alone.

The upside is that with every death, you are instantly teleported to the latest save point, which appear in the form of Jizo statues throughout the town. Interestingly enough, this particular choice in statue is indicative of an incredibly rich understanding of Japanese folklore that is pervasive through all of Yomawari. The Jizo statue is a representation of Kshitigarbha, a Buddhist deity known for it's connection to deceased children and hell-beings. The game's themes of childhood, fear of the unknown, longing for the decased - they're all powerful ideas that are strengthened by the unique world in which the game is set. When you die, you return home, or to Jizo (depending on where you last saved in relation to the chapter's start). You are a child, returning to the patron of dead children. This kind of subtlety helps the game go beyond using a typical Japanese suburb as the backdrop to just another horror game. It gives Yomawari an impressive depth and respect for not only its subject matter, but the connection to life's horrors as seen through a uniquely Japanese lens. This game isn't just about cute anime girls and jumpscares: Yomawari's developers went to great lengths to weave in a culturally rich narrative to their already interesting gameplay. 

As for the story itself? Spoiler's aside, a few searches online into some of the religious and cultural references help make Yomawari story a bit less opaque, as at times it can seem just that. Without brushing up on your Japanese folklore, the story can come off as simplistic. You are a little girl tasked in finding her missing family in a town that's been steeped in the very worst bits and bobs of childhood fears. Regardless, Yomawari's story relies heavily on the experience of playing the game - which, as a reviewer and a fan of good horror, I say it accomplishes wonderfully. Even without an indepth understanding of Japanese folklore, the story is bolstered by an overall game design that helps define the narrative just enough. It isn't a visual novel, it isn't a definitive action title. Yomawari: Night Alone is it's own entity, a truly unique video game that I recommend to anyone interested in Japanese folklore or horror in general.

original_text:
Yomawari has to be one of the most easygoing horror games I'd played. Although you're searching for beloved family members, most of the time you'll be exploring the creepy town at your own pace. The chilling aspects come from the unknown: "What IS that thing floating in the sky? Will it chase me? How should I get around it?" As the game goes on, you learn what makes these spirits tick and the best ways to deal with them. 

Yomawari is short. Painfully so. You'll be done in a few hours, even after trying to find everything the town has to offer. 

Despite this, it delivers on a thrilling (and yet charming) experience.

Despite this, it delivers on a thrilling (and yet charming) experience.

original_text:
A mildly spooky and atmospheric game that will have you searching for all sorts of clues in a creepy neighborhood to discover what happened to your missing sister and dog.

Considering I am a horror lightweight; yes, I screamed, jumped, and panicked more than once over the happenings in this game. The atmosphere is perfect for giving the player an unnerved feeling. If you want to try a horror game but you’re a bit of a chicken [like myself] this game shouldn’t be nightmare-inducing or keep you up at night, but it might give you a fright here and there.

The game controls took a little bit to get used to: I found myself more than once accidentally using the wrong item in an inappropriate moment because I forgot to switch this or that. There is no real combat, the game is more about avoidance.
For those of you going for completion, look everywhere for items, you will need to collect a lot. A guide may prove useful. Many of the collections item achievements rely on one another to be finished. 

I am basically done with this game except for one hang up. The achievement that requires 50+hrs of gameplay is glitchy and may require a replay of the game or some specific trick to make it work. [Personally, I don’t have the patience or time for that. Forever 99%.]

This game was a fun but eerie experience. Would recommend to those who aren’t looking for a hard-core horror experience.

Achievement Hunter’s Note: Hoard salt. The Long Night achievement tends to glitch. This may keep you from 100%-ing the game as it did for me.
Achievement Acquisition Difficulty: Medium

original_text:
Yomawari Night Alone is a very cute horror game with a unique story. Travel around the town finding various objects and piecing everything together as best you can while trying not to die in a number of horrific ways.

Yomawari doesn't rely on jumpscares as much as many modern horror titles and takes a more atmospheric approach to make you feel genuinely unsettled. Those who enjoy Japanese horror titles will feel at home with this game.

Though the game itself is not very long I would still recommend buying it if you are a fan of Japanese Horror or creepy-cute things.

original_text:
The art and sound design are top notch but the fear element in this game is quickly replaced by frustration. So much of the game is just running around aimlessly just hoping to stumble upon something to maybe help progress some part of the story which becomes tedious and obnoxious. As someone that easily gets scared in games, this game I stopped getting scared because I was just so frustrated and at a loss at what I was supposed to be doing. Turns out, an area I thought was blocked off for later was actually a tedious "bait the enemies out slowly and one-by-one in order to progress" section. If that was the solution that "early" in the game and I was already that frustrated I did not want to encounter more "puzzles" like that so I threw in the towel. 

The game is also literally littered with collectibles which sound great at first but when you've been running around for 40mins trying to find what you need to do and you finally stumble upon a shiny item that may be something you need for it to only be another useless "collectible" you start to see red...

It's a bummer because the environment and atmosphere is so incredibly well done that it's held back by tedium and frustrating gameplay.

You can watch my livestream gameplay of the game over on my [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GOjEZJgpibw&list=PL0q93Rkkmx_ubqRG9NXGFrnqB1cBwuQI5&pp=gAQBiAQB]YouTube Channel[/url]!

original_text:
A cute horror game with a nice story.

First off, I haven't had any issue with the game crashing. I was a little scared after seeing all the reports after my purchase but there were no issues.
The only thing that happened a few times was that when I played on Steam Deck and it went on Standby Mode the game would freeze and I had to restart it.

Besides that I had a lot of fun exploring the game and collecting all the items. The riddles (with the Mary Doll or the Hide & Seek) were my favorites. There is a slight jumpscare, the death screen. Not really a jumpscare but it can catch you offguard sometimes and definitely jumpscare you.
I liked the ending & I think It's really cool that you can continue playing and exploring after finishing the story.

The achievements were fun but the 'Long Night' Achievement (Play for 50 hours) is a bad idea for the game and badly designed as well. You usually finish the game in about 10-12 hours, so even 2 playthroughs would just cover half of the achievement... worst part is that you have to achieve 50 SAVED ingame hours. Means if you have 50 hours on steam client but lost 8 hours of progress because you did not save ingame, it doesn't count and you don't get the achievement.
Very important note as well: You can ONLY save at home. The little shrines are just checkpoints for your respawn after you die somewhere. If you DO NOT save at home you will lose your progress and the hours shown on steam are inofficial.

I'd recommend it. If you enjoy horror games that have their main focus on the story. you will like this one! ( •ω•ฅ)

original_text:
The game has a cute art style and is reminiscent of RPGMaker Horror games, but it's overly focused on the frustrating chase element.
While the types of spirits do follow their own rules, it's easy to die without understanding why.
Checkpoints are sparse and everything kills you instantly, meaning you'll be replaying sections multiple times.
The only saving grace is you keep all items you picked up, but that only encourages the player to bolt for items without fear of death.
Even when you know what you need to do, the margin for error is always so small that it can still take multiple tries to do a section.
This gets really bad at the end of the game, where survival feels much more about luck than skill or understanding.

I wouldn't recommend it unless you love the art style or have a high tolerance for trial and error.

original_text:
Yomawari is a pretty good horror game, but the PC port just sucks. It isn't completely unplayable, but VERY unstable. Whether or not you can make it to the next save point before another crash is pure luck. 

The game itself is fine. The gameplay revolves around running and hiding from some well designed monsters, and using keys and other items in the correct places. The only knock on the game itself is that you die in one hit, and sometimes baddies literally come of out nowhere, so you don't actually know what killed you or what you did wrong. Unfortunately, some of the horror is lost when you are repeating the same areas over and over.

EDIT: Having the game file open in Visual Studio 2015 while playing does seem to prevent crashes. I have no idea why this works, or if it will continue to work in the future. Worth a try in any case.

I have no idea why this works, or if it will continue to work in the future.
Worth a try in any case.

original_text:
When I saw a trailer for this back in the day when it was only on Vita, I was kind of hyped for it, because I'm a horror fan. But now that I've actually played it, I'm kind of disappointed. It's pretty casual. I mean, it's super casual. The main way of dealing with enemies is to run away from them since most of the items are highly specialized against one enemy type that you probably won't see in most of the other areas that you're exploring. The main driving force of this game is exploration like in other games like Yume Nikki, but without the surrealism of Yume Nikki. And you'd think in a game where the main mechanic is exploration you would have some interesting environments to explore, but no, you're exploring a normal Japanese town sprinkled with some outdoors type environments.

If you're still interested, I'd recommend waiting for it to go on sale. I don't believe it's worth $20.00.

original_text:
Oh, Yomawari... How much I love this little game!

It's an amazing horror game! It's not long by any means and although it has some difficult parts due to jankiness, it allows you retry almost instanstly, so it never gets frustrating.

It's also clear how much inspiration it draws from 2010's RPG Maker games such as IB and Yume Nikki, which is great! I hope it inspires even more games in this genre!

The graphics are beautiful and really set a scary atmosphere... It basically has no OST, but it just adds to the ambience.

It's one of my favorite games of all time. It's super recommended!

original_text:
A fun casual horror game with a very morbid beginning.
Worth it if you get it on sale (Got mine for like $2.50 after watching some streamers play the beginning).
Kind of niche so I would look into the first 10 min of gameplay to see if you like the play-style.

PLEASE NOTE:
The controls on the PC port are clunky and some people have crashing issues.
I would not recommend playing this game without a controller.

The out of the box "Controller support" does not work with any of the xbox one, xbox 360, or gamepads I have. I was able to fix this however by going to steam settings > Controller > General Controller Settings then check the boxes on EVERYTHING to have controller support enabled for any device you can think of. Doing this made the game start working with my xbox 360 controller.

====================================================================
Update after completion of the game:

This game has some puzzles that can be convoluted at times, however with persistence and or a game guide this no longer becomes an issue. The story is overall engaging and a fun mostly casual horror experience. It mixes elements of cute character designs and fun item descriptions with some dark subject matter and an enjoyable horror game.

The one thing that nearly killed the experience for me without spoiling any of the plot is that near the very end of the game you are forced to try and run past large hand enemies down a narrow path. There are community posts about how BS it is that the enemies not only have incorrect hit boxes, but you also have to greatly rely on luck or getting the ai stuck to continue on. After about probably 30min-1hr I was able to finally figure out how to bug out the first AI to get stuck on small poles to continue onward. The second AI commonly gets stuck on a pole unless you hug the lower part of the map which sounds like a good thing until you realize it often forces a player death by blocking the path.

Even though I was eventually able to get past them by beating my head against a wall, this level of flawed game design is one of the worst instances I have ever seen. Even having played countless hours of dark souls and many unforgiving games this task was an extreme and unenjoyable task to complete which I doubt many casual players would be willing to stick it out long as I was to complete the story. This is a shame considering that not only is the story enjoyable, but this happens right before the final boss of the game which is much easier and there are probably many out there who could not finish the story right at the end due to negligence on the creator.

If this was the only flaw with the game it could still be fine, but with the poor optimization of the PC port where many other users reported crashing, the clunky pc controls/not working controller support out of the box, and some extremely convoluted puzzles at times this game is hard to recommend without any fixes from the creators (which I doubt will happen since this game was released about 8 years ago).

Even with all of the flaws I still recommend this game for its unique story and memorable intro for anyone who is willing to look past its flaws and is persistent enough to complete the main story. Even if you get stuck on the last level like I did, Id recommend looking up the ending of the game for a satisfying conclusion to the game.

original_text:
Let me begin by saying that although I like this game, I do not think it's worth 20$.

The game offers around 4-7 hours of gameplay depending on whether you die often or have trouble finding key items, and maybe a little more if you wish to find all the collectibles.

The mechanics are simple and create a creepy and helpless atmosphere, but some are underutilized, like the stone throwing. (Some monsters reacts to your presence or the noise you make, but don't react when you throw stones).

Death in this game is a bit too permissive; you keep all your items after daying, which means that running, pressing A to loot, and dying works just fine to progress the game, which is a shame in my opinion.

The game brings you to the four corner of your town, each time discovering some dark secrets and resolving cases. Each time, a new zone will open and you will find clues leading you to your sister and your dog. The story is not the driving force behind your actions, but it would have been nice to have a little more, as I couldn't get invested. R.I.P. Poro though.

Each zones reuses the same mechanics, each time with some twists, sometimes the spirits are different and requires new strategies, or the zone itself is labyrinthine.

As the game progresses, I feel like it loses its charm. The mechanics are quite barren, and beside the scary aspects of the spirits and the atmosphere, the game doesn't have much to offer.

The three last zones in particular, Downtown, The Factory, and beyond the tunnel, each brings a bad aspect of the game to light.

Downtown makes you play with a special mechanic that I won't spoil, but to resume, it lets you play with 'perspective'. In the first, monsters blocks your path, and in the other they don't, but you can't accomplish your objective. You need to navigate the two perspectives and place special items in certain locations.

I had to rack my brain and roam through the whole zone to finally succeed after dying a couple of times, and even then, I completed my objective by running like a madman and ignoring the spirits. This wouldn't be a problem had the game not based its entire atmosphere around running AWAY from spirits.

Anyway, I can't call the zone bad, but I won't call it good either.

However, a zone I will call frustating is; The Factory.

The game's end is near, and you feel it; spirits wandering everywhere, a big monster chasing you at certain times, and a big but not open zone.

This area was very frustrating. At specific moments, a big monster will chase you, and if you do not begin to run the moment the cutscene ends, you die. It took a couple of tries, but the thing, you don't respawn right next to those cutscenes, you generally have to run twenty to thirty seconds before.

But The Factory is nothing compared to the end.

The last zone, not named in the game, but that I will call Beyond The Tunnel here, is sometimes fine, and selectively horrendous.

You have to avoid 'hands', but those spirits get stuck on terrains, meaning that you can have trouble predicting them, plus you have to manage your stamina like never before, and moves precisely, AND do this three times in a row if your game bugs like me.

After each hand, you will reach a safe zone, and the game is supposed to save. Well, it wasn't the case for me, so I had to perfect the three hands that get stuck of f*cking terrain in a row, knowing that if I failed, I would have to do it all over again. In few words, excruciating moments, and bad game design.

And finally, you arrive at the end! The final boss is before you! I won't spoil anything, but I will tell just one thing.

The boss is laughably easy compared to the hands that get stuck on terrain.

You finished the game, congratulations, now you can go collect and the sh*t people threw around the town, spend 50 hours with your game in the background to have an achievement, or kick a can 50 times for another one.

And that's all for my review. Despite its flaws, I liked the game. But to be honest, it's really not worth 20$. It offers no replayability, it's 6 hours long if you don't search around, and it's lenght is inflated by all the collectibles laying around. (Looking at you "Kid's sandal"). The story is barebone and the mechanics won't keep you around either. But it's not a bad time, and I had a fun time with my friend, so my 5$ were well spent.

If you wish to buy the game, wait for sales, I can't decently recommend it for 20$.

original_text:
The first of two games, Yomawari: Night Alone is a game that successfully mixes cutesy graphics with more horrific spooky content. You control a young girl looking for her missing sister, who went out to find your pup and never returned. The town isn’t exactly as peaceful as you might expect, either.

Gameplay focuses on evading monsters and scouring the environment for objects and ways forward. Pretty much every monster can instakill you, which leads to some annoying sections of trial and error. You can hide in some things like bushes, but that might not always be enough. There are also a ton of collectibles, encouraging you to explore the town and surrounding environments. Monsters also change based on which part of the game you’re in, letting you explore areas you may have missed earlier.

The monsters themselves have some cool, scary designs. The gameplay sometimes makes them more frustrating than scary to deal with though. The trial-and-error sections are hurt by the occasionally terrible checkpoints. There are also points in the game which really tug at your heart. The moment you see that you have a dog, you know it’s going to be involved in sad events, for example. The atmosphere is bolstered by creepy sightings and a great soundscape. Be warned that there are jumpscares in addition to the well-done atmosphere. 

I didn’t encounter any noteworthy glitches or crashes, but I’ve seen other people report them while playing. Overall, this is a great game with some annoying sections. If you had to play one of the two games in this series, I would recommend Midnight Shadows instead, which features a lot of improvements.

You control a young girl looking for her missing sister, who went out to find your pup and never returned.
The town isn’t exactly as peaceful as you might expect, either.
Gameplay focuses on evading monsters and scouring the environment for objects and ways forward.
Pretty much every monster can instakill you, which leads to some annoying sections of trial and error.
You can hide in some things like bushes, but that might not always be enough.
There are also a ton of collectibles, encouraging you to explore the town and surrounding environments.
Monsters also change based on which part of the game you’re in, letting you explore areas you may have missed earlier.
The monsters themselves have some cool, scary designs.
The gameplay sometimes makes them more frustrating than scary to deal with though.
The trial-and-error sections are hurt by the occasionally terrible checkpoints.
There are also points in the game which really tug at your heart.
The moment you see that you have a dog, you know it’s going to be involved in sad events, for example.
The atmosphere is bolstered by creepy sightings and a great soundscape.
Be warned that there are jumpscares in addition to the well-done atmosphere.
I didn’t encounter any noteworthy glitches or crashes, but I’ve seen other people report them while playing.
Overall, this is a great game with some annoying sections.
If you had to play one of the two games in this series, I would recommend Midnight Shadows instead, which features a lot of improvements.

original_text: Very cute game with beautiful art and creepy monsters. Generous with checkpoints and focused on trial and error.

Generous with checkpoints and focused on trial and error.

original_text:
A very good cutesy horror game about a little girl trying to find her pet dog and older sister who go missing when their town is suddenly infested with spirits.

Some things to note is the game doesn't really tell you some very important things, one being that the Shrines you can "save" at by donating a coin to aren't really "saves", they're actually temporary checkpoints that you will respawn to when you die. To actually save, you need to pause the game and press the button to return home and save at your diary. If you DO NOT do this, and before you head off, you instead save at a Shrine, you will lose all your progress!

It is okay to die in this game, that's what the Shrine checkpoints are for, you are going to die a lot in trying to figure out puzzles and how enemies work, and all the items you pick up are still with you when you die. So don't be afraid to die!

Also, there is a button to turn off your flashlight, it's the Back button on an Xbox Controller, and B (I think) on keyboard.

I had a lot of fun playing this game, I enjoyed the story. There are a ton of collectables for you to find also if you're into doing that, and you can continue playing the game after you beat the story to find them all. I personally didn't do that because I'm not that interested in that sort of thing, only the story.

So don't be afraid to die!
Also, there is a button to turn off your flashlight, it's the Back button on an Xbox Controller, and B (I think) on keyboard.
I had a lot of fun playing this game, I enjoyed the story.
There are a ton of collectables for you to find also if you're into doing that, and you can continue playing the game after you beat the story to find them all.
I personally didn't do that because I'm not that interested in that sort of thing, only the story.

original_text:
I really want to recommend Yomawari, I do -- but I can't. I can't seem to play more than an hour of the game without it crashing.

Over the short time I could play, I was able to get a small impression of the game: Controls and movement are challenging, even punishing (often to a somewhat unfair degree), but given enough time and patience the player can usually work out the best approach. Gameplay could probably have been balanced more towards puzzles than chases without affecting the tension. The obvious shining mark on this game is the aesthetic; gorgeous environments, character/monster design, and representation of Shinto elements give the game a unique look and feel that sets it apart. 

Shame I can't actually play it.

original_text:
I really wanted to like this one. I like the art style, the monster designs are cool, the audio is all great. There is so much trial and error in this game that it ruins the experience, and there are random/inconsistent elements that make it very, very, very, very, very frustrating to play in several segments. I streamed a full playthrough of the game, took a little over 4 hours, and by the end I was ranting like AVGN about how bad it is.

The hitboxes on some of the enemies are very off and there are very narrow pathways you have to go through near the end where the monsters are just so unpredictable that it's just not viable to clear it consistently, and they make you clear like six of those pathways in a row. They give you a save point halfway through, but it literally took me like 50 attempts. So frustrating. So bad.

4/10. Really wanted to like it.

original_text:
Somewhat interesting - if short - story. Tedious gameplay.

Endless trial-and-error, slow movement and consequence-less, one-hit death soon drown the eerie mood established by the intro sequence. Getting killed at one point or another becomes the faster alternative to walking back.

Took 10h for the main story and 2h in freeroam. Some collectibles are mostly luck-based, so walk over to the right spot, check the RNG. Nothing there? Let yourself be killed. Rinse and repeat.

The last remaining achievement requires 50h in-game time, which translates to idling the game in the background. What's the point with that?

original_text:
Just beat it a few minutes ago! I think a lot of the criticism in the negative reviews for this one is warranted. It has a lot of flaws. For me, it was buggy. If I tried to do anything in the menus too quickly, the game would just lock up and stop functioning altogether. In essence, quicksaves were pointless. A lot of the gameplay was very trial-and-error, which is a really negative strike against it. There are a couple of parts that seemed impossible to me and I ended up making progress only to discover I had to backtrack and do some really tight maneuvering if I wanted to actually move forward. More than likely, you'll need to look up a guide for parts of it. 

However, the mechanics at surface level are really good; it's a tense game and you really have to manage your stamina properly. The atmosphere is on-point and really draws out the feelings the devs are looking for. There's a couple of jump-scares, but for the most part, this is proper horror game. If you're willing to look past some of the glaring flaws, I'd super recommend this one--especially on sale. But, if you want a fully functional and stable build, I'd assume the console version is a much better option.

If you're willing to look past some of the glaring flaws, I'd super recommend this one--especially on sale.

original_text:
This isahesitant recommendation, and I'll explain why.

I have heard small buzzes about this game for a while now, so I finally bought it on sale (which I'd highly recommend doing, as it's avery short game, about 4-5 hours tops). It's got a great Silent Hill type set up. You're a young girl walking her dog one night when said dog is run over. You go home and tell your sister that the dogis missing, and she goes out to find it. But when she doesn't come back, you set out to find her, exploring the town and dodging the spirits that roam the streets at night.

For positives, it'smostly the production values. The art is simply gorgeous and the sparse sound evokes a quietly disturbing atmosphere of dread and mystery. The monster design is top notch. The game is filled with truly bizarre creatures unlike any I've seen in a horror game. Think if Studio Ghibli decided to make a horror movie and you've got an idea of what the enemies are like. Honestly, I think the atmosphere is the main selling point since it's so strong and disturbing.

The problem comes with the game play. All of the monsters kill you in one hit without exception. You're usually transported to the last check point (statues that populate the town). It's usually only a few seconds of progress lost, but the thing is that the controls, while not bad, are simply not sharp enough for the scenarios the game places you in. Dodging monsters is nowhere near as responsive as it needs to be, and there are several sections throughout that lose their potency due to how many times you'll have to play them. Chapters 3 and 6 stand out in my mind as being the most problematic due to the mechanics of their respective bosses. And much of this comes from the fact that, for some unknowable reason, the closer you are to a monster, the faster your stamina drains. It's entirely counter productive. When you're not around any monsters, you can run for a good long time. When you're in the vicinity of a monster, it goes down pretty quickly, but you still have enough wiggle room to escape usually. When you're right near a monster, which happens very often, your stamina depletes in about a second and a half, yet there are several scenarios where you are forcedto dodge monsters that are faster than you. All of this is to say nothing about the "story," which is fragmented at best and perfunctory at worst. I don't need everything spelled out for me, but things just kind of happen with no real rhyme or reason. It rarely feels like you're making any actual progress towards finding your sister, until the final chapter which just comes out of nowhere and doesn't offer any real sense of closure.

As an idea for where I stand on this game, I'd give it a 6.5/ 10. It truly is worth sticking through everything just to see the monsters and soak up the unique, nightmare esque atmosphere. I amlooking forward to the sequel, which at the time of this writing is only a few days away. I just hope the developers take notes on the many problems with the gameplay and story and manage to do their wonderful atmosphere justice in every facet of the next game. 

So I do recommend it, but with a huge asterisk. That asterisk is you have to be able to put up with frustrating game design and an underwritten story.

original_text:
Yomawari: Night Alone is an amazing hidden gem.

A beautiful game about a young girl desperately trying to find those she lost and exploring the edges of the town she lives in to do so.

The gameplay, while simple and at times frustrating is very enjoyable. Cautiously and methodically moving around trying to find clues, keys, or tidbits of information all while the threat of a looming terror approaching is what I live for. 

The story is even better, a young girl looking for her missing dog and sister, every little quip the protagonist had about her sister or her dog Poro made me all the more invested to bring this night to a close for her.

The main theme of this game is beautiful and for fifty cents for the theme I can say I would pay triple that amount just to commend the work that was put into this theme.

The Yomawari series is terribly under-appreciated for all the love the developers put into the designs and representation of Japanese deities and creatures. Please, if you haven’t already, play this game. If you like those classic RPG maker style horror games (Ex. Corpse Party, Ao Oni) you’ll LOVE Yomawari. I can only dream Nippon Ichi makes a fourth one after Lost in the Dark.

P.S: Thank you Koi for getting me hooked on this series ;)

I'm going to be honest, I was very back and forth for a long time on whether I liked this game or not.  I did decide in the end that the good outweighed the bad, but there's a lot on both sides.  My favorite part was probably the open-world atmosphere.  You're able to move freely about the map, and while sectors are ocassionally sectioned off from the player at the beginning, I never felt lost or like things were being kept from me.  The art is lovely, the atmosphere works, and for the most part, the ghosts are interesting.

On the other side, this game was clearly meant to be played on a controller.  I'm a mouse and keyboard kind of person and it took me quite a while to feel comfortable with the controls, and even then, sometimes getting around felt extremely convoluted due to controls.  It became extraordinarily frustrating to the point where I wanted to quit the game.  Additionally, the saving mechanic took me longer than I'd like to admit to figure out.  You can continually quick save around the map, but the only known way to save was going home, and for the longest time I didn't know how to get back in the house before the chapter ended.  In fact, I didn't think you could.  However, I found a forum post late game that showed me how, but at that point, it was virtually useless for me since I was already in the last chapter.  So, yes, there is a save mechanic, but it was clunky to use in my opinion.

So, in the end, I've decided the game deserved a thumbs up, but it definitely has some issues as well.

original_text:
It's a neat little game that combines cute and creepy. Developed by the same people who created Firefly Diary or htoL#NiQ, it let's you explore a town in the middle of the night where all the ghosts and spirits wander around. 

The strength of the game is definitely the design of the ghosts and monsters. From stick figures, creepy woman to giant hairball spider, it's not lacking in enemy variety. You are allowed to explore the world although it does have a linear progression. I also really like the UI of the game. The map is a drawing of the little girl you are controlling and it's updated as you roam around the town. 

Unfortunately just like the devs' previous game, the weakness of the game is the difficulty and controls. Though the controls of this game are fine, the mechanics around it is flawed. Just like other horror games like Amnesia: The Dark Descent, there's no combat here and your only option is to run. They decided to add a stamina bar for running. The way it works though is that the closer the monster is to you, the faster the stamina drains. This factor alone makes the game more frustrating than it should be. Note that 1 hit from a monster is instant death. So you'll find yourself constantly getting killed just because the girl ran out of stamina. There is one particular part of the game where you have to be pixel-perfect in running away from a monster and I think I died a total of 10 times just because I didn't escape the hitbox of the monster by a hair.

The story is kind of sparse in this one so if you're looking for a good story, then you'll be disappointed. Most of the bits and pieces of the story is written from the collectibles that you get as you explore the town. Most of the post game is also about collecting stuff and finding extra side events.

All in all, I still recommend this game. If you're looking for a slightly creepy game and likes exploration in games, then you'll like it. Just beware of the frustrating gameplay mechanics.

original_text:
Yomawari Night Alone is a decent little game with a great artstyle. I've bought it multiple times, and every single time I've had a great time with it. You can complete it in about 5-7 hours depending on your skill level with games like this.

The story is nothing to write home about. You're mostly looking for your dog and sister while what lurks in the shadows (literally, you can only see most monsters in the light of street lamps or your flashlight) hunt you down.

The gameplay loop is doing a set bit of story each night, wandering about the town and dodging lots of genuinely cool monsters. Monsters that aren't boss monsters you can kinda just end up running past with reckless abandon eventually, but boss monsters demand you respect their mechanics. At points the game does feel cheap with its deaths though, as the hitboxes of various enemies are genuinely atrocious, and some enemies either teleport or are very fast.

Post game content is there, but it's nothing to write home about. You're mostly looking for items, some of which are behind rare monster events that will require you to keep resetting to your house to get. Tip though, once you do, save at a Jizo Statue as it keeps the event working in case you get killed. Also amass the maximum amount of salt, you'll thank me later for recommending this.

Why do I not recommend this game then? It has two sets of critical bugs that can literally make it unplayable. 

The first bug is that it can just not open. It'll get to the loading screen before the title and then just simply close with no error put on the screen. The other one is that even if you don't resize the window, the game will freak out and think you did, giving an error then closing the game once you get to the same loading screen error. All suggested fixes I've seen on the Steam forums and beyond have not worked for me. What makes it weird is that the game did work fine once or twice, so the issue can appear at complete random.

However, this game does work totally fine on my Steam Deck 512 GB LCD unit. I was able to play the game from start to end with zero issues. I've even been doing the play for fifty hours achievement on it, which admittedly is me just sitting in the protagonist's room, ha ha. That achievement counts ingame time by the way, not Steam hours time. It runs at 60 fps with no issues with sound, graphics, or the before mentioned crashing while maintaining at least three hours thirty minutes of battery life. I did not need to mess with my version of Proton to make it work.

If you do wanna get this game, get it on sale and don't be afraid to refund it. I'd honestly recommend getting it on another platform if you can, as it is a decent little adventure. The chance is very minimal, but I do hope one day this game gets fixes.

original_text:
[h1]For a cute graphic, it succeeded in giving me nightmares :)[/h1]

I wanted to see the new genre Nippon Ichi is creating because this is totally different from all the games I've ever played from the developer. Well, regrets no regrets, I managed to finish the game after experiencing [strike]too[/strike] many heart attack. For a 2016 game, the gameplay and genre is kinda new for me because it wasn't your usual tactical/combat RPG, and it's not a puzzle platformer either. Even now I can't really say what's this gameplay really is lol. But for a horror and jumpscare i'd give it a 10/10. I thought I'd be ready to play it when the sun's out but lol no I was sooooooooooo wrong.

The horror atmospheric and ambience are nicely done to increase the horror vibes. I'll give it a go if you're someone who likes horror game. Well, if some of you still find it "too cute to be horror", let me just tell you that's what I thought at first too...

original_text:
I want to be able to enjoy this game. The first 10 or so minutes seem at least promising. The game has an unsettling vibe despite its cutesy graphics, largely due to its mostly subtle sound direction.

Unfortunately, that's all I can play of it. The game crashes for me in Windows 10 without fail, just when I'm given the first opportunity to save at the character's home.

Searching for this problem brings up no shortage of "fixes", but basically puts the problem at the feet of the player even in the official forum post: update everything, uninstall a Windows update (which is only relevant to Windows 7),  move to another hard drive, enable Compatibility Mode, don't run in full screen, exit out of full screen at the right point, etc.  I was most hopeful about using the beta build, which at least implied the developers were doing *something*, but it didn't solve my issue.

Because it crashes when saving, my game never actually ever *saves*. Which means that each time I try another work around, I have to start at the beginning of the game, go through the tutorial area and then hope maybe it won't crash when I try to save again. I've tried several times now.

I got this in a bundle, so I avoided paying full price, but am frustrated because this game was the primary reason I bought the bundle at all. 

For me, and apparently a decent amount of people, the game is just not even playable. I'm frustrated that nothing has been done about it.

I was most hopeful about using the beta build, which at least implied the developers were doing *something*, but it didn't solve my issue.
Because it crashes when saving, my game never actually ever *saves*.
Which means that each time I try another work around, I have to start at the beginning of the game, go through the tutorial area and then hope maybe it won't crash when I try to save again.
I've tried several times now.
I got this in a bundle, so I avoided paying full price, but am frustrated because this game was the primary reason I bought the bundle at all.
For me, and apparently a decent amount of people, the game is just not even playable.
I'm frustrated that nothing has been done about it.

original_text:
This positive review comes with several caveats.
1. This game can be frustrating and unforgiving.
2. One of the achievements (Long Night) is pretty obnoxious to get. It took me about 15 hours to complete this game, but I'll need to idle it up to 50 for that last achievement.

That said, visually this game is beautiful. The atmosphere is perfect. I liked the story and all the collectible quests.

Some sections were needlessly frustrating though. Several enemies move extremely quickly, and getting touched by any of them is an insta-kill. I followed a walkthrough guide, purely to limit the frustration. When the price for failure was so high (often requiring a long walk through multiple minor enemies to get back to where you were) I was not inclined to experiment or explore.

Overall, I enjoyed the game, but could have done without some of the more finicky sections.

Some sections were needlessly frustrating though.
Several enemies move extremely quickly, and getting touched by any of them is an insta-kill.
I followed a walkthrough guide, purely to limit the frustration.
When the price for failure was so high (often requiring a long walk through multiple minor enemies to get back to where you were) I was not inclined to experiment or explore.
Overall, I enjoyed the game, but could have done without some of the more finicky sections.

original_text:
What makes a good horror game, in my humble opinion, is all about suspense and atmosphere.  And this game has both in spades.

First is the sound design.  In this game you hear your character's heartbeat (and she has a diminished stamina bar for running away) when you get too close to a spirit.  Add to that the ambience and the enemy groans and snorts, and you're in for a creepy ride indeed.

Second is the visual design, and the art for this game is on par with the likes of Silent Hill or Zero/Fatal Frame.  A lot of the spirits are not downright menacing, but rather strange and curious, and it really captures the right feel for such ambiguous creatures.

The story is pretty minimalist as well, with a very basic outline that gets your character motivated to explore the night.  But that's really all they need.  I think leaving the nature of the enemies a question was a good story decision.

So overall, I'd highly recommend this game if you're looking for something spooky and atmospheric.

analysis_results.chunk: What makes a good horror game, in my humble opinion, is all about suspense and atmosphere.
And this game has both in spades.
First is the sound design.
In this game you hear your character's heartbeat (and she has a diminished stamina bar for running away) when you get too close to a spirit.
Add to that the ambience and the enemy groans and snorts, and you're in for a creepy ride indeed.
Second is the visual design, and the art for this game is on par with the likes of Silent Hill or Zero/Fatal Frame.
A lot of the spirits are not downright menacing, but rather strange and curious, and it really captures the right feel for such ambiguous creatures.
The story is pretty minimalist as well, with a very basic outline that gets your character motivated to explore the night.
But that's really all they need.
I think leaving the nature of the enemies a question was a good story decision.
So overall, I'd highly recommend this game if you're looking for something spooky and atmospheric.

original_text:
do NOT buy this game.

It crashes all the time and yet the game only lets you properly save in one location (your room). The quick saves at the shrines do NOT recover your game if it crashes.

I was super intrigued by the stealth horro mechanic and loved the art. However, whoever had the idea of getting LESS stamina when there are ghosts nearby.... just... why?

You literally run SLOWER and lose stamina FASTER when you're trying to run away from an enemy, which doesn't make any sense.. and will cause a TON of deaths. Not because the player is doing anything _wrong_ persay but the mechanics are DREADFUL. 

I LOVE difficult games, literally my favorite games are the soulsborne games, darkest dungeon, the binding of isaac, etc. I LOVE a challenge. However, THIS game isn't "challenging" it's just BAD DESIGN and extremely frustrating with no reward or pay off.

This is the only game that ever made me tilt on stream because of the constant crashes and progress loss, and the completely unfair and badly designed game mechanics. I know a lot of fellow content creators who also stopped playing this game partway through.

DON'T WASTE YOUR TIME

original_text:
I really play a lot of different games, and I try everyone to give it a chance and to play it through.
But this game really forced me to stop. Such a bad gameplay.

You cannot fight the enemies, you have to hide or run (if you ever can escape) but mostly if you meet an enemy it will lead to a restart at the last quicksave point. You got no coin for the quicksave? Too bad then.
But this doesn't matter if you got nerved of dying and want to quit you have to do all again from the beginning of the chapter, as you only can really save after every chapter.

So, you will meet an enemy who teleports randomly in front of your way, often you get stucked and hit because of bad hitboxes. Really fun... not.

The only good things I managed to find are:
- cute graphic
- enemy designs are good

Sorry really looked forward into playing this and the sequel, but got really disappointed.

A young girl is walking her dog Poro around town at dusk when a tragic accident forces her to return home with only Poro's leash in hand. The girl's sister commands her to stay home while she goes out into the night to search for the dog. Time passes. Growing impatient, the girl decides to search for her missing sister and dog herself. 

Pros:
1. Cute horror game
2. Japanese ghost
3. Item to collect
4. PORO!

Cons :
1. Jumpscare 
2. PORO DIE !!!

Yomawari Sequel is coming ~

10/10

original_text:
Through the streets angered spirits of all kinds chased me, with jagged jutting fangs and gaping black sockets for eyes. Their fast pitterpattering along the asphalt and heart-crushing presences followed and filled my vision with spectacular redness. My heart pounded its way through my fragile little ribs, leaving me to waddle away. 

Stone dogs popped out of bushes to snap down with a barking surprise. Floating backpacks grabbed my arms and split me in two. Starfish with burning eyes chased and splattered the streets. Marshmallow tufts lead me down paths only to meet towering puffmen to slaughter me the same. All around no spirit would let me be, no spirit would let me find my big sis.

But then there was that walking statue in the school courtyard, reading his granite book and stiffly stepping with his hard rock sandals. All he did was pace back and forth, reading a single engraved stone page. I stood in his way and he continued forward, carrying me with him. I felt my heart slow to a calm, silent beat and snuggled up against his slim, rough thigh.

Not all spirits are so bad after all.

analysis_results.chunk: Through the streets angered spirits of all kinds chased me, with jagged jutting fangs and gaping black sockets for eyes.
Their fast pitterpattering along the asphalt and heart-crushing presences followed and filled my vision with spectacular redness.
My heart pounded its way through my fragile little ribs, leaving me to waddle away.
Stone dogs popped out of bushes to snap down with a barking surprise.
Floating backpacks grabbed my arms and split me in two.
Starfish with burning eyes chased and splattered the streets.
Marshmallow tufts lead me down paths only to meet towering puffmen to slaughter me the same.
All around no spirit would let me be, no spirit would let me find my big sis.
But then there was that walking statue in the school courtyard, reading his granite book and stiffly stepping with his hard rock sandals.
All he did was pace back and forth, reading a single engraved stone page.
I stood in his way and he continued forward, carrying me with him.
I felt my heart slow to a calm, silent beat and snuggled up against his slim, rough thigh.
Not all spirits are so bad after all.

As if tilting the screen every 2 seconds would help me feel "immersion". no, it just makes me wanna puke.

original_text:
This is a simplie horror game with awesome visuals.

The horror atmosphere is constant during the exploration of the tiny city, with distinct environments and souls that can haunt/hunt you down.
The game has a simple mechanic of distract / run for your life. The gameplay is simple but many enemies will be able to kill you in the minor mistake you do... making some parts a game of try and error. 
While death is a punishing form, after few dozen deaths the perspective of dying becomes an annoyance instead of dread. 

The game is short, pretty and interesting enough to be worth playing.

original_text:
This is one of the most tedious and frustrating games I ever played. It's the first game in like 20 years that made me wanna rage quit and I have a very high frustration tolerance. 

The main problem is the game crashes. A lot. And it's not my system, there are numerous posts on the forums about it, go check for yourself.
That alone is bad enough, but it gets worse in combination with the save system. You can only save your progress at your house. There are several statues on the map where you can create a checkpoint to respawn at when you die, but they won't save your progress.
Since the game crashes so much, you can choose between risking to lose hours worth of progress or going to your house every five minutes to save.

Another issue is all the "boss fights", which are mostly chasing sequences. They're often quite unfair and timed so tightly that you have no margin for error. For example, in one of those sequences you're being chased by a dead woman who can teleport in front of you and attack, in which case you're supposed to turn around and run the other way, but even if you anticipate it and yank your stick the other way immediately, she'll still get you 90% of the time. 
Then there are also lots of cheap and unavoidable deaths. You take the wrong path, a monster appears, you lose control over your character and die. The only way to avoid it is knowing it's there.

All this is exacerbated by the character's slow movement speed and checkpoints being literal miles away from those difficult sections. It sometimes takes you up to three minutes to walk back to where you died. That doesn't sound like much, you might say, but sit down and start counting seconds up to 180. And now imagine you have to retry a section five to ten times and have to walk back just as many times. That's up to 30 minutes of walking. And then your game crashes and it was all for naught. Infuriating.

original_text: [i][b]Yomawari: Night Alone[/b][/i] is a horror-adventure. The game is linear, but it's hard to guess what area to visit next, has unusual and uncomfortable save system (checkpoints work within one game session, hard save is possible only at the end of a chapter or at the hub) and any collision with a spirit leads to restart at the last checkpoint, while keeping all items found at the moment of it. The graphics, soundtrack and (customizable) controls are adequate, though I couldn't bind flashlight to mouse. There are many collectibles, but they just decorate MC's home and don't have any other application.

analysis_results.chunk: [i][b]Yomawari: Night Alone[/b][/i] is a horror-adventure.

The game is linear, but it's hard to guess what area to visit next, has unusual and uncomfortable save system (checkpoints work within one game session, hard save is possible only at the end of a chapter or at the hub) and any collision with a spirit leads to restart at the last checkpoint, while keeping all items found at the moment of it.
The graphics, soundtrack and (customizable) controls are adequate, though I couldn't bind flashlight to mouse.
There are many collectibles, but they just decorate MC's home and don't have any other application.

original_text:
I cannot give a recommendation for a game that is broken. Multiple reports of crashing that have never been addressed, and saving at statues doesn't actually save - there is no explanation given that this is just a checkpoint method and you can only actually save state in your home. Valve strikes again. And the devs should be ashamed for not addressing any of this.

UPDATE: I finally worked up the willpower to play this again, hoping I would be able to work past its bugs to actually enjoy myself. It's awful. Every area looks the same. Controls don't work well, neither do the game's extremely limited mechanics. Never going back, life is too short.

And the devs should be ashamed for not addressing any of this.

original_text:
Control scheme is really bad. I have tried to play it several times and I still haven't figured out how the inventory system is supposed to work.

Skipping dialogue is slow. It is frustrating that I can only seem to be able to do it with mouse when moving is done with the arrow keys. There's a lot of unskippable cut scenes with slow walking characters, and it is often unclear when these cut scenes are over. This was specially frustrating since I kept dying.

Gameplay seems confusing and I am not entirely sure what example, throwing a rock does.

The game crashed twice and didn't save my progress.

original_text:
This is a really neat little survival horror game that is heavily focused on exploration, the atmosphere is spooky and the game isn't over reliant on jumpscares just allowing the ambience to linger.
There are a few moments that feel a bit overly trial and error which kind of kills the scare factor when you are doing the same section over and over, however i by no means think these moments are game ruining however.
As for the story, its very non intrusive which i liked, focusing on showing rather than telling the player what's happening.
The art speaks for itself, its a very nice art style that really complements what the game is going for.
Id overall give it a 8/10,

original_text:
So on the one hand, this game is wonderfully thematic. Explore an empty and distinctly Japanese city while avoiding monsters which look like they crawled out of one of Miyazaki's nightmares. 

Contact with a ghost will kill you instantly. Some people might find this frustrating after dying a bunch of times in the same location, personally I've found it to add to the tension.

On the other hand, there are a few cons. Keyboard controls are awkward. I'm four hours in, and I'm not really engaged in the main plotline. The puzzles I've encountered so far are limited to ''find object, place in obvious location''. You will die a lot, and many of those deaths are practically unavoidable, so there's a fair bit of trial and error. There are cutscenes here and there which try to play to your emotions, but they just come off as slow and irritating.

There are some mechanics which feel like they're tacked on - rocks for instance. I can throw a rock about a foot, I can't collect it after it's thrown, and most ghosts ignore them. The city is strewn with collectibles - bits of gum, old plastic camera - I guess those are thrown in to cater for completionists? 

Apparently there are some side events I'll need to explore in more detail - little noteworthy encounters which you might find off the beaten track. It's a really cool idea, but these encounters seem pretty sparse. I think I've found one in four hours of play. I'd need to consult a walkthrough to have much of a chance to notice them, and to know what to do once I did.

All things considered, I would recommend this game to others. I really enjoy exploring this spooky Japanese town. It's a shame though, with better writing and a bit more polish it could have been spectacular.

analysis_results.chunk: So on the one hand, this game is wonderfully thematic.
Explore an empty and distinctly Japanese city while avoiding monsters which look like they crawled out of one of Miyazaki's nightmares.
Contact with a ghost will kill you instantly.
Some people might find this frustrating after dying a bunch of times in the same location, personally I've found it to add to the tension.
On the other hand, there are a few cons.
Keyboard controls are awkward.
I'm four hours in, and I'm not really engaged in the main plotline.
The puzzles I've encountered so far are limited to ''find object, place in obvious location''.
You will die a lot, and many of those deaths are practically unavoidable, so there's a fair bit of trial and error.
There are cutscenes here and there which try to play to your emotions, but they just come off as slow and irritating.
There are some mechanics which feel like they're tacked on - rocks for instance.
I can throw a rock about a foot, I can't collect it after it's thrown, and most ghosts ignore them.
The city is strewn with collectibles - bits of gum, old plastic camera - I guess those are thrown in to cater for completionists?
Apparently there are some side events I'll need to explore in more detail - little noteworthy encounters which you might find off the beaten track.
It's a really cool idea, but these encounters seem pretty sparse.
I think I've found one in four hours of play.
I'd need to consult a walkthrough to have much of a chance to notice them, and to know what to do once I did.
All things considered, I would recommend this game to others.
I really enjoy exploring this spooky Japanese town.
It's a shame though, with better writing and a bit more polish it could have been spectacular.

Been trying for hours to fix this game. Haven't played a second of it. I tried the very scarce advice i managed to find in the discussions. Company can't even fix the game. The game launches, the window doesn't appear. I click on the tab and i hear sound but see nothing. No window appears on my screen. I've tried everything from compatibility to settings in the files, verifying files, reinstalling, etc. 

Company hasn't fixed this since 2016 and at this point i'm sure has given up entirely. the community doesn't even bother replying to the threads begging for advice because, i assume, no one knows how to fix it. The game either runs for you or it doesn't. And if you got this via code like i did, well then you're screwed and out of money. Thanks a lot NISAmerica. Definitely removing the sequel from my wishlist and probably won't buy a game of theirs unless i know i can refund it, as it will likely not work judging by this horrible experience. 

BTW 1 card drop in 4 hours. the least they could've done if i was gonna sit here troubleshooting for so long, is give me cards out of it.

original_text:
A slow-paced, atmospheric horror game about a young girl who, following a traumatic event,  must navigate her spirit-infested neighbourhood at night to search for her missing sister.

The town itself  is certainly moody enough, with an interesting array of ghosts and monsters to encounter, but ultimately the slow nature of the game ends up being a detriment at times, with the stamina bar tending to be more of a hindrance than anything else.

Still, as far as horror games are concerned, you can certainly do far worse.

6/10

The town itself is certainly moody enough, with an interesting array of ghosts and monsters to encounter, but ultimately the slow nature of the game ends up being a detriment at times, with the stamina bar tending to be more of a hindrance than anything else.
Still, as far as horror games are concerned, you can certainly do far worse. 6/10

original_text:
I love the game's main idea and the story starts off with an interesting approach to give you purpose. Controls are pretty simple too, which I enjoyed.

Unfortunately, the world is WAY too big for such a small scope of a story. Then the game get's filled with "things to find" and little fetch-quest kind of things which I really am not a fan of. If the game narrowed the world and just took me through its engaging story then I'd have been happier with my overall experience. I still had fun, I'm just not a fan of the "extras" it tried to tie in; Especially achievements and collectibles that are largely luck based.
