original_text: While I did end up enjoying the game's story overall, and thought it had a very fun artstyle, the gameplay later in the game was far too frustrating to the point where I wouldn't recommend getting invested in the game. I found that while the environment was beautiful, it was at times hard to interpret where you could and could not go. There were also some chapters where I ended up wandering around for far too long trying to find my next goal, which can be fun given that the environment you're exploring is more telling of where you should go (this was not the case here). I probably will buy the other yomawari because I do really enjoy this 2D style of horror game - and also because it is newer and hopefully some of the gaming issues were improved upon.

original_text:
Horror adventure where you wander around a town filled with spirits to progress the story and find collectibles.  It's very easy to die but you don't lose any progress aside from being moved back to the last save point.  Unfortunately some scripted segments are very tightly tuned and you'll probably have to repeat them several times, which tends to ruin the atmosphere.

Treads a line between spoopy and just frustrating.  Around six bucks on sale which feels appropriate for its ~4 hour playtime.

Unfortunately some scripted segments are very tightly tuned and you'll probably have to repeat them several times, which tends to ruin the atmosphere.
Treads a line between spoopy and just frustrating.
Around six bucks on sale which feels appropriate for its ~4 hour playtime.

original_text:
This is a hard core action game, not for any casual play. The save system is demanding, you must complete each chapter (with a few temporary quick saves). Yet these are not major issues if you have the time. There are other detrimental problems:

1. Navigation is hard with keyboard only. If you use a controller, the game clashes once the controller somehow loses connection (which happened to me at least once during each chapter)
2. The game requires you to explore the town, but the map is totally unreadable (maybe intended, I dunno)
3. This game is designed for handheld console (PS Vita). Game mechanics should be modified for PC play, but nothing is done. 
4. If the game clashes for any other reason, due to the save system, you are required to start from beginning of the chapter again.

I do not recommend anyone to waste your time on this game.

The save system is demanding, you must complete each chapter (with a few temporary quick saves).
Yet these are not major issues if you have the time.
There are other detrimental problems: 1.
Navigation is hard with keyboard only.
If you use a controller, the game clashes once the controller somehow loses connection (which happened to me at least once during each chapter) 2.
The game requires you to explore the town, but the map is totally unreadable (maybe intended, I dunno) 3.
This game is designed for handheld console (PS Vita).
Game mechanics should be modified for PC play, but nothing is done. 4.
If the game clashes for any other reason, due to the save system, you are required to start from beginning of the chapter again.
I do not recommend anyone to waste your time on this game.

I want to start off that I really enjoyed this game.

Pros
- Great story
- The world is pretty big feels like you can go where every you like
- Very pretty and atmosphere is great
- Great tutorial gets into the story quickly

Cons
- Some ghost are easy to avoid while other feel cheap like teleport in front of you making impossible to avoid or move fast then you. So be prepared to die a lot.
- Some time you just stop moving

I like the game and I got it on sale which if you can get it on a sale I high recommend this game.

original_text: For those wanting to use a controller, this game has a terrible first time impression. Instead of the usual Press B (xbox controller) or O (playstation controller), LB or L1 and so on, the game says press button 1, button 2, button 3 or button 4 all the way to button 7. You are forced to find out which button on your controller represents button 1-7.

original_text:
Since the trailer, i've been wanting this game. This little jewel. I am a fan of Nippon Ichi. Played almost every tactics game of them, since PS2. Bought this game for myself, halloween present. A treat to myself. Full price. So eager to play, such a beautiful game...

... that doesn't work. Seriously, DOESN'T WORK.

They made a game that it's only guaranteed to work on a PC with DirectX 11 and DDI 11. Everything else is like a russian roulette. A week has gone and the support just says that it's looking for the answer. Go, look at the community. The topics are going. There was a beta version of the game. NOBODY had the problems that's bubbling in the topics? Seriously? 

I am disappointed with NIS. I will not say that I will not play this game anymore. Maybe someday, in a sale, when the problems will be in the past and, maybe, i will change my opinion about this game and NIS.

For now, refunded it.

This little jewel.

Played almost every tactics game of them, since PS2.
Bought this game for myself, halloween present.
A treat to myself.
Full price.
So eager to play, such a beautiful game...... that doesn't work.
Seriously, DOESN'T WORK.
They made a game that it's only guaranteed to work on a PC with DirectX 11 and DDI 11.
Everything else is like a russian roulette.
A week has gone and the support just says that it's looking for the answer.
Go, look at the community.
The topics are going.
There was a beta version of the game.
NOBODY had the problems that's bubbling in the topics?
Seriously?
I am disappointed with NIS.
I will not say that I will not play this game anymore.
Maybe someday, in a sale, when the problems will be in the past and, maybe, i will change my opinion about this game and NIS.
For now, refunded it.

original_text: Ok. Played this for a bit. 2 things to beef about. 1. Major Spoilers I guess. I don't care cause I'm a little pissed. You will see a animated dog get hit by a car in the first 5 minutes. I am still pissed about this. 2nd. There is a save point in your house. Save when a chapter ends or begins I guess. There are shrines you can pay a coin for to quicksave. Very useful. But I could not get back into my house in chapter 2 and didn't realize the quicksave would not last after I shut the game off. So Just lost a decent amount of progress. That all being said. I do like the art style and the whole vibe. Not a fan of the controls though. Buy it if you like the genre but maybe wait for a sale.

original_text:
A young girl is walking her dog Poro around town at dusk when a tragic accident forces her to return home with only Poro's leash in hand. The girl's sister commands her to stay home while she goes out into the night to search for the dog. Time passes. Growing impatient, the girl decides to search for her missing sister and dog herself. 

But when she steps foot outside, she realizes that this is not the same town. The darkness has made the town unfamiliar, and she appears to be utterly alone...save for the spirits that stalk her. The girl must hide from, outsmart, or outrun the hunting spirits while she searches for clues to find her loved ones.

100 of 10

original_text:
[h1]BAD GAME![h1]

I really wanted to like this game but It makes it so hard. Extremely linear, repetitive, and couldn't even manage to scare me once. The part that made me realize this game isn't worth my time is when I was lost in the school because I didn't know what to do next. I unlocked the pool, drained it, and then searched through the drain in which the game decided to tell me - "It's a drain.". A quick google search later I apparently had to search the 3rd drain pipe to find the next key item even though there was no visual distinction between any of the 4 drains there. With this being so early in the game too I don't want to see what other "puzzles" will be awaiting for me next.

I unlocked the pool, drained it, and then searched through the drain in which the game decided to tell me - "It's a drain.".
A quick google search later I apparently had to search the 3rd drain pipe to find the next key item even though there was no visual distinction between any of the 4 drains there.
With this being so early in the game too I don't want to see what other "puzzles" will be awaiting for me next.

original_text:
Another example where the adage 'don't judge a "xxx" by its cover' has proven. BAD EVERY THING imaginable!
*Insanly slow and boring walking sim. You literally can't even run for one second!
*No plot, no exploration - walk straight to the point, go home(chapter end), repeat. Thats all!
*Game is NOT SCARY, ONLY PAINFULY REPETITIVE - 90% is death screens, one after another, 9% walking, 1% map screen.
*The whole game is trial and error, no skill or learning will help, the game can even kill player whenever it wants(some of the deaths are just scripted).
*A lot of enemies just poorly and lazily designed, huge hitboxes and invisible walls(disproportionate to what I see on screen), sometimes its impossible to distinguish  passage to the new location without a map, disgusting level layout.
*The game seems to have been developed as a "kusoge" genre  and is unsuitable for mediocre player who wants to play a regular 5+ hour horror game.
*Uncomfortable keyboard controls, you practically need a gamepad to play.
Strongest NO, even at a discount!

original_text:
Yowamari Night Alone is an Isometric adventure game from Nippon Ichi Software famous for the Disgaea franchise.  You play as a little girl trying to find her lost sister and dog in your home town gone SPOOKY.  The gameplay consists of little more than managing your stamina as you dodge monsters and other creepy things while exploring the map.  The game is 2 to 3 hours long and there isn't any music so I would be wary about the price. 

In the end I recommend it because it's not a bad game.  It's just that so many of these 'weeb' titles are overpriced because they know anime/manga fans will fall for it every time.  I mean look at neptunia...

analysis_results.chunk: Yowamari Night Alone is an Isometric adventure game from Nippon Ichi Software famous for the Disgaea franchise.
You play as a little girl trying to find her lost sister and dog in your home town gone SPOOKY.
The gameplay consists of little more than managing your stamina as you dodge monsters and other creepy things while exploring the map.
The game is 2 to 3 hours long and there isn't any music so I would be wary about the price.
In the end I recommend it because it's not a bad game.
It's just that so many of these 'weeb' titles are overpriced because they know anime/manga fans will fall for it every time.
I mean look at neptunia...

original_text:
Well, I can only get about 30 minutes into it before crashing. Reading the forums, I'm starting to understand that random crashes are part and parcel with this game. Some sort of memory leak issue, perhaps? The closest thing to a fix is a post from 2016 directing players to play the beta version of the game. Playing the beta version does not resolve the issue.
I don't think I can recommend this game on steam.
I liked what I played of it. Beautiful game, excellent atmosphere, and a large variety of malevolent ghosts eager to do violence upon your person. Manages to keep the tension and doesn't overplay the jumpscare card.
However, the fact that a known issue has been left unfixed for so long is baffling, and I get the feeling it will never be fixed. I will change my recommendation if it ever does.

Some sort of memory leak issue, perhaps?
The closest thing to a fix is a post from 2016 directing players to play the beta version of the game.
Playing the beta version does not resolve the issue.
I don't think I can recommend this game on steam.
I liked what I played of it.
Beautiful game, excellent atmosphere, and a large variety of malevolent ghosts eager to do violence upon your person.
Manages to keep the tension and doesn't overplay the jumpscare card.
However, the fact that a known issue has been left unfixed for so long is baffling, and I get the feeling it will never be fixed.
I will change my recommendation if it ever does.

nice art style, but I don't like the gameplay, where you just run around Zelda Style and try to avoid enemies who kill you in one hit. You can hide at specific spots but it's not that enemies move past your hiding place, they just stand there, so it's more like you pull them towards you and circle around them....
also, it'S really hard to play the game with controller, when you get only prompts like Button 1, Button 2, etc...

Not impressed!

original_text:
Once upon a time, there was a little girl who wanted to be the best. She brought her Pok*balls and some moneys, and went  outside with her Pok*mon, Poro.
Inside a park, she found a Pok*mon. "At last!", she said. So she threw a Pok*ball so hard, sho she could get that Pok*mon.
...but it didn't work.
She threw all of her Pok*mon she had. But it's still useless.
...The Pok*mon came closer, "A wild ***** appears!", but she couldn't see it clearly.
Then she yelled, "Poro, use FLASH!", and Poro did it. Now she could see what Pok*mon it was...

...except that wasn't Pok*mon...
...it was dark, tall shadows...
...so creepy, eh?

...also that round hard thing she brought? That's not a Pok*ball, not even round tho...


...and where's Poro?
We never know...

Stay tune on "Pok*mon GONE!"

original_text:
I have a lot of difficulty playing obtuse, poorly designed games.

I find this is one of them. 

I strongly recommend that you purchase this at a very deep sale like I did, but be prepared to use a guide or die an absurd number of times trying to figure it out. It isn't hard, and isn't scary. It is creepy, but I found it annoying more than anything else. I didn't look up anything because I didn't want spoilers, but having experienced nearly an hour of this for myself, I don't really care to continue any longer, guide or not.

original_text:
Alright, so it's an upvote despite feeling quite annoyed with the game. You have a decent formula for a charming horror, but oh boy do I absolutely loathe the running sections in chapter 6 and 7. Why oh why would you make the chase sequences with randomized odds of success - cause honestly, there doesn't seem to be any rhyme nor reason to your winning strategy. You are required pixel-perfect precision while randomly dying to enemies' rapid turns, random stamina recovery and random amount of steps you are allowed to take, randomly outspeeding enemies by a pixel (or not) (or outspeeding them and dying anyway, cause their hitboxes are like a mile away from their body and the air will hit you and kill you at random either way. You are welcome). 
I spent about 2 hours dying over and over and over again during the ending, which would take probably 10 min at max otherwise. Why do we need to suffer so, dear devs.
Though, if you forget random bull like that (and a few other bullshit sections, though those were minor) it's a fun game with decent atmosphere. I liked it, even when I hated it at times.

Why oh why would you make the chase sequences with randomized odds of success - cause honestly, there doesn't seem to be any rhyme nor reason to your winning strategy.

You are required pixel-perfect precision while randomly dying to enemies' rapid turns, random stamina recovery and random amount of steps you are allowed to take, randomly outspeeding enemies by a pixel (or not) (or outspeeding them and dying anyway, cause their hitboxes are like a mile away from their body and the air will hit you and kill you at random either way.
You are welcome).
I spent about 2 hours dying over and over and over again during the ending, which would take probably 10 min at max otherwise.
Why do we need to suffer so, dear devs.
Though, if you forget random bull like that (and a few other bullshit sections, though those were minor) it's a fun game with decent atmosphere.
I liked it, even when I hated it at times.

original_text:
This game makes my monitor look drunk.

I get that it's a Vita port, and I own a PS Vita. Games look good on the 5in screen, but if you're going to port to PC, you need higher res asssets or the game will look like sh!t.

Having said that, it's a fairly charming game with questionable time-wasting mechanics. Want to know how specific enemies work? Die, and repeat. Want to explore the map? Die and repeat. Want to pad out game length as a developer? Make the player die and repeat a lot. Wait, on second thought, *don't* do that.

Much of the game involves aforementioned dying and repeating. When you're not dying and repeating your last few minutes of gameplay, you're hiding in a bush instead of playing the game.

It's nice to see interesting games getting ported from Japan, but at $20, you are not getting your money's worth. Wait for a sale.

original_text:
I'm not exactly sure why people keep saying that this game is scary because it simply isn't. Apart from a few jump scares/ startling events in the beginning the game quickly becomes quite tedious and frustrating. The art style is too cutesy to make me feel creeped out and the mechanics used to avoid ghosts don't work as well as they should.

Eventually it just becomes a game that tests how effectively you can run around ghosts. Your sprint does not last long or even work as potently as it should meaning some ghosts can't be outrun. The rocks you use to distract? ghosts don't work as far as I've played in the game. You can't throw them far and the ghost don't seem to pay attention to them. The flashlight mechanic is interesting but, seeing that you can only point the light directly in front of you, causes you to have to run towards some ghosts in order to see where they are. Hiding also does not work on all ghost as some will simply wait for you to reveal yourself once again.

The storyline starts off well enough but quickly desolves into unanswered questions. You have a young girl who appears to be spending several nights alone, without parents, who is randomly searching for her sister; meaning she seems to pick the next area randomly without suspicion. She also appears to not realize that her dog died or that her sister was kidnapped, only knows that she is currently missing. While normally I believe that the unknown adds to the sense of horror in scary media I believe that it has to be done tactfully in order to be effective. I don't think Yomawari really does so. The game also has a tendency to corral you in the direction it wants you to go; which again takes away from this spooky feeling of the unknown.

The saving grace of this game that prevents it from being absolutely terrible are the interesting puzzles and of course kittens! but all in all I don't think this title is worth the 20$ and it's really hard to call it scary. It's really too simple to be interesting and spends too much time killing the player.

If you're looking for something similar I'd recommend Claire or Corpse Party.

The art, cute. 
The story is simple and easy.

Some people might enjoy this because of all of the above but personally, I want to have fun when I play games, not get frustrated.

original_text:
Right at the very start, I walked up. It told me I had to go the other way. I pressed down, character would not move. I was stuck. Any people want to test their game? Or maybe have some failsafe?

Well that aside, the screen is very annoying. Every time I change direction. The screen lurches in that direction jarringly. The visual style is very peculiar and confusing at times. Mostly I just spent 5 minutes navigating a maze of roads without much structure or design and zero charm. I was left feeling very little motivation to continue.

original_text:
A fun game with an intriguing but enjoyable story.
Visually creative the game is able to capture the intended atmosphere quite well and both the ghosts and the map share elements in design that feel justified and provide visual cues to their respective background,
The gameplay is simple but straightforward allowing the player to better appreciate the surrounding environments and details. Despite that some sections do feel a bit hard to operate when running away from certain spirits which can be frustrating, specially during long sections with several enemies that send you quite a lot back to your last save point. In those particular cases the tension from the scary atmosphere is greatly reduced upon each retry effectively hindering the overall experience by locking the player in a test of skill of sorts.
The main story is told through the normal game progression, but at the same time several items scattered across the map offer the player a series of mini stories that contextualize the origin of most spirits and give a greater sense of immersion.

Also, keep in mind that this is *per save file*, so if you lost your *only* save slot or deleted it to replay the game again (since there's nothing left to do when you complete post-game lol) like I did... well, tough luck, gotta do it aaaallll again. At the least the game has the decency of letting you unlock the achievement by leaving it idle in the background as long as you are inside the main character's home.
Well, now I have a game with a ridiculously inflated playtime on my account, so thanks I guess? lol

original_text:
I can't begin to describe how much i love this game.

Yomawari night alone is best experienced with as little information as possible. Talking about any part of the game detracts from the experience but let me do my best. 

One of the best horror games i have ever played in my life. The developers perfectly provide the player with absolutely terrifying experiences that are only placed into some context with experimentation and your curiosity. 
The world is not black and white but rather much more mature and human. The story also has much tension with if the desired outcome will take place or will leave you the player heartbroken. 

I would love if everyone were to play this and experience the roller coaster of emotions that i did. I can not recommend the game enough, the only sad part is that the game is not designed around replay ability, although there is content that can extend you experience that does not mean that a new play through will feel fresh but rather samey.

all and all a 9.5 out of 10. The last 0.5 is my own personal bias on what i would deem the perfect experience.

original_text:
NIce little game (but still one to get on sale)! All the other reviews saying it's more of a "horror-themed" game than a horror game are 100% right, though. It's fairly small and fairly simple, but fun to play and explore, and there's quite a few really interesting mechanics that I'd love to see put to use elsewhere. With that, though, it's definitely got its gripes: a lot of it really is just trial and error, since everything kills you in one hit and many of the spirits you can't outrun or they don't return to a path when you hide, so it's a lot of figuring out their mechanics and then finding out how to game those mechanics to get around them.

Liked it enough that I'm gonna go wishlist the sequels, tho.

original_text:
If I had to describe Yomawari: Night Alone in one word, that word would be tedious.

This is more of a horror-themed game than a horror game. It can be difficult in the sense that you need to check every nook and cranny for items while repeatedly dying over and over just to be told that you went into an area that wasn't meant to be explored yet. It's an unsatisfying mixture of a collectathon and all the worst parts about bad horror games: heavy repetition and restarting from a checkpoint over and over so you can just get past that one enemy and get to the next chapter.

The game isn't terrible, but really gets excruciating at chapter 5 and essentially remains that way for the rest of the game. Night Alone is also quite short, averaging a 5 hour playthrough. So keep that in mind before you buy.

Overall, this is the weakest game in the series so far. I played it because I like the franchise. And unless you have already played both of the sequels and want more, there's no reason to pick this one up.

This is more of a horror-themed game than a horror game.

It can be difficult in the sense that you need to check every nook and cranny for items while repeatedly dying over and over just to be told that you went into an area that wasn't meant to be explored yet.

It's an unsatisfying mixture of a collectathon and all the worst parts about bad horror games: heavy repetition and restarting from a checkpoint over and over so you can just get past that one enemy and get to the next chapter.
The game isn't terrible, but really gets excruciating at chapter 5 and essentially remains that way for the rest of the game.
Night Alone is also quite short, averaging a 5 hour playthrough.
So keep that in mind before you buy.
Overall, this is the weakest game in the series so far.
I played it because I like the franchise.
And unless you have already played both of the sequels and want more, there's no reason to pick this one up.

original_text:
This was a fun, mildly spooky adventure game about a girl who loses her dog in an accident, then has to go searching for her sister in a town where every Japanese ghost movie is happening at the same time, everywhere.

Gameplay honestly feels more like a bullet hell than anything. Every type of ghost has different movement patterns to avoid and you die in one hit -- your progress is almost entirely retained upon respawn, so the penalty for failure is very small. You can get by just running away for most of the game, but the last few levels do require you to actually learn how to deal with each enemy to make it through.

It's a pretty compact experience, unless you want to go for all the collectibles, and based on Steam achievements most people won't want to do that. Spritework is sharp and very distinctive, just cute enough to take off some of the edge but it can still get you in some spots. Sound's about what you'd expect, mostly ambient noises.

As long as you're willing to take hits a few times to get through a couple unusually tricky spots, it's a good time.

analysis_results.chunk: This was a fun, mildly spooky adventure game about a girl who loses her dog in an accident, then has to go searching for her sister in a town where every Japanese ghost movie is happening at the same time, everywhere.
Gameplay honestly feels more like a bullet hell than anything.
Every type of ghost has different movement patterns to avoid and you die in one hit -- your progress is almost entirely retained upon respawn, so the penalty for failure is very small.
You can get by just running away for most of the game, but the last few levels do require you to actually learn how to deal with each enemy to make it through.
It's a pretty compact experience, unless you want to go for all the collectibles, and based on Steam achievements most people won't want to do that.
Spritework is sharp and very distinctive, just cute enough to take off some of the edge but it can still get you in some spots.
Sound's about what you'd expect, mostly ambient noises.
As long as you're willing to take hits a few times to get through a couple unusually tricky spots, it's a good time.

original_text:
Yomawari is a top down puzzle adventure horror game, That will pull you in with it's art style and intense atmosphere.  It's a very good hidden horror gem, but it has it flaws.  Mostly the trial and error deaths.  In this game, if an enemy touches you then you are very much dead.  There are moments where you are trying to get somewhere, but suddenly you get jumped by something and you are killed.  Most of your deaths will be like this, most enemies you can avoid very easily.  But some enemies can be very cheap.  I really like the theme on most of the levels.  The levels are actually pretty fun, EXCEPT for the factory.

That level is simply full of frustration and obvious design flaws.  That level is not mean to scare you or make you feel intense, it's simply there, to cause you frustration.  Overall, Yomawari Night alone is a gem worth considering.  But  I would wait for a sale, as this game is pretty short.  You will finish it in around 5 hours give or take.

analysis_results.chunk: Yomawari is a top down puzzle adventure horror game, That will pull you in with it's art style and intense atmosphere.
It's a very good hidden horror gem, but it has it flaws.
Mostly the trial and error deaths.
In this game, if an enemy touches you then you are very much dead.
There are moments where you are trying to get somewhere, but suddenly you get jumped by something and you are killed.
Most of your deaths will be like this, most enemies you can avoid very easily.
But some enemies can be very cheap.
I really like the theme on most of the levels.
The levels are actually pretty fun, EXCEPT for the factory.
That level is simply full of frustration and obvious design flaws.
That level is not mean to scare you or make you feel intense, it's simply there, to cause you frustration.
Overall, Yomawari Night alone is a gem worth considering.
But I would wait for a sale, as this game is pretty short.
You will finish it in around 5 hours give or take.

original_text:
I don't think this game is outright GOOD, i think it does a lot quite poorly actually, but I myself really enjoyed it. It's nice to have a horror game that's so focused on exploration and adventure, and i think it handles horror extremely well. It doesn't just throw cheap jumpscares at you to make you constantly fear when the next shock is gonna happen, it just throws you in a hell hole and leaves you to deal with the feeling of being lost and alone in a scary place. Personally, i think that's really fun. It invokes your sense of adventure while also making you scared to explore, which was a really bizarre feeling to experience.
I do think it goes a bit too far leaving you feeling lost, as MANY things are confused and unexplained, or are entirely reliant on trial and error, and I definitely think that can be bad enough to ruin the game for many people. However, for me personally as someone who LOVES adventuring and exploring, i thought this was a really fun experience!

original_text:
Super cute and charming horror game! The art style really sets this game apart and it has such a strange foreboding atmosphere while still being comfy. While brutal at times it is also quite forgiving, I'd say it's definitely more on the casual side. 

I haven't beaten it yet but the story is decent enough. The gameplay is mostly centered around exploring a town and avoiding entities while finding items and learning more about what is going on. The story is quite dark and tragic though, tugging at your heartstrings immediately even in the tutorial.

It works great on the Steam Deck too! Works perfectly with the controls and the handheld nature works great to immerse you in the world.

Overall the perfect little game for Halloween. It matches the creepy and comfy atmosphere of the holiday quite well.

original_text:
An adorably ominous horror game where you have to search your hometown for you sister after she doesn't return home. The game itself (and Yomawari Midnight Shadows) is extremely well designed and does so many creative things. I would love to tell you what those things are but if I did, it would ruin the experience. The general gameplay isn't complicated and feels very fair. You're primarily exploring and collecting various items while avoiding malicious spirits.

I love the art-style, it mixes cute characters with a creepy town filled with horrific monsters. The sound design also really helps create a good ambiance. The story, while minimal, is still emotional.

Unfortunately the game seems to have issues with crashing which doesn't effect playing through the story too much, does affect the aspect of exploration and collecting. If the game doesn't work for you and you can get a refund, I'd recommend getting the Long Night Collection on another platform.

The sound design also really helps create a good ambiance.

If the game doesn't work for you and you can get a refund, I'd recommend getting the Long Night Collection on another platform.

Extremely late to the game, picked this up during a sale and completed in around 6 hours. Generally a solid little adventure of a little girl set out to resolve some little misery around her town...
The atmosphere is okay, wasn't really scary, there are some jump scare moments in the game but not much. If you want a quick adventure minimal horror game with cute girl, this is your pick.

original_text:
despite having a pretty appealing style this game is exceptionally tedious as a stealth game and remarkably bland as a horror. 
not really any cool or novel horror concepts, and what is there is generally really predictable or is executed flatly. The scariness of the monsters wears off really fast as soon as you realise they all have the same evasion tactic of just walking away, and when they break that mould figuring things out is more frustrating than engaging. Puzzles are stupidly simple but still manage to be a pain because of arguably unfair instant deaths and the game's annoying checkpoint system that makes you walk the same tired paths again and again if you fail, with one level in particular having a particularly patience-testing layout with little to no hints as to where to go.

analysis_results.chunk: despite having a pretty appealing style this game is exceptionally tedious as a stealth game and remarkably bland as a horror. not really any cool or novel horror concepts, and what is there is generally really predictable or is executed flatly.

The scariness of the monsters wears off really fast as soon as you realise they all have the same evasion tactic of just walking away, and when they break that mould figuring things out is more frustrating than engaging.

Puzzles are stupidly simple but still manage to be a pain because of arguably unfair instant deaths and the game's annoying checkpoint system that makes you walk the same tired paths again and again if you fail, with one level in particular having a particularly patience-testing layout with little to no hints as to where to go.

original_text: It's a bit hard to recommend as there are some very frustrating parts and a fair bit of trial-and-error. That said, when you're not dying unfairly, it is quite good. You'll probably have a lot of collectibles left to find after you finish the story. Bunny hopping helps a lot in the last chapters (rapidly tapping the dash button - the bar quickly refills so you can run longer).

original_text:
I only recently got my first gaming PC, and both Yomawari games were among the first games I purchased. I absolutely LOVED this game. You play as a very young girl walking the streets of a small Japanese town, looking for her sister, who has gone out looking for their lost dog. The art style was this amazing dichotomy of cute/adorable and horrific. The fact that there was no way to fight the ghosts made them even scarier. All you could do was sneak, hide, and run. It made encounters extremely stressful. But despite the horrific elements, I found the game enchanting. The centipede demon was just a mesmerizing little bit of storytelling, as was the ghost wandering the cliffs. The ending, and the sacrifice the main character had to make, had me gasping because it was so shocking. It was all just really well crafted and wonderful, and very neatly wrapped up in a little 6-8 hour package. I adore short, concise games that have a clear story, tell that story, and then end.

My only real gripe with the game is the stamina bar, which is the main “battle” mechanic. The closer you are to a ghost, the more frightened you are, and the quicker the stamina bar decreases, which makes for some OBNOXIOUS chase sequences and boss battles when you’re just zig zagging and hiding to conserve the three seconds of stamina you get because you’re surrounded by ghosts. I died so frequently during the main sequences that it eventually became more of a “memorize the route” than a frightening ghost chase.

I’d give Yomawari: Night Alone 8.5/10 and would absolutely recommend it to everyone.

I absolutely LOVED this game.
You play as a very young girl walking the streets of a small Japanese town, looking for her sister, who has gone out looking for their lost dog.
The art style was this amazing dichotomy of cute/adorable and horrific.
The fact that there was no way to fight the ghosts made them even scarier.
All you could do was sneak, hide, and run.
It made encounters extremely stressful.
But despite the horrific elements, I found the game enchanting.
The centipede demon was just a mesmerizing little bit of storytelling, as was the ghost wandering the cliffs.
The ending, and the sacrifice the main character had to make, had me gasping because it was so shocking.
It was all just really well crafted and wonderful, and very neatly wrapped up in a little 6-8 hour package.
I adore short, concise games that have a clear story, tell that story, and then end.
My only real gripe with the game is the stamina bar, which is the main “battle” mechanic.

The closer you are to a ghost, the more frightened you are, and the quicker the stamina bar decreases, which makes for some OBNOXIOUS chase sequences and boss battles when you’re just zig zagging and hiding to conserve the three seconds of stamina you get because you’re surrounded by ghosts.
I died so frequently during the main sequences that it eventually became more of a “memorize the route” than a frightening ghost chase.
I’d give Yomawari: Night Alone 8.5/10 and would absolutely recommend it to everyone.

original_text: Yomawari Night Alone is a survival horror game that takes place in a regular Japanese town. While the game is by no means perfect, it does a lot of things very well. First, the game puts you on edge, and keeps you there for the duration of the game, the graphical style as a whole is also charming, I really like the designs of the spirits. The gameplay boils down to exploring the town, while learning about and evading the different types of spirits. Now, fair warning, you'll be dying a lot while trying to do this, and at times it can be frustrating, but in my opinion it's quite satisfying once you've figured things out. The story is fine, nothing to write home about but its a good excuse for an adventure. Overall a very solid horror game for about 4.5 hours, as long as the gameplay loop I've described doesn't sound awful to you.

analysis_results.chunk: Yomawari Night Alone is a survival horror game that takes place in a regular Japanese town.
While the game is by no means perfect, it does a lot of things very well.
First, the game puts you on edge, and keeps you there for the duration of the game, the graphical style as a whole is also charming, I really like the designs of the spirits.
The gameplay boils down to exploring the town, while learning about and evading the different types of spirits.
Now, fair warning, you'll be dying a lot while trying to do this, and at times it can be frustrating, but in my opinion it's quite satisfying once you've figured things out.
The story is fine, nothing to write home about but its a good excuse for an adventure.
Overall a very solid horror game for about 4.5 hours, as long as the gameplay loop I've described doesn't sound awful to you.

original_text: I'm not fully sure why I enjoy this game as it's a very difficult and unfair game.  I suppose it has to do with the exploring and creepiness of it.  The graphics are both charming and creepy.  Most of the spirits in the game are related to Japanese myths.  If you enjoy movies like Studio Gibli's Spirited Away then the ambiance of this game is might be right up your alley.  However, be aware that you are going to die a lot in this game and probably have a few rage quits along the way. If this doesn't bother you, then I highly recommend checking this game out.  Also another thing, I personally thought it was best played with a controller.  I've been playing it with an Xbox One controller.

analysis_results.chunk: I'm not fully sure why I enjoy this game as it's a very difficult and unfair game.
I suppose it has to do with the exploring and creepiness of it.
The graphics are both charming and creepy.
Most of the spirits in the game are related to Japanese myths.
If you enjoy movies like Studio Gibli's Spirited Away then the ambiance of this game is might be right up your alley.
However, be aware that you are going to die a lot in this game and probably have a few rage quits along the way.
If this doesn't bother you, then I highly recommend checking this game out.
Also another thing, I personally thought it was best played with a controller.
I've been playing it with an Xbox One controller.

original_text: So, after 53 hours of "gameplay", I completed 100% of this game. Well, the game lasts for like 6-8 hours depends on your pace, and a couple more hours if you want to go around collecting what you missed. And that's it. To be honest, I find the last achievement pretty ridiculous, and you have to save your progress in the game, even if you just idle inside the house, if you want your playtime registered since the game doesn't want to take Steam playtime. But still, the game is decent, there's no soundtrack, so you really have the feel of a little child wandering in the dark, the mechanic is okay (you'll need to manage your stamina if you want to survive in encounters). Over all, I find it pretty enjoyable. If you are attracted by the cute artstyle, and the horror elements fit you, then give it a try. I got this game on sale and it's definitely worth what I paid for.

To be honest, I find the last achievement pretty ridiculous, and you have to save your progress in the game, even if you just idle inside the house, if you want your playtime registered since the game doesn't want to take Steam playtime.

But still, the game is decent, there's no soundtrack, so you really have the feel of a little child wandering in the dark, the mechanic is okay (you'll need to manage your stamina if you want to survive in encounters).
Over all, I find it pretty enjoyable.
If you are attracted by the cute artstyle, and the horror elements fit you, then give it a try.
I got this game on sale and it's definitely worth what I paid for.

original_text:
Please let there be a third of this beautiful game, it is such an original and fun concept.

Visuals are gorgeous, music is good, story is simple yet effective, the monsters you find and locations are both interesting and well made, really its a shame it doesnt last 9999 hours.

My only complaints are that the stamina bar is literally useless when you are scared, and there are 2 enemies in the whole game that are just too cheap so they suck the fun out for the brief period they are with you.

Just get this game and the sequel already.

Had some very annoying experiences with how to flee with some enemies and an instance of a very cheap placement of enemies in an area.
Overall very satisfying game to play and would rec to anyone who has played other horror rpgmaker games like Ib, witches house or yume nikki.

original_text:
I want to make readers aware, I have played this game on my vita for several hours. For me I could not get behind the mouse and keyboard controls. I'm sure I could have tried a controller but having this game in handheld format is awesome.

Would I recommend this game? Yes. However, I can only recommend this for atmospheric, horror enthusiast. You are defenseless in this game. While I generally don't buy into the idea that the only way to be scared is being defenseless, Yomawari makes it work. Several moments of the game are filled with tension. Sometimes just slightly slipping away from a spirit is a rush. The atmosphere this game sets out to create is so well done and that alone makes the game for me.

I enjoy the simplicity of the story without giving too much way it is about youth coming to terms with mortality. The tutorial is great opening to the game and subverts expectations in such a great way. The game play is simple, but it works with the set up. Anyone who considers themselves a big horror fan should pick this up. I loved the experience this game gave me.

I enjoy the simplicity of the story without giving too much way it is about youth coming to terms with mortality.
The tutorial is great opening to the game and subverts expectations in such a great way.
The game play is simple, but it works with the set up.
Anyone who considers themselves a big horror fan should pick this up.
I loved the experience this game gave me.

original_text:
Cute, scary, but not so scary that you have to put it down and come back to it. It takes more than a single night to finish, but it isn't really long. There are certainly jump scares as well as build up horror. Fear of the "unknown" is a constant thing. Though there is a ton of japanese spiritual reference spliced into all the horror, so you can guess how some spirits will attack based on that understanding. Cute, scary, and bewildering story that leaves you assuming what the world actually is.

I'd recommend this to people who want a gentler scare than games like Amnesia or Outlast.

original_text:
I've played many compelling and immersive games from Witcher 3, Skyrim, Shadow of Mordor but this game takes the cake for me. This game hit me spot on.

[ SPOILER ALERT ]
 
I have a dog and I love them, and I felt really sad when her dog died. You can feel her sadness in game.
I have a sister, and when she lost her sister in game, all I had on my mind was finding her sister. I just had to find her, look for her with everything I got, take risks for the sake of her sister and when in the end she was finally reunited with her sister I was very happy. When her eye popped, all I said to myself was: "If that's the price I had to pay, I don't mind as long as her sister is safe". 

This game is really something. I would always remember this game. Kudos to the devs who made this game.

original_text:
This game is REALLY fricken good... and then you hit the factory level. Where all they do is spam enemies at you rather than any meaningful design like earlier parts. So your constantly having to be out of stamina from running away and anything you try and pick up has the random chance of something just walking into you.On top of that, they pull a SUPER dick move and on the longest level in the game at that point, they make it so you can EASILY MISS THE KEY TO PROGRESS. The Best part? They shut off fast travel. So you can't just travel back to check and for me, I already saved at the jizo RIGHT OUTSIDE THE DOOR THAT NEEDS THE KEY. So pretty much im having to slog back through the whole poorly thought out level only to die and have to go all the way back. Its the very definition of tedious. haven't gotten past that part yet. (and haven't gone back to it to try it again)﻿ 
   As long as you don't miss the key earlier in the level, i doubt it would be nearly as frustrating. That being said, It's still a fantastic game with an amazing sense of atomosphere, understanding of true psychological horror, and some utterly depressing and emotional moments. So it's still getting a recommendation from me, but it definitely has hurt my experience with it.

original_text:
I recommend this game but only for a very certian group what like creepy design and exploring and only if the game is cheaper. Overall its a ok game not bad or very good. But has many flaws that makes it not easy to recommend.

First a VERY BIG WARNING about the saving mechanic. There are quick saves (inside the town after praying) and normal saves(at home). The quick saves are only check points not saves. If you leave the game without going back home(use map and teleport home) you will lose all your progress. Then going back home a message appear saving you will lose your quick save progress, this you can ignore because its just reset your check point but if you go to any statue inside the town you can fast travel between them.

The main focus of the game is exploring the town and understand the mechanics of the spirit's to overcome some of the obstruction. Most of the time you will just walk/run around the town without much clues and try to avoid the spirit's. If this sounds boring for you, then avoid the game.

There is no combat or "real" death inside the game. If you die you be teleport to your last check point or back home and keep all items you found. 

For the story it's starts good but you can fast lose interest in it and most of the stuff you can tell what will happend already much earlier in the game.

There is not much music in this game but it has a good sound background.

A good thing is that the map is much bigger then i expected and the design and atmosphere is great and creepy.

The spirit's inside the game have a very interesting design and there a lot of types some more command others can be found only on one spot.

Saddly the game has a lot of cheap kills(you can't see your character behind some buildings and also get stuck on corners) and jump scars and this gets at some areas a bit annoying.

Beside all this I had at the beginning a small bug in chapter 0/1 where the map will not load correctly and you see just a blank area. From chapter 2 onwards i didn't encounter it anymore.

original_text:
This is a very, very, VERY hesistant recommend. I LOVE what I've played so far but the game just can't help but crash, crash, and crash. That wouldn't normally be too awful in this day and age of constant, save anywhere games. But Yomawari isn't like that. In Yomawari you can quicksave at Jizo Statues, with coins. Jizo Statues act as automatic repawn points and you can warp to and from ones that you've unlocked. Any keys or items that you find persist between deaths, which is also great. Jizo Statue quicksaves however, are what I'll call a "soft save" and don't persist if, for example, the game crashes...which it likes to do frequently, and for no real reason.

It is really, REALLY inconvenient when it crashes, leading to you having to repeat content repeatedly if it keeps crashing before you can do a "hard save" which you can only seem to do from chapter to chapter, or in your house, which you can't always access. I had to do the section at the school 6 times because the game kept crashing. By the end I was so damn good at that section that I can pretty much speed run it from the house to the end in a few minutes, which is sad. 

The repeated crashing ruins what is otherwise a pretty creepy and amazing game. The atmosphere and sound is out of this world. And the yokai designs are pretty creepy. This definitnely isn't one for people who aren't a fan of games where you die in one hit (Misao, Mad Father, Ao Oni), but it's still a great game. But the crashing, oh the crashing. Don't get this game if you're on Windows 10, unless you're extremely patient and willing to redo sections over sometimes because the developers don't seem intent on fixing the crashing problem. I've read the discussion forum and the reccommended fix was to switch to Windows 98 compatability mode, which did fix the crashing, but then the game ran at 15 fps and gave me a massive headache.

Tl;dr: Half a thumb up? 
Good game
Repeated crashing leads to repeated frustration due to having to repeat content which leads to repetitiveness.
Buy hesitantly.

PS. Also not mentioned in the review but there seem to be this strange effect going on with the streets ingame which looks a bit like screen tearing? Is that intentional or just shoddy programming?

original_text:
I played this at release but never left a review but I gotta admit, it was pretty good.  Highly recommend it to horror fans, even if you don't particularly enjoy japanese or anime type games. 

PROs
 - It's got some real weird ass ghosts
 - Environmental audio really sold the atmosphere with very little text.
 - Puzzles kept the game engaging despite simple mechanics
 - As soon as you understand a ghost type's mechanics theres a new unknown horror to learn to avoid
 - Anime themes without being obnoxious.

CONs
 - Some of the puzzles can get frustrating due to how difficult it can be to get around. 
 - Some of the ghost types are a bit rediculous (industrial park) and might require a guide to get around.
 - It's pretty scary so you might not want to play it
 - Usually no point in the hide system since it's easier and more time effiicient to walk away

original_text:
Yomawari: night alone puts you in the role of a young girl searching for her missing dog and sister. You get to explore a creepy town thats full of ghosts and ghouls [strike] and cats	[/strike] while trying to find out where your sister went..

The Game does a great job at building the athmosphere with the visuals and the awesome sound design. Exploring the different parts of the town feels just the right ammount of creepy and exciting and makes you wanna unravel more of the story and find all the secrets that are lurking in the dark... 
The Story itself isnt anything too crazy but it does a solid job for what it is.

One thing i didnt like about the game all that much was the behaviour of the monsters.
How to deal with them felt a little too similar making some of the gameplay a bit repetitive towards the end in my opinion.

Other than that i cant find anything i didnt enjoy about the game. If you look for a cute looking horror game this one is definitly woth giving a try.

original_text:
I expected this game to be about the contrast between the extremely cute and the horrific, but Yomawari does much more with it than just juxtaposition. It is, at every level, the journey of an innocent little girl, at the age where everything in drawn in crayons and you don't really understand anything about the world, through fear, pain, and death. It's not the darkest game out there, but it's definitely pretty damn grim for a game where you are a cute lil' girl.

[u]Art style[/u]
The ghosts are really creative, and if you're into horror for of the grotesque and creative aesthetics, Yomawari delivers. Hallucinations are few and far between, but most creatures are a treat of Japanese horror.

[u]Gameplay/horror[/u]
You know this problem horror games have when they're scary the first hours and it progressively de-escalates as you become familiar with the game? Yomawari is different. It's not really a survival game, in the sense that you're going to die, easily and a lot, but it's rarely very punishing. It is in essence a die-and-retry. But while it never really inspires dread, the gameplay makes it tense, consistently and until the end. The only thing you can do against the spirits is avoiding them. Stealth very rarely works, you have to zip past them. Only, the game gives you a limited stamina bar, which depletes faster and faster the closest you get to a ghost. What this means is that you generally have juuuuust enough time and stamina to dodge the spirits. It's actually pretty neatly calibrated, and it makes it so that basically you can never feel safe. Especially not with those nasty ghosts that come rushing at you for behind. You probably won't be scared, but you will be on edge.

[u]Content[/u]
That's of course the weak spot of the game, a short four hours to finish the main story, with optional events and collectibles scattered across the map, with a free roam mode to get them all after the story ends.

Overall, plenty to like if you like sad, tense games and J-horror aesthetics.

What this means is that you generally have juuuuust enough time and stamina to dodge the spirits.

Especially not with those nasty ghosts that come rushing at you for behind.

Overall, plenty to like if you like sad, tense games and J-horror aesthetics.

original_text: Cute and Horror? An odd combination, indeed. However, they managed it very well. The main goal of rescuing her sister wasn't the main highlight for me; It was the lore behind the ghosts you'll come across while playing the game. Those are based on actual Japanese horror folk stories. The gameplay was amazing, and rather brutal because you'll be holding and spamming the sprint button more often than not, especially when you know it won't work when you actually need it. Oh, the rage.

original_text:
This game is one of my favorite horror games of all time <3 If you enjoy japanese urban legends and creepy yokai this game is for you. The atmosphere reminds me of the beginning of "Spirited Away" when it gets dark and spirits start to appear.  
It also has a great soundtrack and the sounddesign is an important part of the gameplay mechanics. 
This game can be challenging but its not unfair and it gives you the chance to learn from your mistakes.
The controls are fine with a controller but I wouldn't recommend playing it with mouse and keyboard.
The only thing that bothers me is that the game crashs often when you tab out.

First Impression
So Far, I've played 2Hours and just finished the 2nd chapter. For the 15$ I payed on Humble bundle store, I feel like even the 20$ Pricetag isn't unreasonable.
And it provides a challenge because you can play with One Hand.

original_text:
The game is great. Graphics and characters are cute and they make the game less scary.  The content of the game really corresponds to what it is said in the promotion video: Every adult was once a child, and the game reminds you of what we,a as adults now and children in the past, used to be afraid of: the darkness and the things that may exist in the darkness. Throughout the game you will feel scared and hopeless, just like you yourself is a little girl who are lost and looking for your family (The heartbeat sound effect is awesome!).

The only shortage of the game is that it's short, which makes it unworthy to pay HK$119 (aroung 12 Euro) for it. I would recommend buying the game only when it is on sale. The other problem is that some events and items are closely related to Japanese traditions, which foreigners, especially Western foreigners, may find it difficult to understand.

original_text:
I was expecting Little Nightmares from this game and got Scooby Doo Night of 100 Frights. 

I was not disappointed.

My wife’s boyfriend says Gylt is like the kids version of Allan Wake.. but instead of dealing with the anxiety of being overburdened by those looking up to you... this covers depression and bullying.

It reminded me of a Silent Hill game--fear and guilt manifesting as monsters---but for kids. But fun enough for adults as well.

Gylt is one of the best horror games I’ve played in years- not the scariest, but one of the most thoughtful. The level design and puzzles, the story (collect things!! Lots of story with collectibles!) it all comes together really well. Gylt was right up my alley: creepy, stealthy and somehow still kind of cute. The message is so strong... so many little details. It is just creepy enough to satisfy an adult and is suitable for a kid as well. Gylt plays like a lite version of many stealth and horror games wrapped in a theme of bullying. You play as a child called Sally who ends up in a twisted and surreal version of her town overrun with monsters while she's looking for missing cousin Emily. You sneak around monsters and distract with them tools like a flash-light or throwing soda cans. You explore well designed environments solving puzzles and finding collectibles that flesh out the story. The art style sorta reminds of that Coraline movie.

It plays like a kid friendly version of Resident Evil 2, not scary but spooky sometimes and definitely creepy. The main subject of the game (bullying) can also affect people deeply if you’ve suffered from it while younger (wich was my case to an extent). StillI highly appreciated how the theme of bullying is so incorporated. For example, I liked how the monsters' main attacks are pushing Sally and screeching at her (not sure how using the flashlight to stop them fits into the metaphor though). Or how the paintings, environments and diaries reflect how Emily has been bullied. It’s very good - but - half of the story is told through collectibles. They’re so important you can even go back into your game after beating it to continue collecting. Because it’s a short game, I’d definitely recommend trying to collect everything while playing it!

I dislike that a lot of reviews say “Gylt is great but does nothing new.” It doesn’t need to do anything new. It’s offering a classic, masterful horror game experience in a package accessible to kids! It’s a good and short game (unlocking the last ending will take a bit of extra work though) with great visuals, and I highly recommend it.

8/10

analysis_results.chunk: I was expecting Little Nightmares from this game and got Scooby Doo Night of 100 Frights.
I was not disappointed.
My wife’s boyfriend says Gylt is like the kids version of Allan Wake.. but instead of dealing with the anxiety of being overburdened by those looking up to you... this covers depression and bullying.
It reminded me of a Silent Hill game--fear and guilt manifesting as monsters---but for kids.
But fun enough for adults as well.
Gylt is one of the best horror games I’ve played in years- not the scariest, but one of the most thoughtful.
The level design and puzzles, the story (collect things!!
Lots of story with collectibles!) it all comes together really well.
Gylt was right up my alley: creepy, stealthy and somehow still kind of cute.
The message is so strong... so many little details.
It is just creepy enough to satisfy an adult and is suitable for a kid as well.
Gylt plays like a lite version of many stealth and horror games wrapped in a theme of bullying.
You play as a child called Sally who ends up in a twisted and surreal version of her town overrun with monsters while she's looking for missing cousin Emily.
You sneak around monsters and distract with them tools like a flash-light or throwing soda cans.
You explore well designed environments solving puzzles and finding collectibles that flesh out the story.
The art style sorta reminds of that Coraline movie.
It plays like a kid friendly version of Resident Evil 2, not scary but spooky sometimes and definitely creepy.
The main subject of the game (bullying) can also affect people deeply if you’ve suffered from it while younger (wich was my case to an extent).
StillI highly appreciated how the theme of bullying is so incorporated.
For example, I liked how the monsters' main attacks are pushing Sally and screeching at her (not sure how using the flashlight to stop them fits into the metaphor though).
Or how the paintings, environments and diaries reflect how Emily has been bullied.
It’s very good - but - half of the story is told through collectibles.
They’re so important you can even go back into your game after beating it to continue collecting.
Because it’s a short game, I’d definitely recommend trying to collect everything while playing it!
I dislike that a lot of reviews say “Gylt is great but does nothing new.” It doesn’t need to do anything new.
It’s offering a classic, masterful horror game experience in a package accessible to kids!
It’s a good and short game (unlocking the last ending will take a bit of extra work though) with great visuals, and I highly recommend it. 8/10

original_text:
GYLT is an adorable game that burdens itself with an incorrect message. 

The mechanics are great, game play is fun, story is enjoyable except one vital flaw.
[spoiler] You cannot control other people and if you could it would only make you the bully. The game puts too much emphasis on caring about what others say and do. The message is incorrect in how to handle bullying, as you do not find resolution by policing others or relying on their validation. There will always be those who are mean or even brutal. If you cannot handle this, then the problem is fixed by looking inward. Raising a little girl, I taught her to see her own value instead of caring about what mean kids said to her. I did not give her the idea that their words had weight that should be thought on. Her bully in first grade gave up bullying her, because it had no impact. Bullies are the way they are because they themselves are broken. No need to be broken along side. As such, this is not a good message in this game, as it puts way too much emphasis that hopelessness is without someone else lifting you up. Embracing sensitivity will only make the person more fragile to those who are mean. [/spoiler]

In all, the game is a lot of fun and cute. I recommend it as entertainment, not for its message.

original_text:
Babys first survival horror. Originally a Stadia exclusive, that got a second chance and for the most part it delivers. It's sort of a more kid friendly Alan Wake (mixed with some Silent Hill, if it was made by Tim Burton, where you explore a nightmarish version of your school, in search for your missing cousin. 

It's a very forgiving and casual survival horror overall, you will never run out of batteries (your way to defeat enemies) or health since they are all over the place, the enemies will quickly lose interest in you if you run and hide and you will pretty much always have everything maxed and still have half a dozen more to pick up if things go south, and honestly it seldom does. The enemies are seldom a threat and you can dispatch or avoid them pretty easily. It's pretty much only the bosses that will give you any challenge at all, and even they are pretty easy when you understand the mechanics. This is not a bad thing, it's probably a very good first introduction to the genre, just don't expect to be challanged if you are a veteran.

The amount of collectibles in each area are also clearly marked, and if you are close enough they will be marked in the map. Just make sure you collect everything before the "point of no return", because the only good ending require that you have found and saved all "Inhabitants", otherwise you are given a choice between one depressing and one awful ending that are both pretty horrible, and kind of goes against the theme of the game. I kind of hate when games does that, when the "secret" ending is the true ending. But overall, a few missteps aside, Gylt is a pretty solid game. Happy that it got a second chance after Stadia.

original_text:
[b] [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/31067175///] If you enjoy this review please consider following my Curator page here. [/url] [/b]

GYLT is the latest game from Tequila Works (of Deadlight and RiME fame), that thrusts you into the role of Sally, a young girl looking for her lost cousin Emily. The game takes place in a town where everyone has vanished, save for the monsters that roam the streets and inhabit the buildings. The gameplay is a mix of stealth and puzzle adventure, with elements heavily inspired by Alan Wake with the use of a flashlight against enemies and more often running or hiding from enemies than facing them head on. I found some of the monster designs to be pretty good and there’s a couple legitimate creepy moments in the game. I’d also like to highlight the game's use of light as an indicator of where to proceed next, which felt organic in the sense that it wasn’t holding my hand but I also never felt lost as to where to go.

I found that the story and messaging had their heart in the right place, if not a bit wrought. I enjoyed my time with GYLT, and while it did not bring a ton of new ideas to the table, I think it executed what it set out to do fairly well. While I’m not sure I’d recommend this at full price, I think it should definitely be on everyone’s radar during a sale.

original_text:
This is a really good game. The level design and the graphics are good. The performance is excellent. I had all the settings maxed and stayed above 130 fps. No skips or stutters, no loading screens. I usually don't like stealth. But the devs realize that in order for stealth to be good, the enemies have to be a little "dumb". Yes the A.I knows where you are, but they have cues that will make them attack. Cues like running, your flashlight or if they actually see you. In other games you can be 50 ft away, dead still behind cover and they'll go "I heard something". That type of stealth isn't fun imo.

Combat isn't bad. It would be better if she had a stick or something. I'd like to be able to jump. Without spoiling the game, why'd I do all of this to help, and I stay behind. The other option would be worse. 

There's a camera transition that made me think I fell off the platform. And there's a unique camera angle that was fun once I realized I wasn't the enemy.

This is worth the money.

original_text:
[i] My Experience [/i]

Although I remember seeing something about this game back when it released on Stadia, I really didn't pay very much attention to it. At long last, following [b]Orcs Must Die 3[/b] (another Stadia exclusive that I didn't get to until much later), [b]Gylt[/b] has finally arrived on Steam. And it's pretty good!

I tend to enjoy most stealth games, so perhaps I'm already the target audience for this type of thing. As usual in stealth games, your protagonist Sally can hide in shadows and distract enemies. Taking on many enemies at once is a bad idea. The enemy awareness meter, although simple, is sufficient. 

The game has this cool Alan Wake-style light vs. dark thing going on, where Sally has a flashlight that she can focus to "burn" 2-3 particular spots on an enemy to dispatch them. She also has a "flash" that recharges over time that she can use to stun enemies. She can also jam the flashlight into the backs of most enemies to instantly destroy them. However, both her flashlight executions and flashlight focus eat a lot of battery power. Luckily, there are batteries absolutely everywhere, and the ones that you don't pick up are marked on your map. An odd aspect here is the game's insistence on telling you exactly what you can do with batteries (and inhalers) do every single time you pick them up. You'll get quite a bit of exposure to these tooltips.

The aforementioned inhalers heal Sally, and these are also all over the place (and marked on your map). I'm not even sure I can recall a time when I had less than four inhalers (Sally can carry a maximum of five). Although the batteries and inhalers could have introduced a bit of a survival horror aspect to the game, [b]Gylt[/b] just isn't difficult enough to create this tension in the player. What's odd here is that you later get a fire extinguisher that, although it requires time to recharge, never actually runs out of whatever compound is inside. This can be used not only to extinguish fires (duh), but can also help you solve puzzles, navigate through steam leaks, and freeze enemies!

Don't get me wrong - there's still a lot to enjoy here. I thought the shadow version of Bethelwood and the school environments were compelling and lovingly crafted, and I enjoyed this "Silent Hill 2 for kids" vibe that the game had going on. The game is ostensibly about the bullying of Sally's little cousin Emily, and the enemies say amusing things like "I smell loser!" to drive this point home. Certain doors are also locked with these eyeball stalks that follow Sally around, which seem to echo Emily's feeling that everyone is always looking at her/judging her.

Another aspect of the game that I loved were the "inhabitants." From time to time, Sally will locate a ball of something called "blood quartz." She can use this blood quartz, one for one, to free individuals in the shadow town that have been turned to stone. These individuals have been trapped in the town, and upon their release Sally is rewarded with a diary entry that explains the circumstances that led to their gorgon-ification.

Unfortunately, this brings me to the aspect of the game that I liked the least - the ending. Gylt is one of these games that features multiple endings. Whether you receive ending 1 or 2 depends only on what choice you make at the end, while ending 3 requires you to [spoiler]have located all 10 of the inhabitants and freed them. The issue here is that some of these inhabitants are quite well hidden. To find one in particular, you'll have to hit the button in an elevator to take you to a different floor, jump out before the doors close, and crouch beneath to fall into the elevator shaft! If I were to play the game upon release, when no guides had been written, there is no way that I would've located that inhabitant.

Ending 3 allows both girls to leave. This means that I would be stuck with ending 1 or 2, which just seem unbelievably harsh to me. With these endings, only one of the girls is able to make it home, Sally or Emily. And the game strongly suggests that it should be Sally that stays. When Emily was bullied (prior to the events of the game), Sally was dismissive and didn't take up for her. Granted this is unfortunate, but is developer Tequila Works suggesting that this emotionally immature 11 year-old girl should be stranded in what is essentially Silent Hill as a result? An old man that helps both Sally & Emily comments, "Sally, you know why you're here. Give Emily your ticket. Make things right." Make things right!? And as Emily leaves, Sally comments: "I wish I'd been a better cousin." This is...uh...past tense, signifying that Sally may indeed be in dark Bethelwood for the long haul.[/spoiler]

So, I can recommend Gylt for the environments, puzzles, enemy designs and gameplay, but not for the fact that it implicitly suggests that [spoiler] an 11 year-old girl should be turned to stone and trapped in the shadow realm.[/spoiler] I had a much higher overall opinion of the game prior to the ending, but still came out of it with a net positive impression.

original_text:
Game Review:

SPOILER ALERT! THIS REVIEW CONTAINS EXAMPLES FROM THE GAME! DO NOT CONTINUE READING IF YOU DON'T WISH TO KNOW THEM BEFORE PLAYING!

1. Setting & Theme: The dark, gloomy autmosphere of the game really helped with the overall experience. It was well-made and did include details to express the theme of one's past and the expression of being bullied. As someone who has been bullied in school, and as someone who saw others get bullied, I felt a stab in my chest at some parts of the game, be it if I collected diary entries or if I watches the design of the game; Mean writings on the walls and the wooden dolls depicting acts of bullying. Still, having stuff such as fully functional soda machines did feel a little comical at times. 8.5/10 stars.

2.Gameplay: While using inhalers to heal and fighting monsters with a flashlight and a fire extinguisher (which somehow freezes enemies solid) was a fun concept, the game felt pretty easy once you've gotten the option to really FIGHT back. Some elements that make horror games immersive and exciting is the risk of danger and death. It was pretty good at first, but after you've gotten the upgraded flashlight, you could just pretty much stand and fight most enemies with ease, barely even dodging or running away from them since they stumble after detroying each weakspot. While having the option to kill enemies isn't bad, it should come at a risk of sort (for example, if the flashlight were to overheat or consume more light, that would make players think twice before they just decide to kill everything). Without such risk, and with the game having no difficulty settings, it felt dull at times. Not to mention that stealth-killing an enemy consumes around 30% of your battery, while killing an enemy head-on - only about 5%. Don't bother sneaking around, since you can just kill most of them. Some of the boss fights were also, to be blunt, quite lame, especially the one at the auditorium. You could bath in that monster's light for 10 seconds before actually being in danger. If you've just finished Amnesia: The bunker on hard mode and are looking for a similar nightmarish, challenging gameplay experience, this game might not be for you. 6.5/10 stars. 

Story: I knew what I was getting to after reading the into message, but the story was pretty straight forward. Bullying has been around for many years now, be it in games or movies. The only real major twist that was experienced was the fact that Sally (the protagonist) was ALSO mean to Emily, at least by being ignorant. This is also something that you can only know if You've discovered the underground secret room. And speaking of secrets, discovering the diaries from the people who died down there explains some lore about the mining company and how people lost their mind while digging there. Even after reading all the diaries, I still have many questions as to how that parallel universe works? And how do the big bosses (who are named after emotions and feelings that one would experience while being bullied) change depending on the person? Sally wasn't the only one there, so how do the rest of the people see it? 7/10 stars.

4. replayability and length: The game's length justified its price. With no difficulty settings, no post-story challenges and secrets, your depended on getting all collectibles in the game to play at your fullest. And while the game does have different endings, only one of them had a special condition of getting all the ticket pieces, which you can actually do even after completing the main storyline through an option in the main menu. Imagine if the game itself has choices that affected the ending, This could have made people actually replay the game just to find out how to get them (or at least how to make a video online guiding others). 7/10 stars.

Overall, I would reccommand this game. I had fun with it, but after getting all collectibles and knowing there is nothing left after, I'll be moving on to the next title.

analysis_results.chunk: Game Review: SPOILER ALERT!
THIS REVIEW CONTAINS EXAMPLES FROM THE GAME!
DO NOT CONTINUE READING IF YOU DON'T WISH TO KNOW THEM BEFORE PLAYING! 1.
Setting & Theme: The dark, gloomy autmosphere of the game really helped with the overall experience.
It was well-made and did include details to express the theme of one's past and the expression of being bullied.

As someone who has been bullied in school, and as someone who saw others get bullied, I felt a stab in my chest at some parts of the game, be it if I collected diary entries or if I watches the design of the game; Mean writings on the walls and the wooden dolls depicting acts of bullying.

Still, having stuff such as fully functional soda machines did feel a little comical at times. 8.5/10 stars. 2.Gameplay: While using inhalers to heal and fighting monsters with a flashlight and a fire extinguisher (which somehow freezes enemies solid) was a fun concept, the game felt pretty easy once you've gotten the option to really FIGHT back.
Some elements that make horror games immersive and exciting is the risk of danger and death.

It was pretty good at first, but after you've gotten the upgraded flashlight, you could just pretty much stand and fight most enemies with ease, barely even dodging or running away from them since they stumble after detroying each weakspot.
