Without such risk, and with the game having no difficulty settings, it felt dull at times.
Not to mention that stealth-killing an enemy consumes around 30% of your battery, while killing an enemy head-on - only about 5%.
Don't bother sneaking around, since you can just kill most of them.
Some of the boss fights were also, to be blunt, quite lame, especially the one at the auditorium.
You could bath in that monster's light for 10 seconds before actually being in danger.
If you've just finished Amnesia: The bunker on hard mode and are looking for a similar nightmarish, challenging gameplay experience, this game might not be for you. 6.5/10 stars.
Story: I knew what I was getting to after reading the into message, but the story was pretty straight forward.
Bullying has been around for many years now, be it in games or movies.
The only real major twist that was experienced was the fact that Sally (the protagonist) was ALSO mean to Emily, at least by being ignorant.
This is also something that you can only know if You've discovered the underground secret room.
And speaking of secrets, discovering the diaries from the people who died down there explains some lore about the mining company and how people lost their mind while digging there.
Even after reading all the diaries, I still have many questions as to how that parallel universe works?
And how do the big bosses (who are named after emotions and feelings that one would experience while being bullied) change depending on the person?
Sally wasn't the only one there, so how do the rest of the people see it? 7/10 stars. 4. replayability and length: The game's length justified its price.
With no difficulty settings, no post-story challenges and secrets, your depended on getting all collectibles in the game to play at your fullest.

And while the game does have different endings, only one of them had a special condition of getting all the ticket pieces, which you can actually do even after completing the main storyline through an option in the main menu.

Imagine if the game itself has choices that affected the ending, This could have made people actually replay the game just to find out how to get them (or at least how to make a video online guiding others). 7/10 stars.
Overall, I would reccommand this game.
I had fun with it, but after getting all collectibles and knowing there is nothing left after, I'll be moving on to the next title.

original_text:
If you are looking for a simple stealth game with good graphics, don't wait. Pick this up NOW..

Gylt was a Stadia (Yeah, that dead gaming concept) exclusive that moved over to everything after a short stent. You play a the older sister looking for your missing younger sister who just started going to the same school as you. For some reason, there is a parallel city that she was trapped in with several other town residents. 

If you are looking for a game with excellent graphics, I would not put this on the top of the list. Do not get me wrong, the graphics are great and the level of detail is outstanding. This game was not designed to look like Horizon Zero Dawn. The comical animated style brings a sense of childish wonder mixed with a terror of silent hill. Heavy attention was paid to when they designed the feel of the environments.

Moving over to the music. I will be short. It is simplistic to the point where it gets the atmosphere and tension where it needs to but no further. On the plus side, although repetitive, it is not overly loud nor is it annoying.  

Controls are simple. You pick up a few items that you would normally find at a school. These items will be used to clear pathways and deal with the monsters. As the game is more stealth than anything, usage will be more for traversing the multiple sections.

The game has multiple endings so there is room for additional play-throughs. 

In conclusion, if you have fatigue from all those hardcore games, definitely pick this up. It is not very long but have simple intuitive game-play with a satisfying story!

original_text:
Good- Well-written characters with compelling voicework; engaging atmosphere; mechanics are simple but enjoyable enough for the short runtime. 

Bad- The story needs to be fleshed out; the level design can be pretty linear, making puzzles easy; combat mechanics don't have much depth. 

Thoughts- Despite its many shortcomings, GYLT is a passable adventure that retained my interest throughout its campaign. Sure, the mechanics aren't anything new or particularly innovative – but they serve their purposes for the relatively short runtime of around six hours. The story also has an exciting premise but falters due to a barebones structure and poor pacing. GYLT might be worth a try if you find any of this interesting, but it's passable if you aren't particularly piqued by anything on offer.

Bad- The story needs to be fleshed out; the level design can be pretty linear, making puzzles easy; combat mechanics don't have much depth.
Thoughts- Despite its many shortcomings, GYLT is a passable adventure that retained my interest throughout its campaign.
Sure, the mechanics aren't anything new or particularly innovative – but they serve their purposes for the relatively short runtime of around six hours.
The story also has an exciting premise but falters due to a barebones structure and poor pacing.
GYLT might be worth a try if you find any of this interesting, but it's passable if you aren't particularly piqued by anything on offer.

original_text: ABSOLUTELY AMAZING! I was drawn to the game by the character design and Little Nightmare vibes, but this was no copy knock off this was a game true to itself. Puzzles and combat weren't hard so can be enjoyed by those who want to enjoy the story, maybe a hard mode update in future for those who want a challenge. The environments and characters were unique, accompanied with the music it made for a memorable experience - especially the creepy mannequins! There were a couple spelling errors in the diary notebooks and 2 of the achievements popped early but they are simple fixes. I'd love to see some DLC covering the background of the rock people or playing as Emily and her journey. 10/10

original_text: I love this game, probably best story driven, action, puzzle horror title so far this year, without counting all the remakes. Back tracking, puzzles, combat and world design are great. World feels twisted like Evil within or Little nightmares, combat is a bit more complex then Alan Wake. I would like if developers add difficulty so we get less batteries  or less hp recovery items. I was mostly maxed out most of the time.  Other then that this game is a breath of fresh air for a genre. 8/10

original_text: Wonderful little spooky stealth horror adventure game for all ages. If you're a fan of Alan Wake, Coraline, or Little Nightmares, chances are you will love this title. I adore the art style especially. Would love to possibly see an update that adds fully rendered cutscenes, as the still images kinda took me out of it every time they showed up, but I also understand its an idie team and its not really a big issue at all. I won't spoil anything, but great art, great story, great music, and great gameplay. I absolutely see myself returning to this every once n a while for a long time.

original_text: Wow. Immersive, creative, creepy, exhilarating, heart-breaking, mind-bending, wow. Difficult enough to provide the player with a decent challenge, but not nearly break-your-controller frustrating (aka, good for novice/intermediate players). Solid depth of lore/backstory, complex enough to not quite get it off the rip (had to watch an explanation video afterwards but just to tie a few pieces together that I didn't catch on to- Pay close enough attention while playing and you will). Been compared to Alan Wake, which I have not played so I can't say, but figured I'd mention it in case that helps anyone else. Took me quite a few hours to complete, although I would put myself in the novice/intermediate category of player, as mentioned previously. Overall, definitely worth the money, great experience, would highly recommend.

Immersive, creative, creepy, exhilarating, heart-breaking, mind-bending, wow.
Difficult enough to provide the player with a decent challenge, but not nearly break-your-controller frustrating (aka, good for novice/intermediate players).

Solid depth of lore/backstory, complex enough to not quite get it off the rip (had to watch an explanation video afterwards but just to tie a few pieces together that I didn't catch on to- Pay close enough attention while playing and you will).
Been compared to Alan Wake, which I have not played so I can't say, but figured I'd mention it in case that helps anyone else.
Took me quite a few hours to complete, although I would put myself in the novice/intermediate category of player, as mentioned previously.
Overall, definitely worth the money, great experience, would highly recommend.

original_text:
If you like smaller games you can actually finish with a interesting story with a Tim Burton-esque Carolina feel to it, this might be the game for you.

Now it certainly feels like a game aimed at younger children, especially given the moral of the story and the difficulty. Realistically, anyone should be able to finish this, as the resources are anything but sparse, and it's very forgiving even if you do slip up.

The collectibles are important for the story, but even if you miss out on those its not like you have to start an entirely new game or anything.

original_text:
So far the game has been quite the experience. I am not normally one for scary games so I thought I'd dive in on this one since it didn't seem as scary on the outside. It does however have a certain unnerving quality to it and I think the people who made it have done a very good job in regards to that. 

If I had one actual gripe with the game it would be that it isn't very good on power usage and you can't actually turn OFF the Post Processing. Something a lot of newer games seem to have, but also takes a large toll on people's hardware.

Would I recommend the game? Yes. Is it streamable? Not really unless you have a very and I mean VERY good computer.

original_text:
Enter a hauntingly beautiful world in 'Gylt', where fear and bravery intertwine in a mesmerizing tale. Developed by Tequila Works, this atmospheric adventure keeps you on the edge with its gripping storyline and immersive gameplay.

Embark on the journey of Sally, a courageous young girl exploring a mysterious, eerie town to find her missing cousin. The game seamlessly blends puzzle-solving with stealth mechanics, keeping you engaged at every turn.

The striking visual design coupled with a haunting soundtrack creates an ambiance that lingers, immersing you deeper into the narrative. 'Gylt' delivers a mix of emotions, from fear and tension to triumph and empowerment, leaving a lasting impression.

With its captivating narrative, atmospheric world, and compelling gameplay, 'Gylt' stands tall as a testament to the power of storytelling in gaming.

original_text:
The game has a great visual style, each location is unique and twisted by otherworldly forces to match the theme. The city at the end of the game, which is buried in a mountain, is especially successful.

Also worth noting is the last moment when a huge monster is chasing Sally and Emily, and the camera through which we are watching the characters moves into its mouth. The last time I saw something like this was in Rayman 2.

The gameplay is simple, and can be described as a walking simulator with stealth mechanics. Despite its simplicity, it was fun to throw cans at crows and mannequins, as well as freeze them with a fire extinguisher.

The game is short (6.5 hours for a full playthrough for the true ending and collecting all the collectibles), but I still enjoyed the game, and I also recommend you play it.

P.S.: It's a shame that Stadya's exclusivity essentially killed this good game, fortunately it didn't stay there forever and was ported to other platforms, but the damage had already been done.

The city at the end of the game, which is buried in a mountain, is especially successful.
Also worth noting is the last moment when a huge monster is chasing Sally and Emily, and the camera through which we are watching the characters moves into its mouth.
The last time I saw something like this was in Rayman 2.
The gameplay is simple, and can be described as a walking simulator with stealth mechanics.
Despite its simplicity, it was fun to throw cans at crows and mannequins, as well as freeze them with a fire extinguisher.
The game is short (6.5 hours for a full playthrough for the true ending and collecting all the collectibles), but I still enjoyed the game, and I also recommend you play it.
P.S.: It's a shame that Stadya's exclusivity essentially killed this good game, fortunately it didn't stay there forever and was ported to other platforms, but the damage had already been done.

original_text:
Gylt was a pleasant surprise to me. I initially thought it would be a game for children, but I was mistaken. Gylt showcases beautiful graphics with meticulous attention to detail in the art style that enhances the game's immersive nature and captivates players from start to finish. The search for Sally's missing cousin, Emily, drives the story forward, and the game successfully explores themes of guilt, fear, and friendship. The beautiful relationship between Sally and Emily is a significant aspect of Gylt, adding depth and emotional resonance to the game's narrative.

It's worth mentioning that Gylt is remarkably polished, no glitches or bugs, providing a smooth gameplay experience. Additionally, all achievements can be unlocked without any issues. Gylt offers three distinct endings, including two bad endings and one good ending. The game allows you to obtain these endings without replaying it entirely; you can return to the campus after completing the game to collect any remaining items.

The search for Sally's missing cousin, Emily, drives the story forward, and the game successfully explores themes of guilt, fear, and friendship.
The beautiful relationship between Sally and Emily is a significant aspect of Gylt, adding depth and emotional resonance to the game's narrative.
It's worth mentioning that Gylt is remarkably polished, no glitches or bugs, providing a smooth gameplay experience.
Additionally, all achievements can be unlocked without any issues.
Gylt offers three distinct endings, including two bad endings and one good ending.
The game allows you to obtain these endings without replaying it entirely; you can return to the campus after completing the game to collect any remaining items.

original_text:
I loved this game!
I played the whole game in one sitting (just under 6 hours first playthrough) and had to play more to get the collectables to get the secret ending.
The story, the graphics, level designs and gameplay mechanics were great. It was a good balance on everything.
Had an Alan Wake feel to it at some moments.

I know some people have gotten annoyed and complained about dead ends in the game, but they are usually people who don't really enjoy or go for collectables in games, which is what some of the dead ends in the games were.

If you use the map by looking in your backback with TAB, you can easily work out where you need to go next for the story or where you haven't been to find the missing keys etc for progression in the game.

original_text:
This is an interesting horror game, even though the art style is cartoonish/cute the subject matter is pretty heavy, as it deals with school bullying and the effects it has on children. Which is also what makes this game quite unique for a playthrough, because you dont see too many games touching on this subject of matter. 

Gameplay wise, this is a stealth action game, think an easier Metal Gear Solid. 

The story was what really kept me going, I was surprised by how polished this game is. 

Total game time is about 5 hrs 30 mins to 6 hours. I recommend this for someone who enjoys horror and interesting storyline.

original_text:
This was my favorite Stadia exclusive so I was really excited to see it finally come to other platforms. I picked it up the second it went live on the store and I do not regret it. 7.5 hours later and I've got 2 of 3 endings, all the collectibles, and just have 9 more achievements to wrap up.

To me, this game has a story that reminds me of Sea of Solitude, environments that remind of The Evil Within 1 & 2 with a little bit of Obscure thrown in, the cutscenes remind me of Deadlight (which was also by Tequila Works so that makes sense), and when you put all that together you get a fairly compelling horror game with a sad story. I really, really love this game. I loved it on Stadia and I love it even more now. I'm definitely going to buy the physical Collectors Edition for PS5 to add to my collection (the front of the CE looks like Sally's backpack !!!)

Anyway, I got off track a tiny bit with the physical there but if you like games like the ones I mentioned above, definitely check this out. It's got exploration, stealth, puzzles, a great story, etc. I really think you'll love it if you give it a chance.

original_text: Survival horror is indeed a very tricky genre to make, although there are many games in this genre. The only game alongside GYLT, that I will call true survival horror is Outlast. That being said, this is a very well made survival horror game and even defeating enemies requires stealth and a lot of thinking. But, I would say, each success is very rewarding. The game involves a lot of thinking and strategy and the experience is made to be very realistic. You can relate to your character and strategize. What do I mean by that? Here's a small example without spoiling much. In the arcade section, as you try to get to the room with two billiards boards (this room is the only way to get to the second floor, where your objective is), you will have to face against two monsters. The problem is, if you face against one of the monsters, you will end up alerting another one, even before you can kill, at least, one of them. Facing off against two monsters simultaneously is never recommended. They gang up and you will not survive. Your best option is to distract them and crawl very noiselessly to the next room. I used a soda can to distract the monster to cross over behind one of the arcade game machine. But, there are gaps between rows and one of the monsters' visual field goes straight up the the opening, because he's standing facing the opening. The other monster is walking to and fro and he's the only one who can block monster 1's field of vision. Also, his visual field is not directly facing the opening in front of my character. But, you can clearly see his side profile. That means, his peripheral vision can see me partially. It will, at most, make him suspicious of my presence, unless I quickly hide behind another arcade machine. In simple words, you have to take a gamble. You must cross to the next row of arcade machine, as long as monster 2 is blocking the field of vision of monster 1, despite there being a chance that, he might get suspicious of your hiding spot and that's the gamble I took. In that area, there are three monsters in total. I could only kill the third one and that too using stealth mechanics. I can relate to the game and I can relate to it, because the game designer made it as realistic as possible. I played many survival horror/puzzle horror game with stealth mechanics. In most cases, I can never understand the game, because many a times, no - most of the times, the game logic does not relate to real life logic, which is sad, considering, most players are real life people who employ real life logic most of the time. The game is also very well executed. Most games gives excuse of "I will not hold your hand". What does holding my hand means? Does providing a bit of explanation of how your games works automatically translates to holding hands? That's so stupid. Holding hands means literally telling the player where to go and what to interact with throughout the whole length of the game. Explaining the game mechanics to the player very elaborately is not holding hands. If anything, it makes the gameplay very enjoyable for the players aka the clients of the developers. I do not think Overwhelmingly Positive reviews are hard to attain. Some developers are simply conscientious and others are not so conscientious. They never cared if their game is going to be entertaining. They only saw their customers as cashcow or their game is made for a selected or specific group of people. Overwhelmingly Positive games are made for everybody, so that everybody enjoys their time with the game.

But, I would say, each success is very rewarding.

I used a soda can to distract the monster to cross over behind one of the arcade game machine.

Also, his visual field is not directly facing the opening in front of my character.
But, you can clearly see his side profile.
That means, his peripheral vision can see me partially.
It will, at most, make him suspicious of my presence, unless I quickly hide behind another arcade machine.
In simple words, you have to take a gamble.

You must cross to the next row of arcade machine, as long as monster 2 is blocking the field of vision of monster 1, despite there being a chance that, he might get suspicious of your hiding spot and that's the gamble I took.
In that area, there are three monsters in total.
I could only kill the third one and that too using stealth mechanics.

original_text:
Gylt is a good niche game: its got slight horror, puzzle, and combat along with  wonderful characters that gives a compelling people to root and feel sorry for. Only two characters have names in this game where as the rest our done in single entry journals that do a wonderful job in giving us a idea of what these nameless characters were like.

Monster design is quite nice and simple, there's not to much going on and it works for this game.





























Spoilers Ahead

































Bosses, while interesting, do not have proper boss fights. Only one boss is actually fought and you fight him twice. There are two others, a stealth boss and a escape boss. the stealth one you can just ignore stealth for the most part if you have the healing to get through.

There is a implied Fight or Stealth in most encounters but your resources are so plentiful that you would save yourself so much trouble by just fighting through everything.
My biggest gripe is that the true ending requires you to get at least three  complete sets of collectibles that require each other for completion.
I also hope that we can get a sequel to learn more about the dangers of the mountain and to either deal with them or bury them cause even though you escaped the evil the evil is still very much there. Its almost next door for crying out loud.

This is a game worthy of trying out, i played it do to seeing a little bit on Superhorrorbro so if the devs wanna get games like this known they should check out you-tubers who play specific types of games.

Monster design is quite nice and simple, there's not to much going on and it works for this game.
Spoilers Ahead Bosses, while interesting, do not have proper boss fights.
Only one boss is actually fought and you fight him twice.
There are two others, a stealth boss and a escape boss. the stealth one you can just ignore stealth for the most part if you have the healing to get through.

original_text:
People are drawing comparisons to Alan Wake and while I see it on a surface level, this isn't that at all. Nor is it as good as Alan Wake. 

- M+KB Lock-in is enabled by default. I don't think it is advisable to turn this off but then you lose some significant gameplay. Having it off also disables your crosshair from being red when aimed at a weakpoint so now you aren't sure what to "shoot"
- AI placement and detection is questionable. The distraction and detecting leaves me a little confused but that may just me not having enough time in the game. With the distraction soda can tutorial, the enemy is placed in a questionable position. I threw the can to distract it and hid further along its path. Where I hid, the monster can detect me and there are no soda cans around. Turns out I can just run to the door and it'll sense but not detect me, even though the placement, how its facing, and the indicator all showing that if I come out then I'm screwed. 
- The AI (I don't think) can't see anything past its "zone". If there is an enemy patroling a specific hallway, if you are in a connecting room and you can stare at him through the window without him caring. The environmental design people drew blinds right next to the window but left the window completely bare. 
- The environmental and level design in my opinion is the worst offender for it being made that way because "video game". Looks completely unnatural and out of place as an actual real world location. 
- Less said about the writing in the story, the better. The overarching story is interesting but the actual storytelling from the writing and the environment leave something to be desired.

I'm not entirely knowledgeable on the staff from Tequila Works but some of these issues seem to stem from a developer's first game. I know it's their first game as that studio label but not sure where Stadia got their employees from when they asked for this game.

analysis_results.chunk: People are drawing comparisons to Alan Wake and while I see it on a surface level, this isn't that at all.
Nor is it as good as Alan Wake. - M+KB Lock-in is enabled by default.
I don't think it is advisable to turn this off but then you lose some significant gameplay.
Having it off also disables your crosshair from being red when aimed at a weakpoint so now you aren't sure what to "shoot" - AI placement and detection is questionable.
The distraction and detecting leaves me a little confused but that may just me not having enough time in the game.
With the distraction soda can tutorial, the enemy is placed in a questionable position.
I threw the can to distract it and hid further along its path.
Where I hid, the monster can detect me and there are no soda cans around.

Turns out I can just run to the door and it'll sense but not detect me, even though the placement, how its facing, and the indicator all showing that if I come out then I'm screwed. - The AI (I don't think) can't see anything past its "zone".
If there is an enemy patroling a specific hallway, if you are in a connecting room and you can stare at him through the window without him caring.

The environmental design people drew blinds right next to the window but left the window completely bare. - The environmental and level design in my opinion is the worst offender for it being made that way because "video game".
Looks completely unnatural and out of place as an actual real world location. - Less said about the writing in the story, the better.
The overarching story is interesting but the actual storytelling from the writing and the environment leave something to be desired.
I'm not entirely knowledgeable on the staff from Tequila Works but some of these issues seem to stem from a developer's first game.
I know it's their first game as that studio label but not sure where Stadia got their employees from when they asked for this game.

original_text:
Optimization seems to be a bit bad.  While the game runs rather gracefully it certainly puts a lot of pull on the CPU which feels kind've strange.  Obviously based on my hours played here, I did not finish the game.  Ultimately the puzzle aspects left me scratching my head trying to figure out how to solve at times, and I didn't want to jump in and out of Youtube to try to figure them out.  I don't like puzzles, and I'm sure the game has some that aren't crazy difficult...  But, I can't spend a long amount of time struggling to figure them out because it leaves me not wanting to play anymore.

But what I did play, I really enjoyed.  Beautiful soundtrack, awesome locations and animations, and the story feels pretty good as well.  I didn't get far into the Bullying storyline so I'm not sure how that ends up.

original_text:
I feel that i need to shout this in all caps:

YOU DO NOT LOCK THE ONLY DECENT ENDING BEHIND COLLECTING RANDOM GARBAGE, are you kidding me?!

I could understand if it was plot-relevant diaries or something. It is not, you can miss them to your heart's content.  Instead here is what you need to do:

- Collect 10 red rooks
- Put 10 random (and I mean random) souls to rest using aforementioned 10 red rooks
- Collect 6 birds.
Some of that stuff is hidden in some asinine moon logic places. 

You do all that and your ending will be just abrupt and unsatisfying, and not, you know, infuriating. And that even not touching the fact that this game moonlights as anti-bullying PSA, with disclaimers and everything, and fails miserably at it. I'm serious, implications of the "normal" endings are insane, ill-advised and very irresponsible, just shy of The Medium and The Suicide of Rachel Foster (mostly because the subject matter is a little more tame). I'd recommend playing it with the achievement guide from the very beginning.

The game itself is alright, I guess. It's like Silent Hill for the beginners. It looks mostly good if you don't count very rough comic cutscenes, The pacing was tight before it did a nosedive due to 1,5h of garbage collecting.

I can VERY cautiously recommend it at 75% off or more.
===================================================

Is it just me or the grandpa in this game really looks like old Postal dude?

original_text:
🌟 A Hauntingly Beautiful Adventure! 🌟

GYLT is a gripping horror-adventure with a stunning, Kena-like art style—almost Pixar-quality but with a darker twist. The world is eerie yet mesmerizing, offering an emotional story backed by immersive exploration, light puzzles, and stealth mechanics. The soundtrack enhances the tension, making every moment feel suspenseful yet rewarding. The story (without spoilers) has mysteries that will make you think a lot. If you love narrative-driven games with breathtaking visuals and a haunting atmosphere, GYLT is a hidden gem worth experiencing!

🎧 I strongly recommend using headphones or earbuds for the best experience.

⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

The same exact quirk chungus indie game slop with reddit writing that I've seen a million times already, there's no point to engage with the environment and explore, the gameplay loop is worthless, the setting is ALL IN LE HEAD as usual and you have to actively LARP that the basic and boring enemy NPC's are scary in order to MAYBE have some amount of fun. I don't think I'll launch this game again after my first 1.5 hour session. Some of the plot points are about bullying - which is yeah, please, I really need yet another posh upper-middle class college grad game dev to preach about bullying, that's so brave and also very unique - and following a missing person, which is seriously so original for a horror game that I could just vomit.

You have to be an 8 year old to respect this game - but if you have an 8 year old, please do them a favor and just install an emulator and let them play actual quality products from the past instead of this basic pig feed.

original_text:
I don't think Gylt is necessarily a bad game but after about an hour, I don't really have any desire to go on so why recommend it?

This is a stealth game in a horror setting. The stealth mechanics are really basic and the AI is not smart at all. You can lose them way too quickly. With how dumb the AI is, it made me want to just play it sort of like an action game which also isn't much of a challenge.

People talk about an interesting story but after about an hour, there's hardly any story at all. There's a section early where you have to hide from a boss who shines a spotlight looking for you. If it spots you, you have to hide as it slowly drains your health. That section felt really buggy, I wasn't even in the spotlight and it would just snap to me. That was fortunately the only spot that felt rather buggy for me.

I may not have experienced many bugs but what I did experience after an hour just wasn't that appealing. Again, it's not a bad game, but it doesn't feel particularly good either.

original_text:
A close approximation of what playing a Laika movie might be, though perhaps not as well written or charming.

A pretty basic stealth game with some combat mechanics, it's certainly not a bad horror game for a younger audience.  Topics of the story are dark enough to warrant the warning that you see at the beginning.  Though the story is painfully predictable to the point that Sally (the MC) almost seems a bit of a goof for not connecting the dots way earlier.

It's an easy enough game to run through in a few hours, though make sure you grab all of the collectibles before the end.  None of them can be missed, but they are tied to one of the game's three endings.  All of which you can see on a single playthrough, so this game is comfortably a one-and-done in terms of that.

Overall?  A solid game.  Nothing fantastic, but far away from being bad.  It plays well, it looks alright, and the voice work is actually quite good!  It just falters at a few places, like the comic book cutscenes, the weird subplot that rather goes nowhere, and a fun, if disappointing, final boss.

analysis_results.chunk: A close approximation of what playing a Laika movie might be, though perhaps not as well written or charming.
A pretty basic stealth game with some combat mechanics, it's certainly not a bad horror game for a younger audience.
Topics of the story are dark enough to warrant the warning that you see at the beginning.
Though the story is painfully predictable to the point that Sally (the MC) almost seems a bit of a goof for not connecting the dots way earlier.
It's an easy enough game to run through in a few hours, though make sure you grab all of the collectibles before the end.
None of them can be missed, but they are tied to one of the game's three endings.
All of which you can see on a single playthrough, so this game is comfortably a one-and-done in terms of that.
Overall?
A solid game.
Nothing fantastic, but far away from being bad.
It plays well, it looks alright, and the voice work is actually quite good!
It just falters at a few places, like the comic book cutscenes, the weird subplot that rather goes nowhere, and a fun, if disappointing, final boss.

original_text:
Spoilers!!!!!

Quando eu comprei esse jogo ele não me dizia nada, apenas gostei do design e achei que merecia dar uma chance. O começo do jogo não me pegou muito, por já me apresentar como uma mecânica de stealth, mas quanto mais eu jogava e ia encontrando a Emily e também seus diários, mais o jogo me instigava a buscar respostas. A cada cutscene, parecia que surgiam mais perguntas do que respostas.

O final que eu escolhi, com a Emily indo e a Sally ficando e desaparecendo, me deixou ainda mais curioso com a história por trás daquilo tudo: o que era aquele lugar e como ele poderia ser uma cidade parecida com Bethelwood? Depois de tentar entender a narrativa, passando pelas mecânicas do jogo, que não são grandes inovações nem trazem dificuldades, mas que ainda assim são divertidas de jogar, posso dizer que esse jogo ganhou meu carinho. Um verdadeiro achado dentro da Steam.

original_text:
Don’t like horror but want to try it anyway? This game might be for you. 

Enjoy horror and are looking for your next game that keeps you on the edge of your seat? This game might not be for you. 

Gylt is a narrative singleplayer homage to games like Silent Hill and Little Nightmares rolled up into something that plays like a starter pack for getting into the survival horror genre. Whether you choose the route of hiding from your fears or fighting them head-on, all of the classic survival horror mechanics are present. The game is easy to understand, and I’d say even suitable to play for children that don’t get scared too easily. 

There are puzzles here and there, but nothing really different from what you may come across in other games. You’ll come across them through game progression or when looking for collectibles. 

It may also be worth mentioning that the camera controls are decelerated, so turning the camera with a mouse seemed extremely slow even at max sensitivity settings and occasionally felt like an issue during combat. If you decided to play with a controller instead, this may not be an issue. 

As a side note if anyone out there is interested, it was indeed developed to play on Windows, but I played it on Linux. The minor bugs that surfaced were easily fixed – they were inconvenient, but did not make the game unplayable. 

For me, the game wasn’t horrible, but it wasn’t great either. At the very least it may be worth a try if you're into this sort of thing.

analysis_results.chunk: Don’t like horror but want to try it anyway?
This game might be for you.
Enjoy horror and are looking for your next game that keeps you on the edge of your seat?
This game might not be for you.
Gylt is a narrative singleplayer homage to games like Silent Hill and Little Nightmares rolled up into something that plays like a starter pack for getting into the survival horror genre.
Whether you choose the route of hiding from your fears or fighting them head-on, all of the classic survival horror mechanics are present.
The game is easy to understand, and I’d say even suitable to play for children that don’t get scared too easily.
There are puzzles here and there, but nothing really different from what you may come across in other games.
You’ll come across them through game progression or when looking for collectibles.

It may also be worth mentioning that the camera controls are decelerated, so turning the camera with a mouse seemed extremely slow even at max sensitivity settings and occasionally felt like an issue during combat.
If you decided to play with a controller instead, this may not be an issue.
As a side note if anyone out there is interested, it was indeed developed to play on Windows, but I played it on Linux.
The minor bugs that surfaced were easily fixed – they were inconvenient, but did not make the game unplayable.
For me, the game wasn’t horrible, but it wasn’t great either.
At the very least it may be worth a try if you're into this sort of thing.

[i]Gylt[/i] is what I might call a wholesome horror game, as it has a story that is about understanding and overcoming bullying and depression. It is a little bit [i]Alan Wake[/i] in its gameplay, and in some ways it reminds me of [i]It[/i] or [i]Stranger Things[/i], but probably less mature.

My only complaint is that you have to collect some stuff to get the good ending, but its not that hard to find. I was thinking of recommending it for kids to play, but if they are too young it might be a little scary for them.

original_text:
A decently long adventure with minor elements of horror, the stealth is for the most part optional, and although the start of the game can feel a little underwhelming the game becomes more fun to play once you get past it. 
My only critique would be SPOILER ALERT 


The final boss was a little underwhelming as there was zero fighting, just a chase scene, but still!
I give the game a positive review as the gameplay mechanics were enjoyable, especially after being given tools to fight back, and the enemies were pretty unique from one another, you had decent boss fights and the animation and visual style of the game is very pleasing to the eye. 
Oh and there's multiple ending too! Gives great replayability :)

original_text: The graphics and art style are nice but the animations at times can be rather janky. The combat is atrocious so it's definitely better to stealth your way through the game. The spooky atmosphere is passable and the environments are varied. Aiming at monsters while using a controller is extremely sensitive and inaccurate, even with aim assist enabled. Overall it's not a terrible game, just pretty mediocre especially with the lack of enemy variety. The enemy designs are nice though. This could definitely be a kid's first horror game. It's weird that you are unable to hold the flash light and a can of soda at the same time. The last time I checked a little girls had two hands. What's also weird is that this game was using 100% of my GPU and made the fans spin at max speed. I've never heard my GPU become so loud before with any other game. Since there is no neutral rating on Steam I'll give this a thumbs up only because I don't think it's bad enough to give this a thumbs down. I do recommend this game but only for kids wanting an introduction to the horror genre.

I do recommend this game but only for kids wanting an introduction to the horror genre.

original_text:
a fairly standard stealth adventure game with light horror elements. It might spook you a bit for the first hour or so, but mercifully this is one of those modern horror games which don't try to scare you so much as unnerve you. Which is much better and the game does so wonderfully.

All of the gameplay elements, the stealth, the puzzles, etc are all a bit undercooked. None of it's bad but none of it's particularly good, so most of your enjoyment will have to come from the story. which is actually pretty good. The game is on the shorter side so it doesn't need to parcel out its story sparsely, with frequent cutscenes that don't drag on beyond what's needed. You'll also be reading journal entries from various characters that further explain what's going on with your cousin and what's happening in the town.

replayability is low however, apart from a few collectibles and different endings there's not much to the game. As afformentioned the gameplay is not particularly enticing by itself, so you can expect to be done and through with this game in a single playthrough. Which will take you about 6-7 hours. The are no difficulty modes or new game plus modes and the endings can be selected at the end and thus dont require seperate playthroughs.

Some advice for your playthrough however, the 3 different endings are good, bad and secret. The good ending is not particularly satisfying, so unless you're going to watch the other endings on youtube like me, i suggest you to carefully collect all the clay people collectibles. There's about 10 total in the game. Don't worry too much about getting everything in your first go as you can backtrack later and you'll get a warning before the final stretch begins.

Final rating: 7/10, its good but i'd wait for a sale unless the game really appeals to you.

Short and simple Alan Wake-style game that lasts about 5-6 hours to 100%. And do please 100%, the story is actually engaging enough to care about what happens to the characters and the true ending is the only one that isn't massively depressing, so please unlock it.

original_text:
Very much love this version of childfriendly horror. One might think that means a fun cutsie halloween like experience like Luigi Mansion 3. But no, not at all. 

This game is more like the book series "Scary stories to tell in the Dark". Subject matter and visuals that are creepy and unsettling, but not so much that kids would be traumatized for days after. In other words, scary and serious enough that kids would be able to appreciate the thrill of fear the way adult horror media does for adults. 

And its brilliant. We need more movies and games like this.

In terms of gameplay, its again, approaching that level of survival horror that isn't too taxing but enough so that you can tell if you were careless you would feel it. Its what easy mode should be in any game; not a braindead mode, but a mode that you have to take seriously but can easily enough bounce back if you got sloppy. 

But I will give one criticism to the gameplay. Due to the nature of the aim mechanic, being like og Resident Evil 4 with the laserpointer, the crosshair provided doesn't always line up to where the flashlight beam is aiming for combat or puzzle uses. With no option to turn off crosshairs, you just kinda have to learn to ignore it. Small thing, but still notable.  

In terms of story, I LOVE that it feels so much like Silent Hill. So much so, that this game could EASILY fit in the Silent Hill universe with very VERY minimal changes to background lore that doesn't even need to be found. Unless you want the best ending.

Thumbs WAY up on this one.

But no, not at all.
This game is more like the book series "Scary stories to tell in the Dark".

In other words, scary and serious enough that kids would be able to appreciate the thrill of fear the way adult horror media does for adults.
And its brilliant.
We need more movies and games like this.
In terms of gameplay, its again, approaching that level of survival horror that isn't too taxing but enough so that you can tell if you were careless you would feel it.
Its what easy mode should be in any game; not a braindead mode, but a mode that you have to take seriously but can easily enough bounce back if you got sloppy.
But I will give one criticism to the gameplay.

Due to the nature of the aim mechanic, being like og Resident Evil 4 with the laserpointer, the crosshair provided doesn't always line up to where the flashlight beam is aiming for combat or puzzle uses.
With no option to turn off crosshairs, you just kinda have to learn to ignore it.
Small thing, but still notable.
In terms of story, I LOVE that it feels so much like Silent Hill.
So much so, that this game could EASILY fit in the Silent Hill universe with very VERY minimal changes to background lore that doesn't even need to be found.
Unless you want the best ending.
Thumbs WAY up on this one.

original_text:
Overall GYLT is a really nice and a bit creepy 3rd person action adventure game with some puzzles, a bit of stealth, relatively easy combat and a few boss fights. I wouldn't call it horror since it's not too scary overall.

Level design is nice, controls work well, performance is good, puzzles are fair and well designed and the combat and stealth parts aren't too easy, but never frustrating. It feels like a good mixture of Little Nightmares, Alan Wake and Stray.

There's just one thing i didn't like at all: To get the good ending you have to find a lot of optional collectibles which is a bit frustrating, especially since the game doesn't give you a warning and the chance to say "no, i still have things to do" when the last mission starts. But you can get back to the campus in freeroam mode after finishing the game, collect the missing items and finish the game again to get the good ending (that's how i did it). But i still think this isn't a prime example of good game design since the game doesn't warn you and getting the collectibles requires a lot of backtracking an possibly a guide to find some of the better hidden items.

But overall i'd say: Really good game! Not a masterpiece, but except for the "finde certain collectibles to get the good ending" it's at least good in everything it does.

analysis_results.chunk: Overall GYLT is a really nice and a bit creepy 3rd person action adventure game with some puzzles, a bit of stealth, relatively easy combat and a few boss fights.
I wouldn't call it horror since it's not too scary overall.
Level design is nice, controls work well, performance is good, puzzles are fair and well designed and the combat and stealth parts aren't too easy, but never frustrating.
It feels like a good mixture of Little Nightmares, Alan Wake and Stray.

There's just one thing i didn't like at all: To get the good ending you have to find a lot of optional collectibles which is a bit frustrating, especially since the game doesn't give you a warning and the chance to say "no, i still have things to do" when the last mission starts.
But you can get back to the campus in freeroam mode after finishing the game, collect the missing items and finish the game again to get the good ending (that's how i did it).

But i still think this isn't a prime example of good game design since the game doesn't warn you and getting the collectibles requires a lot of backtracking an possibly a guide to find some of the better hidden items.
But overall i'd say: Really good game!
Not a masterpiece, but except for the "finde certain collectibles to get the good ending" it's at least good in everything it does.

original_text:
Fantastic story. It really hits close to home for me as I was bullied relentlessly in middle school. It felt like no one would ever stick up for me. Close friends didn't help or mention it. Teachers ignored it and pretended like they cared but never actually helped. I ran into the guidance councilor's office crying once... just to have her kick me out and tell me to get back to class...

I'm almost 30, now, and I have a tough shell... I confront things head on and I don't take anything from anyone... Push before they push you... Its not a good way to be. 

... If you see bullying happening... please help stop it... doing nothing leaves scars that won't heal on their own.


As for the game, itself:

Great stealth mechanics, movement is fluid, controls are intuitive (though space for crouch is an odd choice, but you get used to it).

A great survival horror game that had me panicking at times, but not so scary that it was hard to push forward.


o.o ...but those manikins are pure nightmare fuel...

Close friends didn't help or mention it.
Teachers ignored it and pretended like they cared but never actually helped.
I ran into the guidance councilor's office crying once... just to have her kick me out and tell me to get back to class...
I'm almost 30, now, and I have a tough shell...
I confront things head on and I don't take anything from anyone...
Push before they push you...
Its not a good way to be....
If you see bullying happening... please help stop it... doing nothing leaves scars that won't heal on their own.
As for the game, itself: Great stealth mechanics, movement is fluid, controls are intuitive (though space for crouch is an odd choice, but you get used to it).
A great survival horror game that had me panicking at times, but not so scary that it was hard to push forward. o.o...but those manikins are pure nightmare fuel...
